PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Senator Patterson—On a point of order, Mr President: where is the rest of the Government today at the beginning of this session in the Senate? There is one senator here representing the Government!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You know that is not a point of order.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 19 citizens), Senator Calvert (from 192 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 92 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Simplification Bills
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Those provisions of the "Sales Tax Simplification Bills" as applying to the payment of wholesale sales tax on spare parts by farm machinery manufacturers and dealers and its subsequent recovery is unfair and unreasonable in that it will;

PARA.TAB: 1)prejudice the financial viability of farm machinery dealers and manufacturing businesses
2)increase farm machinery prices and increase production costs that will further prejudice the viability and competitiveness of primary production
3)not give any net gain to Government revenue

PETITION.PARA: We therefore call on the Government to withdraw the provisions involved.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke-free International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Leader and members of the Senate of Australia. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that 219 hectares of reserved forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest in the Otways Rainforests, Victoria has been set aside as a flora reserve, but the rest of this catchment may be cleared for logging.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners humbly pray that this catchment may be wholly set aside as a National Estate to protect this unique rainforest.

PETITION.TITLE: Harvesting of Whales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Senators of the Parliament of Australia in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned secondary school students, as petitioners, urge members of the Parliament of Australia, to support as a matter of urgency the continuation of all present bans, inhibitions, agreements, contracts and compacts—against the taking of whales for harvest and/or for `scientific' research, from the worlds oceans, especially by the nations of Japan, Iceland and Norway.
Your young petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Exposure to Radiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) That exposure to radiation causes cancer, leukemia, and death;
(2) That the storage of radioactive wastes near urban areas risks the health of residents;
(3) That the Land and Environment Court of NSW has declared that the present storage of radioactive waste at Lucas Heights is illegal;
(4) That a Bill before the Senate seeks to remove all State restrictions on the storage of radioactive waste at this site.

Wherefore your Petitioners request that the Senate reject the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill 1992, and that the Senate take action to prevent the storage of radioactive waste in any populated area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)when the Labor Government came to office in 1983 there was just one tax on superannuation and now there are six,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That Government Business order of the day No. 1, the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and five related Bills, be debated without limitation of time.

SPEECH.PARA: We had an interesting discussion during the last sitting week as to whether the guillotine motion from the previous session still applied to the Sales Tax Assessment Bill. There was some controversy about that. I was of the view that it did and, in fact, that finally emerged as the predominant view. Notwithstanding continuing press reports of Opposition intentions to filibuster with regard to this Bill—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are your reports.

—That is a statement of fact: the press reports say that. I am sure that that would not be true and that this speakers list is a mirage which will evaporate. Therefore, contrary to the advice of many people who think this is an act of charity unjustified by history, and as another victory of hope over experience, I have nevertheless moved this motion so that we can proceed with the debate on these Bills, in the perhaps forlorn hope that we will have a reasonably constrained and informed debate and then get to a vote in reasonably good order.

—The coalition welcomes the motion moved by Senator McMullan. We would have been amazed had it not been moved because in the discussion of the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation on the Bills Senator McMullan did say that no guillotine would apply to the further consideration of these Bills. So the motion he is moving now simply gives legal form to that. We welcome the motion.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan has not read any press reports saying that the coalition will be filibustering these Bills. We have been at strenuous pains to say quite the contrary. What we have said is that these Bills, on the Government's own statement when they were originally introduced, represent the most significant changes to the sales tax legislation since its original introduction in 1930 and that, on those grounds alone, these Bills therefore require proper and due consideration in the Senate. That was why the Senate set up a select committee to look at them.

The Select Committee's work was cut from beneath it in many important respects by a statement by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) at 6 p.m. on the night before the Senate Select Committee was due to consider some of the 150 submissions it had received expressing concern about these Bills. The Treasurer put out a statement absolutely emasculating six of the key areas that the Bills were dealing with in the Government's so-called attempt to simplify the sales tax legislation. Those amendments are now in the Senate. They require, as does the general concept behind the whole simplification exercise, very detailed and proper consideration if we are to do our duty as elected members of the Australian Parliament.

These Bills were guillotined through the House of Representatives in 45 minutes flat, and those on this side of the chamber have no intention to resile from our responsibilities and give those Bills and their fundamental emasculating amendments the fullest possible consideration. We will not be filibustering the Bills, but I can assure Senator McMullan that we will have a full and informed debate on this matter because the Australian public would expect no less of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot have any more debate on this motion because technically it is still under the guillotine. Perhaps I should not have allowed the last speaker, but Senator McMullan's motion is taking us out of the guillotine.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
