TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that General Business, notice of motion No. 1042, standing in my name, relating to an Australian flag for the chamber, be taken as formal.
—Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal? As there is objection, it is not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate or to provide for the consideration of any other matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I gave notice of a motion to move that the Senate chamber be furnished with the Australian flag in a manner which is in keeping with the proportions and architecture of the chamber, to give a permanent outward sign of allegiance which we all owe the nation of Australia; to show respect for the commitment Australian men and women have demonstrated to the Australian flag throughout the history of Australia both in times of peace and war, and now as the unifying symbol for our sports people in the international arena; and to demonstrate that the Senate is proud to display the Australian flag. The final paragraph of the motion seeks to ensure that the flag be installed in the chamber within three weeks of the motion being carried.

PARA.TAB: This parliamentary building has been in use for over four years. This must be the only parliamentary chamber in the world that does not have its national emblem displayed proudly. After four years it is time for us to declare whether or not we want the flag in this chamber. The National Party and the Liberal Party have 100 per cent support for prominently displaying our national symbol in this chamber. We have a national symbol flying over this Parliament and we have two national symbols in the House of Representatives, yet this chamber is devoid of our national emblem. I think it is a shame, my colleagues think it is a shame and they think that it has gone on for too long. After four years it is time we made a decision. Not only do we think that this chamber should have a flag but also 64 per cent of the Australian people want to retain the Australian flag. I think the Senate should listen to the wishes of those people and display the flag in our chamber.

Over the past few months since Mr Keating was appointed Prime Minister we have seen him try to denigrate the Australian flag. We have seen him trying to use it as a diversion and a subterfuge to dismiss the problems of Australia's financial security. He has used it to divert attention from the needs of Australia. That will not wash. It is up to the Labor Party to support the Australian flag on a vote or to vote against it. But I tell honourable senators opposite that if they vote today against the Australian flag going into this chamber, the wrath of the people of Australia will come down on them. This will be the time when they either put up or shut up. The people of Australia are looking. The Labor Party cannot hide one way and divert the other way. It cannot go out and say that we should not have an Australian flag and then we should have an Australian flag. Senator Loosley says that we should get off the subject of the Australian flag. We want to know where the Labor Party stands. This will be the acid test for it today. Not only will it be an acid test, but also the Labor Party will be under the spotlight of Australia. It will be caught today, whether it is for or against the flag. Today it will be seen for what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop laughing at yourself.

—I am taking this matter very seriously. The Government has played fast and loose with the Australian flag for the last 12 months. There is division in the Labor Party. That division has to come out and the Labor Party has to come clean. Does it want the national symbol? Does it want to change the national symbol? It has five minutes to decide what it wants to do. It is going to make the biggest decision of its life and it will have to take it on the run, whereas the people on this side of the Parliament—I include the Democrats—are firmly convinced that the Australian flag should be proudly displayed in this chamber.

—If anyone had listened to Senator Boswell's speech they would not have realised that he was moving a contingent notice of motion to suspend Standing Orders to discuss an urgent motion. One would have thought that he was entering the general flag debate. What Senator Boswell has moved today and what he has said in his comments is a condemnation of several hundred senators in the past. If, as he is saying, this matter is of such urgency, why has something not been done about it over the past 91 years? I am not going to speak today, right now, about the subject matter of whether we should have an Australian flag on display in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Under Standing Orders opportunity is given to Opposition senators to bring up during General Business any matter they regard as being of high priority and to carry whatever motion they like. But it is interesting that no-one else—all those patriots who have served in this chamber for the last 91 years—has had to prove his patriotism by putting up a flag. They have always been patriots. They have always been great Australians and they do not need cheap chauvinistic tactics to prove it.

Today the Leader of the National Party in this chamber, who is not trusted with a front bench portfolio, is not putting before us trade issues as the most urgent matter. He wants to raise an issue of putting one symbol here. We have a symbol here. Whether we have another symbol will not be of great moment to the Australian people. But Senator Boswell, the man who walked into the party room, talked tough on sugar and then tugged the forelock and crawled to the rest of his Liberal colleagues and gave in, wants a diversionary tactic today. He wants a diversionary tactic because those opposite are all over the place on Opposition policy.

The good old boys of the National Party do not want the GST. But the one thing they want more than anything is ministerial office. So they go along with the GST and sell out their traditional supporters. They sell them out on sugar—we are going to get a zero tariff policy. So in comes a diversion. They do not know whether they are Arthur or Martha on trade policies. One of them is going off talking to Major. Others are going off to join the North American trade zone. They do not know where they are on policy, so they look for a diversion. And what could be a better diversion than to say, `We want this Senate to suspend all other business to discuss for the first time in 91 years whether we show the Australian flag in this chamber'. Well, Senator Boswell, that diversion will not work.

I will be quite happy to go out to the rural areas of Australia and say, `Your most senior representative in the Senate did not suspend Standing Orders to discuss tax policy, did not suspend Standing Orders to talk about the sugar tariff, did not suspend Standing Orders to talk about wheat, but in a cheap and absolutely pathetic way decided to come in here with a diversion today'. Senator Boswell has the opportunity to raise this motion during General Business if he is given priority to do so by his coalition colleagues—and they shudder every time he gets to his feet. He has had that chance.

Seeing that Senator Boswell is so fired up these days, why does he not come in with another motion and also add the knighthood issue. He wants to go back to the grovelling imperial system of honours so that he and the good old boys of the National Party can start giving out British honours. At least they will give them out for free now because we are on to them. They will not be able to sell the old knighthoods for fundraising—the good old boys from the National Party going back into the nineteenth century, tugging their forelocks to the empire. That describes absolutely what they are.

This is a diversion. They spend all their time at the State council meetings discussing who is going to be Lord this or Sir that. Do not worry about the farmers that they are supposed to represent; do not worry about the sugar growers that they have sold out; do not worry about any of these people. Come in here and run a useless diversion and then run out and say to the electorate, `We are more patriotic'. Well, patriotism is the way in which one serves the country, not the way in which symbols are put up. It has nothing to do with the chauvinistic cliches that those opposite go on with. It is to do with how one helps and develops the country.

Senator Boswell and the rest of his National Party colleagues have sold this country out. They are one of the reasons why we have had to restructure this economy. In the McEwen days nothing happened. All we ever got was protectionism, protectionism, protectionism. All we got was the old mercantilistic system.

Senator Boswell comes in here today and wants to suspend Standing Orders to discuss what is in terms of this country an irrelevancy. When did we ever have a flag in this chamber? This is not the flag debate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about the pot calling the kettle black! The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has actually voted against the Australian national flag—what a statement! The false line that Senator Ray just ran that somehow this was not a debate on the flag is a very simple lie, because this motion has been introduced to remedy something that has simply been overlooked.
—What, for 90 years?

—We have been in this building for four years. We are debating the question of the flag because this country's Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has denigrated our most potent national symbol in a foreign nation and made it an issue in an attempt to divert attention away from the state of the economy. That is what this Prime Minister has done. He cringes away from things which are Australian. So Senator Boswell today has moved a perfectly proper motion to remedy the fact that there is no flag in this chamber. Very simply, all Senator Ray had to do was acquiesce in the formal motion. He did not have to say a word. All he had to say was, `Yes, the motion can be formal', and the flag would have been in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to relate that the President of this chamber gives me a sense of pride in that he has chosen to have his portrait painted with our flag in that portrait. Yet this spineless band opposite wants to hear the Minister for Defence tell his troops that he is ashamed of the Australian national flag. He will not have it in this chamber because he will not agree to simply having a motion declared formal.In a moment we will hear bit more vitriol from the lovely Senator Schacht who spends more time out of this country than he does in it. He has no time for conventions or the things that are important to this country, so we expect a predictable speech from him.

There are two more things to say. This Labor lot is out of step with former Labor leaders. Bert Evatt described it as the most beautiful flag in the world; Arthur Calwell described it as attracting the proper respect which would, indeed, mean that people would follow the laws of this country. But the quote I like best is the one that came from an old digger who served this country well. In a letter which I received, he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: My dear mates who died in the Battalion would not believe what has happened. I do not whinge. My sense of humour overcomes pain, but I ask you now, do not add insult to my injuries, by abolishing the symbol which represents the spiritual qualities which invest a nation with nobility and integrity.

All Senator Ray had to do, to acknowledge that old digger's sacrifice for this land, was agree to a formal motion that said that our Australian national flag could be seen in this chamber here, but he and his Prime Minister have chosen to denigrate our flag and all it stands for. He, as Minister for Defence, has the gall to stand up and try to say that there is something improper about this debate. Shame on the Minister; shame on him.

PARA.TAB: This matter is urgent; when we have a Prime Minister who goes to a foreign land and denigrates our flag, it becomes urgent. Bob Hawke did not denigrate the flag; Paul Keating denigrated the flag. Senator Boswell has chosen to draw the nation's attention to the fact that those opposite—look at them, how many of them are prepared to stand up and speak? I have challenged Beazley to debate, I have challenged Bilney to debate, and they are spineless and gutless and will not do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who can they dredge up? Senator Schacht and Senator Evans.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! Could we have fewer interjections and a little less noise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I just want to bring the chamber's attention to the fact that those opposite are a spineless lot who cannot find people to defend their position. Shame on the Minister; shame on him. (Time expired)

—It is useful to drag this debate to what it is really about, that is, the suspension of Standing Orders. It is not, as has already been pointed out, about the flag or even whether we should have a flag in this chamber, although that is the substance of the substantive motion. Most people in this chamber should know that there is a recognised procedure by which motions are made formal, and that is that the Whips are notified and everybody is informed beforehand as to the intention of the mover of the motion. I understand that in this case that did not happen. The Government was not informed and was therefore taken by surprise in relation to this motion. For that reason, it is inappropriate that we suspend Standing Orders and accord this motion the importance of a full debate when there are so many other important things ready to be handled.

PARA.TAB: In looking at the motion—and I pointed this out to Senator Boswell when he brought the motion to me yesterday—we see that it talks about this chamber being furnished with `an Australian flag'. I pointed out to Senator Boswell that, should we decide to change the flag in, say, six or 12 months time, his motion would still obtain and that flag—perhaps a different flag—may well be in this chamber.

I am pointing to the actual words of the motion about which we are asked to suspend Standing Orders in order to debate. The words of the motion do not designate which flag on a future occasion may well turn up in this chamber. The motion would be quite consistent with the flag being changed and then appearing in this chamber. So the nonsense that Senator Bishop went on with is totally irrelevant, either to the suspension of Standing Orders or even to the substantive motion.

In our party room this morning, we considered the suspension of Standing Orders in order to debate a far more important issue—Senator Spindler's motion—which sought to do something very positive and very direct about the attack on Australia's trade in relation to wheat, using the US bases as a bargaining chip. That is something which I think most people would agree is a far more significant and far more important issue at the present time than whether we have a flag of whatever sort in this chamber. We chose not to seek to make that motion formal or indeed to suspend Standing Orders to debate that issue because, even with that important issue, we thought there were still far more important things which needed to be debated in this chamber today.

Frankly, I find the motion as it stands—the substantive motion—substantially innocuous. It does not identify which flag we may have at some future time. It talks about `an Australian flag'. Questions of the architecture of the place and the appropriateness of the colours of the flag in this chamber would have to be considered and, indeed, as the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), who is in the chamber, has pointed out, if it were so urgent why in over 91 years have we not had a flag in this chamber.

I come back to the matter which we really are debating, which is the suspension of Standing Orders. Senator Boswell, despite his very long time in this chamber, seems not to understand the normal procedures for formality. We believe it is inappropriate at this stage to allow him to suspend Standing Orders to debate this matter further at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It now appears that the Australian Democrats are not going to support a motion to allow us to debate whether we are to have our flag in our Senate in our Parliament. The reason advanced for not supporting this motion—the reason we have just heard for not wanting to choose to put an Australian flag in this chamber—is simply that there was some sort of procedural defect and that because the Government was not given notice of the intention to declare this motion formal they will not support a suspension of Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: The reason we are seeking to suspend Standing Orders is that the allegiance to our flag and the willingness of this Senate to display it in our chamber should be a matter that does not require debate. It is a matter that should not require more than a second's thought, yet members of this Government, so riven with their internal divisions, have lost sight of what it means to be senators in the Parliament.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I cannot not hear Senator O'Chee. We must allow the senator his call.

—Members of the Government have lost sight of what it means to be senators in the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. That is why they do not want this motion to proceed. I am sure that if the Democrats blocked this motion today and we gave them notice immediately after the division that tomorrow we would be seeking to make it formal, they would find another reason for wanting to run away from having our flag in our Senate chamber. How would the Democrats vote tomorrow if we had another motion to suspend the Standing Orders?

PARA.TAB: Some of us consider this motion to be very important. I know that people on the other side of the chamber, such as the good Senator Schacht, who, as Senator Bishop quite rightly says, seems to spend more time out of this nation than in it and therefore may not really appreciate what this flag is all about, may not want to have a vote to put this flag in this chamber. But what sort of Australians are those opposite if they do not believe in an Australian flag being in the Senate chamber? What sort of cringing people are they if they do not believe in displaying the prime emblem of our nation in this place? While Senator Schacht sits on the other side and laughs, although he does not do me a disservice, he does himself, this Parliament, this Senate and our nation a disservice.

We are telling honourable senators to think carefully about how they vote on this motion, because they will be judged not by their peers or the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—this is not a matter about whether Senator Schacht makes it to the front bench—but by history and the Australian people. They will be judged by the 17 million Australians who will ask, `If you lack sufficient pride in our nation to display our flag in the Senate chamber, what right have you to be senators in the Parliament of Australia?'. That is the question which we will decide today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion to suspend the Standing Orders. The Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, who is at the table, was very succinct about the sort of political stunt that this motion is. Firstly, I note that we have members of a delegation from New Zealand in here who are observing us in order to determine whether they want to establish a Senate in New Zealand. If they need any proof why they would be absolutely bonkers to establish a Senate in New Zealand, they have just seen it in the last half hour with this stunt of the Opposition in putting a motion like this. I say to these visitors: `Irrespective of whether you are in the Labour Party or National Party in New Zealand, please do not inflict on the New Zealand people an Australian-style Senate or you will live to regret it for the next couple of hundred years'.

PARA.TAB: I point out to Senator O'Chee and others who seem to have suddenly become super patriots that they do not prove their patriotism by a belief in the existing flag or any other flag design. I point out to Senator O'Chee and others on the other side, including `Dame' Bronwyn Bishop, who is so in love—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so stupid.

—There is no doubt, Senator Bishop, that the reason you want to support this motion put by Ronnie Boswell and the National Party, who are trying to bring back imperial honours, is so that you can be one of the first in the row to grab one.
—Senator Schacht, please refer to colleagues in this place and the other by their named titles.

—The situation is that last weekend the National Party had a national conference. The members carried a resolution about trade, but then they got down to the real serious business: they want to bring back imperial honours. Why does Senator Boswell not bring in here as a matter of urgency a motion to say, `We want imperial honours. We want to go back to the old Bjelke-Petersen days of Queensland when they were raffled or auctioned off'? People could get a knighthood for a $100,000 donation to the National Party or Bjelke-Petersen Fund. That is what knighthoods were, and that is what the imperial supporters of Queensland wanted the system for. For Senator Boswell to come in here and say he is a super patriot is hypocrisy.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise to a point of order. The motion of urgency is to discuss the question of having the Australian national flag in the chamber. Could you remind the good senator that that is what we are discussing, Madam Acting Deputy President, and not an aberration that he has fixed in his mind.
—Senator Bishop, I would have thought that, on the precedent of other contributors to this debate, Senator Schacht is in order.
—May I raise a second point of order?
—As long as it is not dissenting from what I just said, Senator Bishop.

—I would not want to dissent from your ruling at this stage, Madam Acting Deputy President. I just want to say that the subject matter of this motion is the Australian national flag. All speakers here have spoken about the importance and urgency of discussing the flag because it has been denigrated by the Prime Minister that we have. We are not discussing other items that may have been on the agenda of the National Party in Queensland.
—As I ruled before, Senator Bishop—and your second point of order goes close to repeating what you have already said—Senator Schacht is in order, given the precedent of previous contributors.

—There is no urgency in this motion. The Minister has pointed out that this matter can be dealt with in general business. In the 90-year history of the Senate the honourable senator's side of politics has unfortunately been in government twice or three times the amount of time we have been in government. Firstly, the Opposition has never decided to put the flag out in front, and, secondly, the Prime Minister's statement to which the honourable senator referred was made in April. It has taken seven months for it to become a matter of urgency and for Senator Boswell to bring it in here.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister said, this is a stunt today to divert attention from the mess the coalition is in over trade policies, tariff policies and the car industry. They have brought this on and are waving the flag in the hope that people miss all the problems the coalition is in over its economic policy. This motion has to be rejected. If it is brought back under general business with a proper debate, I will be more than happy to spend all my time in that debate explaining why I think there ought to be a change to the Australian flag and why patriotism is not the refuge of the last few scoundrels of the National Party.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time available to me, let me say that the issue is simply this: a motion has been brought before the chamber by Senator Boswell to rectify a very clear omission that has existed for 90 years and to put the Australian flag, our national symbol, in this chamber.I would not have thought it a particularly controversial matter. The Labor Party flies the Australian flag on its logo. Everywhere one goes one sees the ALP and the Australian flag. I would have thought the motion could have gone through in 30 seconds. The reason it has not is that Senator Ray and his mates have to come out and support Paul Keating's obsessive hatred of Australian national symbols. Senator Ray knows that is the reason. He was summoned to the Prime Minister's office; the Prime Minister said that this motion has to fail; and Senator Ray trots back to the chamber, whatever his beliefs—

—I rise to a point of order. I do not know whether it is in accordance with Standing Orders to invent the notion that I have been called down to the Prime Minister's office. I put this on the record for two reasons: firstly, as a pay-back for Senator Bishop's intervention and wasting time—I have just done that to Senator Kemp—and, secondly, to say that it is untrue.
—I raise a point of order.
—The time for this debate has expired. The question before the Senate is that Standing Orders be suspended.

—I raise a point of privilege, Madam Acting Deputy President. As you know, a point of privilege takes precedence over all other business of the chamber. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that not only is it a breach of standing order No. 193 to use offensive words against either House of the Parliament, but it is also a grave offence of privilege to do so.

PARA.TAB: In his contribution today, Senator Schacht said that this chamber was a prime argument why New Zealand should not adopt a Senate of its own. I did not take the opportunity at that point in time to call a point of order because I wished to give Senator Schacht his opportunity to have his speech. But it is quite clearly the case that Senator Schacht has used words which are highly offensive to this chamber and highly offensive to this Parliament.

Most importantly, Senator Schacht has followed the precedent of his Prime Minister by belittling the institutions of this nation in front of another nation. Therefore, I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to require Senator Schacht to withdraw his offensive comments against this chamber as they are not only out of order but also against the privileges of this Parliament.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! There is no point of order and there is no point of privilege.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Schacht commented that the reason why this motion was being moved had something to do with imperial honours. Such a comment is a gross slur on this chamber and it should be withdrawn. No-one in this chamber complained when Mr Walker and Mr Brereton wrote to the Governor after the fall of the Wran Government and requested that they keep their titles of `Honourable'. No-one thought that that was a particular slur on their chamber. When Senator Evans gave himself the title of QC, no-one complained in this chamber. So don't you go on about titles, Robert, you love them!
—Order! There is no point of order, Senator Kemp. The question before the Senate is that Standing Orders be suspended.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Boswell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this Bill will remove the sales tax exemption for certain recycled paper products. The following goods, if they are made wholly from recycled fibre, will become taxable:
.books of blank, lined or graph paper used for writing or drawing;
.toilet and facial tissues;
.paper bags marketed for household purposes or for use in marketing goods sold by retail.
These products will now be taxed on the same basis as similar goods that are made from virgin fibre or mixes of virgin and recycled fibres.

Following from the Industry Commission's report on recycling, the Government has decided that the sales tax exemption should remain but be narrowed to address problems that have arisen and to direct better the measure to environmental concerns. For example, high quality waste paper is used in the manufacture of tissues and paper bags which cannot be recycled again. This high quality waste paper could be used in other products, such as writing papers, which can be recycled several times.
The following products will remain exempt from sales tax where they continue to meet the requirements of the sales tax law:
.writing and drawing paper;
.pads of writing or drawing paper;
.paper for use in accounting ledgers and journals; and
.envelopes.
The exemption from sales tax will be removed with effect from 26 June 1992.
The removal of the exemption is estimated to result in a gain to the revenue of $11m in 1992-93 and $12m in 1993-94.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the instrument dated 25 May 1992, making changes to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991 (MSB Act) which deals with:

TAB.TAB: (a)the contributions to be made by members of the Defence Force who are members of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme established by the Trust Deed in accordance with section 4 of the MSB Act; and
(b)the benefits to be provided to members of the Military Superannuation Benefits Scheme upon retirement or to dependants of deceased members of the scheme;

PARA.TAB: made under subsection 5(1) of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991, approved by the Minister for Defence on 25 May 1992 and laid before the Senate on 3 June 1992, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: If ever there was an example for the New Zealand delegation present here today of the value of a house of review, I think the issue which is before us is such an example. I rise to speak today to my motion to disallow instrument No. 2 of 1992 relating to Defence Force superannuation.

PARA.TAB: I first learnt about this rule change to the military superannuation benefits scheme back in June and it concerned me when I heard about it. I sought advice and clarification from the Department, but the events that unfolded as a result led me to believe that something was seriously wrong. This belief has been confirmed by many detailed letters which I have received from defence personnel setting out their personal circumstances.

If the regulation were allowed to pass, approximately 2,048 defence personnel in a buy-back of service situation would have a portion of their own contributions stay in Consolidated Revenue rather than being transferred into the new military superannuation benefits scheme. Defence personnel currently have until 30 September to decide whether to stay in the old scheme, the DFRDB, or to transfer to the new scheme, the MSBS, in much the same way that Commonwealth public servants had to make a choice in July last year.

DFRDB is quite unique as far as superannuation schemes go. A compulsory 5.5 per cent of salary is paid by defence members, not into a fund like the public servants schemes but into Consolidated Revenue where the Government has full use of the money. Members who leave the forces before completing 20 years of service receive only their own contributions without any interest and without any employer contribution. They are required to take them; there are no rollover provisions in the Act.

If a service man or woman leaves after 10 years and then decides to rejoin the forces, he or she has the opportunity to buy back that previous 10 years of service with extra contributions from his or her salary. The Act says that this will be at a rate of 2.75 per cent. So, in sum, they will be paying 8.25 per cent of their salary to superannuation: 5.5 per cent for current service and 2.75 per cent for buy-back of previous service. One must remember that they have never had anything from the Government or any interest on that money, so they are not in a double-dipping situation.

The Sir William Cole committee, set up in June 1990 to review DFRDB, decided that as a scheme it was too difficult to convert to a proper defined benefit funded scheme and recommended that a new scheme be developed to accommodate all the requirements of the occupational superannuation standards. The Cole report also stated—this is a very important matter—that a defence member with a buy-back entitlement should be treated with equity in relation to a member who has had continuous service. This rule change would mean that personnel with buy-back entitlements would not be treated with equity in relation to a member who had had continuous service.

The MSBS was introduced in April 1991 and both DFRDB members with continuous service and those with a buy-back entitlement became eligible to transfer, except that the ones with the buy-back entitlements must finish contributing all that they need to in order to have completely bought back their previous service. If they do this and transfer to MSBS, they will, like all Commonwealth public servants, receive an employer benefit for their entire time of service.

The Government decided in October last year that those who had a buy-back entitlement but had not yet finished the process could catch up by buying the buy-back in lump sum form instead of by contributions. This was to enable those who wished to transfer to MSBS to have all of their service counted for the notional employer benefit MSBS was set up to provide. Remember also that the buy-back contribution lump sums are paid into Consolidated Revenue, not into a super fund.

Some have paid for their lump sum buy-back with savings, others with a personal bank loan. Some have chosen to offset the balance of what they need to have finished buying back with the total amount that they have contributed during the second period of service. But all have put their own money into DFRDB and bought back their previous service.

This rule change, made in May this year, will effectively say that, retrospectively, any lump sum contributions made since October last year will now be treated as debt to the Commonwealth, will stay in Consolidated Revenue and will not be transferred over to the new scheme. There are about 2,048 people in this situation, and if their money stays in Consolidated Revenue it will mean a windfall gain to the Commonwealth of approximately $12m to revenue. That is $12m paid by service men and women from their own resources—$12m which would have remained credited to their names in the DFRDB scheme to be paid back to them eventually from Consolidated Revenue on their retirement.

For people leaving after less than 20 years service, those DFRDB contributions will be all that they receive—no employer benefit at all. By transferring to the new superannuation scheme they will lose their money. The argument in support of the rule change says that there is windfall gain to the member, an argument which does not stand up to close scrutiny. In fact, advice from the Economics and Commerce Group of the Parliamentary Library confirms this. In the paper provided to me it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: DFRDB members purchasing past service with outstanding debt effectively have their transfer value reduced by $2 for every $1 balance of outstanding debt.
This is not, I would think, intended policy. Rather, it reflects from an accounting and actuarial perspective a poorly defined transfer value. Further, the paper from the Parliamentary Library said:

The instrument made by the Minister under subsection 1(5)(i) of the MSBS Act will not remedy the anomaly. Rather, it will remove the opportunity for DFRDB members purchasing past service who repay their debt to be placed in the same position as DFRDB members with continuous service. This creates a further anomaly.

This advice has not been discredited by anyone. I gave that advice to Senator Ray's office. As I told the Minister two months ago and confirmed to him in my letter of 30 June, I did not wish to make this matter a public issue. MSBS, the new scheme, is an excellent scheme for the majority of defence personnel and I did not wish to frighten those who should transfer to it. So I went to Minister Ray with my concerns in June, having had difficulty with Minister Bilney's office. I appreciate the fact that Minister Ray took the matter seriously and, as a result, had the matter referred to the Australian Government Actuary. But, being a personnel issue, his office then handed back the issue to Minister Bilney.

PARA.TAB: My staff member spoke to the Government Actuary early in July and he indicated that he had already looked at the matter and responded on 2 July. My office tried to get hold of his report from Minister Bilney's office, but to no avail. Throughout July and August, Minister Bilney's office kept saying that it was coming. But it never did. Not until mid-August, having once again telephoned Senator Ray's office, did I receive the report.

The report was accompanied by a letter from Minister Bilney indicating that the Actuary was taking a further look at the matter. Despite several phone calls and messages to the Actuary, we were not able to secure his final report until just before the debate on this disallowance motion was due to take place in the last sitting session. For this reason I agreed to postpone the debate on the disallowance motion. I was reluctant to do this due to the imminent commencement of the MSBS scheme at the end of September and because this matter could not wait any longer, as servicemen only have until then to join the new scheme.

The Actuary's second report points out that there is no unintended windfall to the serviceman, which is the reason put forward by the Government as justification for the regulation. The second report of the Actuary, however, also points out that the view held by the Opposition and the Parliamentary Library on the rule change is reasonably held, and Minister Ray has accepted this advice. I must say in passing, however, that if I were in business and had asked the Actuary for a report on which I intended to act, I would have refused to pay the bill for the report. It can be fairly criticised, I think, for trying to have two bob each way and being a pretty inadequate basis for ministerial decision making.

Nevertheless, I am glad to say that Minister Ray has now advised me that he will not be opposing the disallowance and will be recommending to the MSBS trustees that a further rule change be introduced to ensure that those who have already made their decision, vis-a-vis a transfer from DFRDB to MSBS, will be treated equitably. We will, of course, as I said to the Minister, scrutinise the new rule when it comes before the Senate.

I do welcome the Minister's wise and proper decision and I commend him for his readiness to have this matter properly investigated. But there is, sadly, more to be said about this issue. I think fellow senators and the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, will be appalled to learn of some of the backroom behaviour that took place in trying to ensure that this rule change went through come hell or high water.

I have no doubt that Minister Bilney may not be on top of the intricacies of superannuation. However, on his staff he has Mr Finnegan, whom one would expect to know all about superannuation because he comes from the human resources area of the Defence Department. He went through the revolving door and came back into the Department as a consultant to the new military superannuation implementation team. He is now in the Minister's office as senior adviser. A former colleague of Mr Finnegan is Mr Peter Skinner, who is head of the MSBS implementation team. Mr Skinner, incidentally, has recently been appointed Deputy Commissioner to the Retirement Benefits Office and an alternate member of the MSBS board of trustees. I am seriously concerned about this appointment. As a trustee, he has a compelling legal duty to protect the members of his trust. I fear that Mr Skinner does not appear to understand this.

It is my belief that Mr Skinner, as head of the MSBS implementation team, has wrongfully and wilfully advised the Government that these bona fide superannuation contributions from 2,048 defence service personnel should not be credited to them and should remain in Consolidated Revenue. I can only speculate that Mr Skinner started off by making an honest mistake, which he then tried to cover up by his subsequent behaviour. This advice was accepted by Minister Bilney's office, but I cannot be sure whether the Minister knew the entire story. I suspect that he might have been informed on a need to know basis. I understand that this matter was handled by Mr Finnegan, Mr Skinner and Mr Alan Thompson, First Assistant Secretary, Human Resources and Management Division, and by the Assistant Chief of Personnel, Rear Admiral Stubington.

I am also dissatisfied that Sir William Cole, as Chairman of the board of trustees, refused to have the matter reviewed or re-looked at when it was put to him by the military representatives on the board. The need for independence of the Chairman from the Public Service and from the Department is obviously essential.

My colleagues would be aware that I am rarely given to strong and extreme language, but the developments that occurred in relation to this issue compel me to speak out. I suspected that something was very wrong when Mr Finnegan directed my research officer not to speak about the matter with anybody in the Department of Defence except Mr Skinner. A letter to the same effect was promptly received at my office. This was despite an earlier arrangement, which had been working for some time with Senator Ray, that my office could go direct to the Department for advice when necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the Bill.
—No, on a range of things—when Senator Ray first became Minister.
—Through a Minister's office.
—No. I do not want to debate that now.
—There is a misunderstanding there.

—I will press on. Other members of the MSBS unit who disagreed with Mr Skinner had tried to take action on the matter through official channels and had been knocked on the head for their efforts. When one of those members became so concerned and frustrated about what was going on and was put in touch with my office, he was removed from his position by Mr Skinner. I requested a briefing on Commonwealth superannuation generally from the office of the Minister for Finance. This appeared to be acceptable and then was mysteriously refused. That brief was eventually given after I complained to Senator Ray.

PARA.TAB: I cannot understand why Mr Finnegan and Mr Skinner did not realise that their actions were not consistent with the behaviour of people with nothing to worry about. If the case Mr Skinner was putting to me was correct, what did he have to fear from anybody else talking to me? Why the cover-up? Why the closing of doors and the withholding of information? Alternatively, if it was at Minister Bilney's behest, what did the Minister have to fear?

My suspicions were confirmed when I came across a document written by Mr Finnegan and faxed from Minister Bilney's office to Mr Thompson, the First Assistant Secretary in the Department. For the benefit of those who believe that bureaucrats are there to serve the public interest, I intend to read that document into the public record. It is headed `23 July 1992, 8.19 a.m., Science and Personnel'. The headline is `Reference Response to Senator Newman on MSBS rule change'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: ACPERS told me the other day that he intends to seek a follow on opinion from the Actuary. I was not clear on what point. Perhaps you might check with him as we don't want egg on our collective face over this issue.

PARA.TAB: Have we seen the parliamentary library opinion to which Senator Newman's letter refers? If so, should we have the actuary look at it? At the least, should our reply mention it?
We will be strengthening the reply to para 3 of Senator Newman's letter. There is no doubt among MPs about the rules on going to the Department: it is with the Minister's knowledge and sanction.

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers have to rely on their advisers and they expect that advice to be the right advice. Ministers are not well served by only being give one opinion when there is more than one view on important issues. A smothering of one opinion and a closing of access to information serves only those who are trying to further their own agenda. How can any Minister, Labor or Liberal, rely on the advice of people such as these?Only recently, former Labor Minister Clyde Holding in an article on defence management said, `How can you govern a country with bastards like that running the Department?'.

PARA.TAB: As I said at the beginning, I was disappointed that it had to get to this stage. I had hoped the matter would have been speedily resolved but I did not anticipate the determination of some public servants to cover their backs and their tracks, as has happened in this case. I cannot understand why they have been carrying on with all this Keystone cop activity. I will not be snowed or misled by members of the Public Service, particularly when the rights and well-being of our defence forces are at stake. But nor can I condone the misleading of a Senate committee by a Minister of the Crown.

I draw the Senate's attention to a letter signed by Minister Bilney on 21 August to the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The purpose of the letter was to answer concerns of the Committee in relation to this rule change. The Minister wrote two pages of justification and explanation. But he attached to his letter by way of supporting evidence the report from the Government Actuary. Unfortunately, however, the report that he attached was dated 2 July—that is, it was the first report from the Government Actuary. But at the time Minister Bilney sent that letter to the Committee, he had already received the second report from the Government Actuary dated 19 August but in fact delivered to my office by Steven Duffy of Minister Bilney's office on 18 August.

So irrespective of whether it was 18 or 19 August, the Minister wrote that letter to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee on 21 August. He concealed from that Committee the fact that there was a second report in which the Government Actuary had changed his advice. It is on the basis of that second report that Minister Ray is prepared not to oppose the disallowance motion. I find it totally unacceptable that this Senate could accept such action from a Minister of the Crown. Clearly there has been an attempt to mislead a Senate committee—a most important committee because it plays such an important role in protecting the rights of citizens. I draw that matter to the attention of the Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinance Committee.

I intend to disallow all four points in the instrument, even though the matter I have spoken about relates only to the second point. The reason for this is that under the Act any rule changes to the MSBS Act are required to go before the board of trustees before being implemented. I am informed that Mr Skinner did not put the other three items before the board, and this was confirmed last night at a Senate Estimates committee meeting. Mr Skinner has no right to make changes to a superannuation scheme that affects the futures of many people, without putting them before the board of trustees.

I recognise that the board insisted that such action should not occur again and that Mr Skinner apologised. Nevertheless, Mr Skinner is now Deputy Commissioner of the Retirement Benefits Office and an alternate member of the MSBS board of trustees. He is not a clerk. As a result of his behaviour over this whole issue, I have serious concerns about these appointments. His conduct leaves many serious questions unanswered and he appears to have inadequate concern for the well-being of the very defence personnel for whom he holds a trust.

Being a trustee is a most serious and important appointment and one which is covered by an important body of our laws. Great care must be taken in making such appointments, and trustees must be subject to close and continuing scrutiny as they fulfil their positions of trust. The conduct of those associated with this rule change is a cause for serious concern.

As I move this motion to disallow, I once again welcome the fact that Minister Ray, having given the matter close attention, as I asked him to, will not be opposing the motion. He understands that he has an important responsibility to Australian service men and women and that their confidence in their new superannuation scheme must not be undermined by Government action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a disallowance motion for defence superannuation regulations. This issue is one of the fairness of regulations concerning the military superannuation schemes. Under the current Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme, members who leave the service of the defence forces and take a refund of their superannuation contributions but subsequently rejoin the services may buy back their superannuation entitlements to the previous period of service. This is a long-standing provision and is supported by the Australian Democrats and, I presume, by the other parties in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The new scheme, the military superannuation benefits scheme—MSBS—also enjoys the unanimous support of members of the Senate. The scheme was introduced with the usual rights afforded to existing superannuants. That is, existing members would have the option of transferring from the existing system to the new system if they so elected. It is the rules that apply to transfers from the old DFRDB to the MSBS by Defence Force members who are currently buying back their previous service that are the target of this disallowance motion.

Put simply, if a member still has an outstanding balance of unrepaid contributions relating to a previous period of membership of the superannuation fund at the time of the transfer into the MSBS, the unpaid value of the previous service is deducted from the transfer value of the member. However, the transfer value should then take into account the fact that the previous service has become fully paid up. That is, the value of repurchased service must also be taken into account in the calculation of the transfer value, otherwise the member will be extremely and unfairly disadvantaged. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter explaining the anomaly .
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to you in relation to an inequity that exists in the arrangements for transferring from the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme (DFRDB) to the new Military Superannuation Benefits Scheme (MSBS). This inequity affects those members who, at the time of transfer, have an outstanding balance on the purchase price of a previous period of service. The unfairness of the formula used to calculate a member's transfer value can lead to the loss of thousands of dollars of equity in the MSBS. The recent rule change by the MSBS Board of Trustees only compounds the inequity. My own situation is a case in point.

I am a member of the ADF with over 11 years service. That period of service comprises a previous period of seven years and a current period of four and a half years. When I reentered the ADF on 11 January 1988 I elected to have the previous period of service recognised as a period of qualifying service, as was my right under Section 64(1) of the DFRDB Act. I effected purchase of that previous service by fortnightly instalments in accordance with the provisions of Sections 64(2) and 126(1) of the DPRDB Act.

My concern is that, should I elect to transfer from the DFRDB Scheme to the MSBS, I would be doubly debited for the amount of the outstanding balance of the buy back price of my previous period of service. This constitutes a substantial financial loss and creates an inequity that is contrary to the DFRDB Review Board's principle that equity must be preserved and that the transfer arrangements should not disadvantage members.
It would be useful to demonstrate this inequity by way of example.

My 11+ years of service comprises a previous period of 7 years and a current period of 4+ years. DFRDB contributions for the current period amount to $10,017. Purchase price of the previous 7 years of service amounts to S16,789. Of this amount $3,899 has been repaid through fortnightly instalments, leaving an outstanding balance of $12,890. The notional interest entitlement for NSBS transfer purposes amounts to $3,079.
If the outstanding balance had been repaid in full (either by payment of the last instalment or by a lump sum payment of any
outstanding amount) prior to the rule change in May this year, my DFRDB account balance on transfer to MSBS would have been as follows;
Case 1—Payment by instalments completed.
DFRDB contributions for the current period (a) $10,017
Additional contributions for previous service (b) $16,789
Notional interest (c) $3,079
Account balance (a+b+c) $29,885
Case 2—Payment of outstanding balance by lump sum payment.
DFRDB contributions for the current period (a) $10,017
Additional contributions for previous service (b) $3,899
lump sum payment of outstanding balance (c) $12,890
Notional interest (d) $3,079
Account balance (a+b+c+d) $29,885
In both cases I consider that the account balance accurately and fairly represents my contributions to, and hence my equity in, the superannuation scheme.

Now the MSBS transfer provisions allow a member to offset any outstanding balance on the purchase of previous service against credit in his/her DFRDB account. This is to facilitate the clearance of any debt prior to entry to the MSBS. While this is commendable in principle, the formula used to apply the offset and hence calculate the transfer value, unfairly penalises the members by doubly debiting them for the amount of the outstanding balance. Applied to my situation the account balance, or MSBS transfer value, as determined by the transfer formula becomes:
DFRDB contributions for current period (a) $10,017
Additional contributions for previous service (b) $3,899
Notional interest (c) $3,079
Less outstanding balance on previous service (d) $12,890
Account balance (a+b+c-d) $4,105

This calculation shows that the outstanding balance on previous service has been paid out but clearly, does not show that the value of the previous service purchased has not been fully recognised. Indeed, I have purchased previous service to the value of $16,789 (comprising $3,899 paid by instalments and $12,890 paid from existing DFRDB contribution credits) but only $3,899 is recognised.
The equitable way to determine the transfer value is to give recognition to the total value of the purchase price of previous service. My situation should be as follows:
DFRDB contributions for the current period (a) $10,017
Notional interest (b) $3,079
Less outstanding balance on previous service (c) $12,890
Plus value of the previous service purchased (d) $16,789
Account balance (a+b)-(c) + (d) $16,995
This transfer value of $16,995 reflects the value of the contributions made in the current period of service and the total value of previous service purchased.

Indeed, this is exactly how my equity in the DFRDB Scheme would be determined if I chose to remain in DFRDB. I fail to understand why I should be penalised a considerable financial sum on transfer to MSBS, particularly when the Review Board's intention was to ensure that members would not be disadvantaged.
I ask you to consider this grossly unfair anomaly and seek your assistance to having it rectified.

TALK.START.PARA: —This letter clearly and succinctly shows the anomaly that arises under the current regulations and why the Democrats will be supporting this disallowance motion. I note that the Government will not be opposing the disallowance motion, and I commend the Minister for that action. I have also noted very carefully the description of the difficulties that were experienced with the respective Ministers' officers as well as with the Public Service, and I look forward to the Minister's reply to the statements that were made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have made a contribution so far. I thank Senator Newman for again proving me right. In my comments yesterday I said that she would spend more time on the process than the substance of the matter; although I also understand that, if she believes that I am not going to debate in depth the substance of the matter, that may have been a self-fulfilling prophesy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler invites me first of all to comment on the process. I do not subscribe to the conspiracy theories that we have heard today from Senator Newman. I do not say that the advice of the Department of Defence has been with the consistency and clarity that I would require of advice from officers, but this is an exceptionally complex matter. However, I do not subscribe to the conspiracy theory that in some way Senator Newman was fundamentally led up a dry gulch; nor do I necessarily say that she was given a carte blanche in 1990 to speak to everyone in the Department. Certainly on this issue I know she approached me very early on—this is before the legislation—asking whether she could get advice and so on, and I said yes.

The normal procedure, though, if one wants to approach people in the Department is to come through the Minister's office, and Mr Downer and Senator Durack have done that. So there may be a misunderstanding there. I do not think there has been one occasion on which Senator Durack or his successor, Mr Downer, have approached me for a briefing on bases or anything else when they have been refused. I believe Defence is not as combative a portfolio in that sense as some other policy-making portfolios and that maximum access should be given to all parliamentarians, but especially their spokesmen.

As I said at the start, this is a very complex issue. Even though the Senate today will disallow this rule change, I do not believe that the new rule change can be particularly condemned. We are looking at two entirely different superannuation schemes. Trying to move from one scheme to another and bring about consistency is an exceptionally difficult task. The old scheme essentially required 20 years service. It meant that contributions, made at 5.5 per cent of one's salary, went into Consolidated Revenue and one achieved a pay-out at the end of it. The new scheme is quite differently constructed.

It is fair to say that those with continuous service have been given two very clear options: either to stay in the old scheme or to come into the new scheme. They will make that decision with only one factor in mind: self-interest—what scheme offers them the best deal. Quite clearly, either scheme, depending on one's circumstances, could be preferable to the other. We do not really have a problem with continuous service. The problem arose with broken service and how we were to deal with that.

The first and absolute decision made by the board of trustees, reflected in legislation, is that no-one can carry a debt into the new scheme. I do not think anyone disputes that that should be the case. I think we all agreed when the legislation went through that no-one should take a debt into the new scheme. If one were to transfer from the old scheme to the new scheme, all debts had to be settled one way or another.

In defence of the new rules change which we are going to disallow, it must be remembered that it was really a reflection that, when people paid off their debt, they were paying it off to achieve the employer benefit. That is the nub of the question; that is the reason it was done. But as a consequence, the method and total of paying off affected what employee benefit one would get back, and that has been the nub of the question that the Department has been trying to tackle over time.

Before the new superannuation scheme was even in its embryonic stages, people with split service had two potential methods of getting back into the superannuation scheme. They could make a lump sum pay-in when they rejoined the defence forces or they could have a deduction from their pay. In other words, they could increase their contribution from 5.5 per cent; usually another 2.75 per cent was added.

It would not surprise anyone in this chamber that, in those circumstances, everyone—I do not think there was an exception—opted for the increased contribution, which meant they would pay it off over time. The difficulty with that is: when one is in a transition period, moving from one scheme to another, and one is required to be fully paid off but has not paid it off, what method should be adopted?

The trustees quite clearly thought that everyone would use the offset method; that is, the amount they owed would be deducted from the amount they paid in. That is certainly a fair way of them achieving their qualification for the employer contribution down the track. However, because—and it was not just in October as Senator Newman mentioned; this has been a continuing thing—lump sum pay-out was possible and because it affected, in a different scheme, the amount of one's own money one got back, that in turn led to a situation where suddenly a pay-out allowed a much better result than the offset where one had one's debt deducted from what one had contributed. It left an entirely different result—not in terms of what one got back from the employer but in terms of what one got back from one's own contributions.

One of the things that the new rule change tried to do was affect that particular disadvantage. In other words, if there were two servicemen, one of whom had the cash, either by borrowing or in savings, needed to pay out, he was substantially advantaged over the other who could not accumulate those assets to pay it off—even though I am sure one could make a rational argument, in terms of interest rates, inflation rates and everything else, that it was really in the person's interest to pay off. Therefore, the rules change was brought in to make everyone equal.

There is another viewpoint that we can put over the top of that; that is, how people with continuous service are treated compared with people with broken service. I am arguing that the rules change was essential to give equal treatment to those with broken service, but, on the other hand, does that create a disadvantage for those people compared with those in continuous service?

One can look at the matter two ways. Both ways are right in terms of equity; the issue is just about which one we should prefer. Senator Newman referred to the Government Actuary's advice—the two bob each way advice. He acknowledged that either view could be accepted.

If today we disallow this regulation—somewhere in the order of 2,100 to 2,300 people have not made a decision; I put on the public record that I am not particularly concerned that the cut-off date is in 20 days because they have all been thinking about it up to this point and making arrangements—they will be able to make that decision in the next 20 days. What we do not know is how many will make that decision.

One other aspect of this scheme is that if people do not elect to transfer they are kept in the old scheme. We do not know how many people have decided, `I am not going to transfer, so why should I bother putting in the declaration because I will be automatically kept in the old scheme'. So we could have any proportion of people staying in the old scheme—which will mean that nothing is affected here—or up to 2,300 people suddenly switching in the next 20 days. I cannot even make a guess as to who is affected.

In the meantime, if we disallow this today, we have to give some consideration to those 170 people who have made a decision to transfer from the old scheme to the new scheme by way of an offset rather than a lump sum payment because from May to September they did not have the opportunity of choosing a lump sum payment. As late as midnight last night we were wrestling with this problem. We have come to the conclusion that we cannot do it by administrative means: we are so entrapped by the rules under the Act that that is impossible. But we believe that we can fix up the 170-odd people by way of a rules change.

Those people have not had the opportunity of making the same plans as others in the last few months. People know that we were not able to put in a rule to change the cut-off date. Because these people have elected into a scheme, they are no longer affected by the cut-off date. It will be possible to do a subset of this rules change to give them 90 days to make their arrangements. So we are not in breach of the legislation because they have already elected. Only those who have not elected will be hit by the 30-day cut-off date. So we will be under way to write a rule to in effect give those 170 people the same right as those who elected to make a lump sum payment before May and those who, subsequent to today, want to make a lump sum payment. For the neatness of the public record I will incorporate in Hansard a two-page advice from the Actuary which, as I think Senator Newman has seen, is the first advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is dated 2 June.

—Yes. I then want to incorporate a five-page advice from the Actuary dated 19 August and a letter, which is not signed because I have a draft copy of the letter, that was sent to Senator Giles as the Chairperson of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.
—The first Committee.

—The information that Senator Newman has given us is that the first report of the Actuary was attached to it. I do not have it attached to my draft copy. Nevertheless, I would like the three items incorporated in Hansard so that people can read them.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr A.G. Thompson
First Assistant Secretary
Human Resource and Management Division
Department of Defence
Russell Offices
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Mr Thompson
MSBS RULES—BUY BACK ARRANGEMENTS
Thank you for your minute of 25 June.

As requested, I have examined the appropriateness of the recent change to the MSBS Rules, in the light of the principles established in the DFRDB Review Committee Report. This Report is extremely comprehensive and has formed the basis both for the design of the MSBS and for the transfer arrangements offered to members of the DFRDB who wished to join MSBS.

The treatment of DFRDB buy back arrangements was considered by the Review Committee, and their conclusions are stated in paragraphs 15.21 to 15.23 of their Report. These conclusions may be briefly stated as follows:
(i)no buy-back arrangements would be permitted in the MSBS

(ii)where a DFRDB member has entered into a buy-back arrangement then the MSBS will give full credit for prior service in the calculation of the employer financed benefit, whether the buy-back had been completed or not
(iii)where a buy-back has been completed, the transfer value, calculated as member contributions plus notional interest, would include all contributions made for the buy-back

(iv)where a buy back has not been completed, the transfer value would be calculated as member contributions plus notional interest (including contributions actually made towards the buy-back) less the outstanding amount of the buy-back price. (If this produced a negative result, then the member would be required to pay to DFRDB the amount of the deficiency before they could transfer).

In the Report the Review Committee state that `Repayments [of the buy back price] are on a fortnightly basis'. There is no qualification to this statement, which is not in fact correct: repayments were most commonly made fortnightly, but members in the DFRDB have always had the option of making lump sum payments towards their outstanding buy back obligations. It is therefore reasonable to suppose that the Report lays down the method which should apply when repayments are made on a fortnightly basis, but this may not necessarily be applicable to lump sum repayments.

Now it is a peculiarity of this method that, for a member with an outstanding buy-back obligation, each $1 of contribution made towards the buy back will increase the member's transfer value by $2. If the buy back contributions were on a fixed fortnightly basis (as the Committee assumed) the peculiarity would not have given rise to any particular problems. However, since members can choose to make lump sum payments, it would obviously be in their interests to do so, if they are able to afford it. So an anomaly would be created between members who can afford to make lump sum payments, and those who cannot.

The recent Rule change redresses this anomaly, by effectively applying the Committee's method at 1 October 1991, and providing that each $1 of contributions made thereafter will only increase the transfer value by $1. In my view, this is a reasonable approach in the circumstances.

I have also examined the alternative point of view enclosed with your minute. This alternative approach involves a rejection of the Committee's clearly stated conclusion, summarised in (iv) above. There would obviously be many problems if any of the Committee's conclusions, reached after full and detailed consideration, were to be re-opened at this stage in the transfer process. I have therefore not examined the merits of this alternative approach in any detail. However, I would point out that if the Committee's conclusions were to be offered for a re-consideration, then there are a number of different approaches which could be taken, some of which would be more favourable to members, while others would be less favourable to members, than the approach adopted by the Committee.
I hope this is helpful to you.
Yours sincerely,
D.B. Duval

Mr A.G. Thompson
