Dear Mr Thompson
MSBS RULES—BUY BACK ARRANGEMENTS

Thank you for your minute of 23 July 1992. I have now examined the alternative approach in some detail. In order to do this I have had to consider the broad context of the arrangements for transfer from DFRDB to MSBS, and also the buy back arrangements in DFRDB.

In this letter I give my opinion on the `official' view, as represented by the current regulations, including the amendment made on 27 May 1992, and the `alternative' view presented in a paper attached to your minute of 25 June 1992.

In forming my views I have had the benefit of meetings with Mr Skinner from the MSBS Implementation Team and Mr van den Tol from the office of the Director General Service Conditions. This enabled me to get a clear picture of the issues.

In the discussion which follows I have ignored the notional interest which is added to employee contributions on transfer to MSBS. It has an effect on the figures but confuses the questions of principle which this letter addresses.

The structure of the DFRDB was that members who leave get either an employee benefit (return of contributions) or a defined employer benefit (partly commutable pension) depending on their years of service. Under MSBS, all members who leave get both an employee benefit (return of member contributions plus interest) and a defined employer benefit (preserved benefit).

This difference in structure clearly makes it difficult to determine what is an equitable transfer arrangement. The arrangement adopted was to give credit in MSBS for both the period of service in DFRDB and the contributions paid to DFRDB. In effect the transferring member commenced in MSBS in the position they would have been in had the MSBS always existed and they had been members of it throughout.

The buy back arrangements in DFRDB have not been replicated in the MSBS. They operated on the basis that a member who had left the defence forces and then rejoined could buy back their previous service. This was important in the DFRDB, where no employer benefit was payable until after twenty years service. In MSBS, the employer benefit starts to vest after one year and is fully vested after seven years, and so a buy back arrangement was not felt necessary.

The way the DFRDB buy back operated was that a buy back price was struck on re-entry to the forces. This price was 5.5% of the member's salary at re-entry, multiplied by the years of previous service. This was established as a debt, which could be paid off by fortnightly instalments, subject to a minimum fortnightly payment. Since no interest was charged on the debt, it was always in the member's interest to make repayments at the minimum level, and this was commonly done. Any outstanding debt at the time of retirement became payable then.
The question is—how should these buy back members be treated on transfer to MSBS?
I think it is useful to draw a comparison with the DFRDB.

(i)In the DFRDB the buy back price can be regarded as a proxy for member contributions attributable to prior service. That is the member is restoring the contributions to those which a continuing member would have. However there is a small penalty because the member has to make contributions on the basis of a higher salary (salary at re-entry).
(ii)The member is entitled to an employer financed benefit when total service reaches twenty years. That is buy back service vests when the member reaches a total of twenty years of service.

(iii)On retirement any outstanding debt is deducted from the commutation in the first instance. If the commutation represents the member's contributions then this may be regarded as the member foregoing the contributions attributable to prior service which had not been restored at the time of retirement.

This suggests that the method which would have been most consistent with the DFRDB approach would be as follows. Allow all contributions which have been paid to be included in the member transfer value. Allow buy back service to vest at the time it would have vested in DFRDB, ie after twenty years total service. Treat the outstanding

debt as member contributions attributable to prior service which have not been restored. As such they should not be deducted from the MSBS transfer value, because the MSBS transfer value already excludes these contributions. This option would have been the most consistent with the treatment in DFRDB but administratively complex, and not in harmony with the general philosophy behind MSBS.

Another possibility would have been to provide proportionate vesting. Under this option all contributions which have been paid would be included in the member transfer value. Only a proportion of buy back service would vest in the member, the proportion being calculated as the ratio of debt repaid to initial debt. Since the buy back service would have been reduced to allow for the fact that the debt had not been fully repaid, no outstanding debt would remain. Again this method is not considered further.
I now consider the `official' and `alternative' views.

The `official' view is that the member transfer value should be calculated as total contributions at the date of transfer less the outstanding debt at 1 October 1991. If the outstanding debt at 1 October 1991 exceeds the total contributions at the date of transfer (ie the transfer value is negative) then the member has to make additional buy back contributions at least equal to the excess before being allowed to transfer. The member transfer value would then be recalculated including the additional buy back contributions as total contributions. Buy back service vests immediately, in the sense that, on transfer, the member is given credit for all buy back service for the purposes of calculating the MSBS employer financed benefit.

If the buy back price, or initial debt, is regarded as member contributions attributable to buy back service, then the outstanding debt at 1 October 1991 can be regarded as member contributions which had not been restored by 1 October 1991. If this is the case then it is not reasonable to deduct the outstanding debt at 1 October 1991 from the total contributions paid to the date of transfer. However, as mentioned above, buy back service vests immediately on transfer to the MSBS. If the outstanding debt is considered to apply to the employer financed benefit then the deduction for outstanding debt makes more sense.

A consequence of the `official' view is that members who have only recently started their buy back will need to pay in a lump sum if they are to be permitted to transfer to the MSBS. For a member with a large amount of previous service, and therefore a large buy back price, this could be difficult. Moreover these are the members who would not have to wait very long before becoming eligible for an employer financed benefit in the DFRDB.

The `alternative' view is that the member transfer value should be calculated as total contributions at the date of transfer. Any outstanding debt at the time of transfer is forgiven. However, if the initial debt exceeds the total contributions at the date of transfer then the member has to make additional buy back contributions at least equal to the excess before being allowed to transfer. Buy back service vests immediately, provided total contributions exceed the buy back price.

The logic of this position is that the buy back price, or initial debt, is a proxy for member contributions attached to buy back service. The member should therefore be allowed to include all of the buy back contributions in the member transfer value. The outstanding debt is forgiven because it represents member contributions attached to buy back service which are yet to be restored. Essentially the member should have been allowed to transfer the entire buy back price to MSBS but because the member had not repaid all the buy back price the amount which remains unpaid cannot be transferred.

The additional condition that total contributions at the date of transfer must not be less than the initial debt determines when the employer benefit vests. It appears to have arisen because under the `official' view, a member may not transfer if total contributions at the date of transfer are less than the outstanding debt at 1 October 1991. This condition makes sense for the `official' view, because the outstanding debt is treated as a debt to the Commonwealth for provision of the employer benefit. However it seems less reasonable for the `alternative' view where the initial debt is regarded as a debt to the member.

In my opinion the `alternative view' is one of a number of reasonable views which may be held on the question of how the buy back arrangements should be treated on transfer to MSBS. In my opinion it is the most generous view which could reasonably be taken (except for the condition on eligibility to transfer, which does not seem intrinsic to the approach). In order to support the `alternative' view, the following conclusions would have to be reached:
(i)For each year of service, the appropriate accrual in MSBS is both an employee financed benefit and an employer financed benefit.
(ii)The member's right to the MSBS employer component in respect of prior service arises from the member's decision to buy back service, not from any further service or from contributions.
(iii)The member's entitlement to prior service vests when total contributions are at least equal to the initial buy back price.
(iv)The member's right to the MSBS employee component in respect of prior service arises from the payment of contributions towards the buy back.
(v)The full amount of the buy back price should be regarded as employee contributions.
In order to support the `official' view, the conclusions would have to be different in the following respect:
(i)The member's right to the MSBS employer component in respect of prior service arises from both the member's decision to buy back service and from the actual payment of buy back contributions.
(ii)Buy back contributions made prior to l October 1991 give the right to both the employee financed benefit and the employer financed benefit in respect of prior service.
(iii)Buy back contributions made after 1 October 1991 give the right to employer financed benefits only.
A consequence of both approaches is that the ability of members to transfer may depend on their ability to make a lump sum payment prior to transfer.

It would be possible to take the view that buy back contributions (whether made before or after 1 October 1991) should give rights to employer financed benefits only. This would be substantially more severe than the `official' view.

As I indicated at the outset, the structure of MSBS is so different from that of the DFRDB that it is not possible to devise a simple approach which will satisfy everyone: there will always be differences of view. Indeed, this is one reason for retaining the old DFRDB scheme while giving members the option to transfer to the new MSBS.
I would be happy to discuss this issue further if required.
Yours sincerely
D.B. Duval
Australian Government Actuary
19 August 1992
