Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles

I refer to the Committee's request for advice on a representation from Senator Newman on Instrument No.2 of 1992 made under subsection 5(1) of the Military Superannuation and Benefits (MSB) Act 1991 which took effect on 25 May 1992.

The instrument relates to transfer provisions for some 2400 members who at 1 October 1991 were paying additional contributions to buy back a previous period of service in the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) Scheme for pension purposes. The purpose of the Instrument is to ensure fair treatment for all members who elect to transfer to the MSBS.

I will first summarise the treatment of past service debt for re-entered DFRDB members. Under the DFRDB Act, members who resigned with a refund of contributions and later rejoined the Defence Force could elect to purchase their previous period of service so that it would count towards their DFRDB retirement benefit. The purchase price was based on the rank and salary of the member at re-entry and was thus greater than the original refund of contributions. The purchase price could be paid immediately or in fortnightly instalments of additional contributions. In practice, members always chose to pay in instalments. In DFRDB, if the purchase price debt has not been paid in full at retirement, the member's commuted pension benefit is reduced by the amount of the purchase price outstanding. The additional contributions paid to purchase past service are only directly refunded to the member when he or she resigns from the ADF before qualifying for a retirement benefit.

The significance of the arrangements for purchasing past service for re-entered DFRDB members is that they establish the principle that the member must pay off the purchase of service debt when an employer-financed benefit becomes due. This principle is inherent in the MSBS transfer provisions for re-entered members which were recommended by the DFRDB Review Committee. The Instrument re-establishes this principle except for any debt already paid before 1 October 1991.

The DFRDB Review Committee was of the view that the carryover of debts into the new Scheme was undesirable. At the same time, it recognised that the repayment of a debt before transfer to MSBS could be beyond the reach of many members and could prevent them from transferring. Accordingly, the Committee recommended that any outstanding debt should be offset against a member's transfer value (the starting credit of member-financed benefit in the MSBS comprising DFRDB contributions, including additional contributions already made to purchase previous service, and notional interest). Although the starting amount of member-financed benefit is reduced, full credit is given for previous service being purchased in the employer-financed benefit entitlement at transfer.

The Review Committee did not envisage that any members who had been paying a past service debt by fortnightly instalment would do anything but use the offset and the provision was incorporated into the MSBS Rules. As a result, all literature and advice on the treatment of the debt for re-entered members only illustrated the offset method. Note that the offset method aligns with the treatment of debt for purchasing past service under DFRDB in that any debt outstanding at retirement is repaid by virtue of an offset.

Before the Instrument amending the Rules, there was an unintended gain in MSBS transfer values for those DFRDB members who chose to repay the amount of their purchase price outstanding as a lump sum, when compared with those who utilised the offset arrangement. For example, where a member paid an outstanding DFRDB purchase of service debt of $2,000 at 1 October 1991 in a lump sum before transfer, the resulting transfer value was $4,000 more than the transfer value for the member who offset the $2,000 debt outstanding against contributions.

The effect of the Rule change is that any DFRDB member who has elected to joint the MSBS after 25 May and who, after 1 October 1991, paid additional contributions to purchase previous DFRDB service will not have that money included as contributions in his or her transfer value. However, the debt component of the transfer value will be reduced by the amount of contributions paid. The member who repays an outstanding DFRDB purchase of service debt of $2,000 before transfer will have a transfer value which is $2,000 greater than the transfer value for the member who uses the offset arrangement.

The Instrument is not retrospective in any prejudicial way. It does not remove any entitlement from members who took advantage of the unintended consequences before the Instrument came into operation. Moreover, all members affected by the amendment were forwarded written advice of the change on 26 May 1992 (copy attached) and those DFRDB members in the process of repaying DFRDB purchase of service debts at the time of the Rule change received individual counselling and were given the option to have the repayment refunded.

The Instrument does not operate harshly or unfairly. What it does is to ensure that as far as possible members are provided with the benefits which were set out in the literature including the Personal Information Statements provided to all members about their entitlements. There could be no legitimate expectation that members would receive windfall benefits beyond the intended scope of the Scheme.

The need for the Rule change has been the subject of careful deliberation by the MSBS Trust Board, and subsequently by a high level Departmental Committee who sought the advice of the Australian Government Actuary (AGA). The AGA (copy of letter attached) has advised that the change is fair in the light of the DFRDB Review Committee's recommendation that any DFRDB debt would be repaid prior to transfer to MSBS by offsetting the debt against the MSBS member-financed benefit equity. It would be contrary to a specific recommendation of the DFRDB Review Committee to adopt the position which Senator Newman has recommended.
I hope that this letter allays the Committee's concerns. However, if further advice is required on this matter, Departmental staff will be available for discussions.
Yours sincerely
GORDON BILNEY

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the financial aspects of this, it should be acknowledged and put on the record that these measures will have both a perverse and adverse affect. By disallowing this new rule, there may be an increased impost on Commonwealth revenues in the long term. When that falls will depend on when people leave the scheme. If many of the 2,300 elect to sign up in the next 20 days, it may also have the perverse effect of an unexpected sudden infusion into public revenues by the Budget payments. But we are talking here of a maximum amount of $10m to $12m both ways. It should at least be put on the record that there is a financial consequence of this disallowance matter.

PARA.TAB: As I say, it gets back to the question of what is equity and what is not equity in this matter. I will not accept that the new rules change was either maliciously intended or meant to hurt members. It was meant to bring equity into the subset between offset and lump sum payment. On the other hand, I acknowledge that when the picture is broadened out—when the camera is brought back, if you like—and broken service is compared with continuous service, another viewpoint can be put that is equally valid.
I say to Senator Newman, in terms of the process she has spoken about, that I do not believe the extent of the conspiracy theory. I know she does not believe it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't allege that.

—I think Senator Newman alleged that public servants attempted to deliberately frustrate, et cetera. She made some fairly abrasive comments about those public servants which I know she will not make outside this door and, therefore, I devalue them to some extent. In my dealings with public servants of late they have been very flexible, very open with me about all the alternatives and very helpful. I pay tribute to them for the work they have done in the last three or four days in trying to get through some of these very difficult issues.

PARA.TAB: I also make one other comment, and this is not the first time I have made it. I do not think it is right, under the Library rules, for people to come in and quote Library papers here. As I understand it, they are written specifically by the Library not to be quoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I checked with the Library; I rang them specifically.

—They must have changed the rules, so I am well behind the play. Even so, it has dangers—not particularly in this case—when Library research is used to support a case. It has dangers for the Library, too, but that is not a major point. If the Library's policy has changed and Senator Newman is able to quote from the papers, then I withdraw that comment.

PARA.TAB: I will sum this up for the senators who are interested. It is a fairly complex issue, where there are no absolute rights and wrongs because the two schemes are so dramatically different. Getting the transition provisions right has occurred in the majority of cases. In the cases of those with broken service, trying to remedy one inequity may well lead to another inequity. and we have to be very careful about that.

I am confident that in having this disallowance go through today, and the subsequent rules change which picks up a much smaller group, we can make sure of that group's rights. Another couple of smaller groups could emerge somewhere that I do not know about yet who are suddenly disadvantaged. I do not know. I cannot give anyone that guarantee because the matter is so complex. I very much doubt it, but there might be people who elected to stay in the old scheme who argue to us now, `We wouldn't have elected to stay in the old scheme if we had known this was going to be disallowed'. I doubt that, because most of them would have made their decision to stay in the old scheme on a different set of principles.

We have to be careful that through this action today no-one else is suddenly disadvantaged. We have identified the largest disadvantaged group. We are proposing a rules change. We are proposing a subset of the rules change to give them another 90 days to make their arrangements. We are also in a position to write to and telephone those 170 people. We can get their names from our database and let them know that, once the trustees and the rules change come in, they will have a different set of options.

I do not think I should add much more to the complexity of this debate today. I do have a variety of tables showing all the financial aspects of different examples, but I do not think we need to complicate matters too much with those today. Suffice to say, it tends to support the overall result we will achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply—As I said in my speech earlier, I do welcome the approach of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to this whole issue. It is consistent with his management of the Defence portfolio that, in my view, he has always been sympathetic to the fair treatment of Defence personnel.

PARA.TAB: I have not advocated a conspiracy theory. I have set down the facts as I believe them to be true. They are a series of facts which I have never encountered before. Since Senator Ray became the Minister my ready access to his Department has been most appreciated. Never before have I found it so difficult, with so many of the shutters coming down. I understood that was because of the Minister's direction. If he does not want to take the credit for the treatment I have received over the last two and a half years, that is fine, but I understood it was because of him.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't help in my pre-selection.

—I am sorry if the Minister wants me to take his reference back. Nevertheless, the change of behaviour over this issue was too dramatic to be accidental. In addition, after I spoke to the Minister, wrote to him, explained what the problem was and that I believed his colleague Minister Bilney had only been given one source of advice, why, when I said that we needed an independent assessment, was the Government Actuary only briefed by the official view? That is why the Government Actuary on 2 July or 3 July—whatever it is—brought down a view which, in fact, supported the official view.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister said, it is a complex matter, and I could not agree more. Why was it then that we finally had a second point of view explained to the Government Actuary, as a result of which he came down with a different perspective? The Minister admits that. Perhaps if he had not had only one view at the beginning but had had both points of view put to him, he might have come down with a more clear-cut recommendation in his second report, but that is only speculation. The man was then in a position where he had already put his reputation on the line with his first report, so he was in a bit of a quandary about how he dealt with a second, quite different advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It says on page 2, `I have also examined the alternative point of view'.
—That is right, in his second report.
—No, the first—page 2 of his first report, 2 July.
—I am sorry, I understood that he had not.
—In the last paragraph on the second page he says, `I have also examined the alternative point of view'.

—I fail to understand then why the second one was done. Why was the second report asked for? As I understand it, it was after the Chiefs of the Defence Force asked that there be independent or separate advice given to the actuary that we got a second report done. Is my information incorrect?
—If you read the rest of that paragraph you will see that he also goes on to say, `other matters'. Therefore, he was asked for a second view because he had not explained those.
—He had not had them all explained.
—The only point I make is that he was given the alternative view.
—Obviously something occurred between then and 19 August to make him feel that there was an alternative point of view that deserved respect.
—I acknowledge he gave it much better consideration in his second letter.

—I thank the Minister. The Minister mentioned the Library. I do assure him that we rang the Library because I had a concern, as he did. I was told that it was perfectly legitimate for me to quote where it had come from. It is important in this case because the person concerned is a specialist in the area, whose professional opinion was valued and respected by the people who read the opinion. So where that advice came from is a very relevant issue.

PARA.TAB: I recognise that there will always be problems when one is trying to transfer from one superannuation scheme to another. The transfer arrangements are complex and will always be in danger of producing anomalies, as the Minister said. But I get back to the point I made earlier in my speech: the Cole report did say that there had to be equity between the members with buy-back and the members with continuous service. Clearly, that was not achieved by the changes that we have seen before us.

It can be a very complex issue but it can also be a very simple issue. Does the Commonwealth have the right to change the rules whereby people's own personal contributions get swallowed up in Consolidated Revenue; where, if they had stayed in the DFRDB scheme, the contributions that they had made to Consolidated Revenue would have stayed notionally credited to them and they would have eventually had the benefit of it, but by opting to transfer to the new scheme, they lost their own cash, some of which had been borrowed. That is really what it does boil down to—just a question of doing the fair thing, and it would have been a windfall gain to the Commonwealth. Whether one says it is clear-cut, or whether one has to say `on balance', what we are doing today is clearly the right thing by those defence personnel, and I do thank the Minister for his approach to this matter.
Question resoled in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (EXCISE) BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (GENERAL) BILL 1992SALES TAX AMENDMENT (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1992SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will recap a couple of points I made in my previous remarks on the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and associated Bills. Firstly, I declared that, as a primary producer, I had a personal interest in these Bills. Secondly, I emphasised that the problem with wholesale sales tax was that it was a hidden tax, as are fuel excise and other taxes and, as such, it cascades through the system and enormously increases prices to individual consumers well above what the tax is worth. Thirdly, in a taxation system it is important that there be equity and fairness.I want to deal with that question of equity and fairness, particularly as it relates to agriculturalists, as they are now known and not farmers. The definition has been broadened because it includes bee keepers, fence repairers, water borers and so on.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the May economic statement, we saw the introduction of what is known as ruling 3005. Transport is one of the areas where wholesale sales tax hits not only the farm sector and pastoralists but also miners, other industries and the consumer at the household level because the imposts applied to the carriage of goods add enormously to the final price. I will give just one example. A rig doing 250,000 kilometres per year—which I am told by transporters is the average economical distance they have to travel—loaded with freight, pays over $80,000 per year up-front taxes prior to earning a dollar of income. This cascades, as I have already said, through the system to the consumer.

Let us look at the situation which will now exist with regard to trucks which carry goods in the agricultural sector. We find that four-by-two vehicles will still carry sales tax, unless they are only used to drive between contiguous premises.If we look at the situation which exists with four-by-four vehicles with a body, we find that they are exempt for general purpose use by agriculturists, including bee keepers, shearers, crop dusters, fertiliser spreaders, contract harvesters, et cetera. If that particular four-wheel drive has a detachable cover, it remains exempt, but if it has a non-detachable cover, it loses its exemption.

I will contrast this anomaly with the situation which exists with stock crates. If a stock crate is built onto the semitrailer, it is exempt. But if it is removable and the truck is used for some other purpose—for example, to carry a load of wheat, fertiliser or anything else—because that stock crate can be taken off, it ceases to be exempt. That is a direct contradiction in terms of applying simplicity—and this is supposed to be about simplicity—to sales tax. It is unbelievable that the Government should come forward and increase the confusion.

Ruling 3005, which was introduced just before the May economic statement, cleared up a lot of these anomalies. Under ruling 3005, bogie drive trucks, which are four-wheel drive trucks with separate steering wheels, became exempt, the same as four-wheel drive trucks, because they are four-wheel drive trucks. The only difference between them is that they have separate steering wheels.

We find that that exemption will be removed when this legislation comes into force. Once again there is confusion with regard to the legislation. Yet if a truck which is exactly the same size, carrying the same load and carrying out the same functions, has the driving wheels on the front and on the back and it pulls a trailer, the whole unit is exempt.

If we look at other aspects of the situation with regard to trucks, we find that if a semi-trailer is put on one of these four-wheel drive prime movers, they cease to be exempt. But if a dolly is put under that semi-trailer, a tow bar is put onto the dolly and hooked to that four-wheel drive truck, they are exempt. Talk about confusion in terms of the application of a sales tax law!

When we talk about confusion, one of the things that needs to be taken into account, as I have already mentioned, is fairness—fairness between users. The Government needs to answer this question: why should one particular operator who tows a trailer, with exactly the same load, along the road, enjoy the benefits—if it can be put that way; I think it should be a right in terms of cost of production—of being exempt from sales tax, yet if he puts that trailer directly onto the four-wheel drive vehicle pulling it along the road, he is not exempt?

It should be taken into account that it is much safer to put the semi-trailer directly onto the prime mover. As I am sure many people on this side of the chamber would know—I doubt that many people on the other side would even understand, or attempt to understand—once a trailer is put behind a towing vehicle, one gets what is known to happen from time to time, particularly on steep or difficult roads, as jack-knifing. The trailer can overtake the towing vehicle and, of course, very serious accidents have occurred, and will continue to occur, with this configuration. If the Government were interested in safety it would get rid of this ridiculous anomaly and encourage people who have to carry their produce or inputs on roads to adopt the safest method.

As I work through these various configurations I have talked about equity and fairness, and I have now introduced the subject of safety. In fact, decisions will be made not for practical reasons but for financial reasons—and one can understand that, because producers have to survive—which are not in the best public interest. I question why the Government and the people involved in putting this legislation together will be reneging on ruling 3005 which cleared these things up, got rid of the confusion and made the position absolutely clear.

One can put together further configurations. One can have a single-wheel trailer; a tandem wheel trailer; a trailer with a single wheel on the front and tandem on the back; tandem wheels on the front and back; or, for that matter, one can have tri-axles on front and back. Provided that they are towed, they are exempt. I notice that the advising officers are writing lots of notes. It will be rather interesting to find out, through the Minister, whether they have actually looked at the ridiculous situation in which we now find ourselves in terms of the application of this legislation.

One can examine many aspects of the legislation, but I thought that the example I have given was an extremely good one to demonstrate how something that is supposedly simple is totally confusing and will lead to distortions in the decision making process. I re-emphasise the craziness of the situation whereby stock carriers and stock crates that are built onto a trailer will be tax exempt. But the stock crate can be built as a separate unit and can be removed, which is the main practice. In the agricultural sector, trucks are used for many purposes. At seeding time a super bin is put on the back; at harvest time a grain bin is put on the back; and in between times they are used for a variety of other means, including the cartage of stock.

In the time remaining to me, having emphasised the inconsistencies that have been introduced in terms of the moving of agricultural product, I now turn to one other point relating to disadvantaged people. If somebody has a hearing problem, there is a sales tax exemption on the hearing aid. Yet if a person has an eye sight problem and requires, for example, a particular computer in order to study, that computer is not sales tax exempt. Once again, it highlights the inconsistency of this Government and the way in which it treats people in the community in different ways.

Unfortunately, a reasonably close friend of mine is in this situation. I think it is very sad that because this particular child has an eye sight deficiency, the child is treated differently from children who have a deficiency in another area. It highlights very clearly the inability of this Government to come to grips with consistency and fairness for people in the community.

I conclude my remarks by saying that this legislation, far from simplifying many areas, makes it more confusing. I have already highlighted a couple of points. It does not lead to fairness, nor does it lead to equity. It expands significantly the number of areas under which sales tax will be claimed.

One of the most damning things about it is with regard to people who are registered as against people who are not registered. Of course, registered and non-registered users can claim sales tax exemption. But if a person is registered, the amount of sales tax has to be put on the invoice. If a person is a non-registered consumer, it does not. I pose the question: how does a non-registered consumer claim the sales tax exemption if the sales tax does not have to be placed on the docket or invoice? Of course, that is part of hiding the sales tax component which we all pay every time we purchase something off the shelf.

This legislation creates significant confusion. It significantly broadens the indirect tax base in a secret way and it does not provide fairness and equity, which was highlighted by a number of people and organisations who put in submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of wholesale sales tax Bills is nothing but a tax grab by Keating, nothing but a tax grab to increase the tax take from the ordinary Australian battler. The whole of the framework of the wholesale sales tax structure is based on illogical principles, it is inequitable, and in surveys and opinions that the Australian Taxation Office itself has commissioned the finding has been that as a system of taxation it is beyond redemption and should be scrapped.

PARA.TAB: The manner in which these Bills have been dealt with in first being introduced and then being referred to the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation for thorough investigation by this chamber—in the meantime the Government does a back flip on a couple of aspects of it but does not let the Committee have the details of those precise amendments, attempting to thwart the work of the Committee—shows the cynical attitude the Government has towards struggling taxpayers. Bear in mind that since Keating was first Treasurer and now Prime Minister, the tax take from the wholesale sales tax area has increased by about 300 per cent. Who asked the ordinary Australian voter or taxpayer whether they approved of that? Who asked the taxpayers whether they approved of the fact that, since Mr Keating was first Treasurer and now Prime Minister, the amount of tax that we collect from Australians has more than doubled?

The fundamental problem with our taxation system is that it has worked assiduously against savings—and our savings are at an all-time low—it has worked against incentive and it has worked against productivity. The monthly balance of payments figures show that we continue to go further and further into debt. They are caused by the interest payments we have to make on borrowings we have already made. The taxation structure which this Government has overseen has meant that we have not accumulated sufficient Australian savings to invest in our own country. Basically, we have gone overseas and we have borrowed other people's savings, and we have to meet the repayments on those borrowings. That debt now stands at $150 billion. To meet the monthly repayments on that, we have to borrow more and effectively go into more and more debt—somewhere between $12 billion and $20 billion additionally per annum.

If this happened in our regular household situation, we know precisely what would happen. If we had a mortgage on our house, a Bankcard and a few other debts and we simply were not earning enough money to meet those monthly repayments, in would come the bailiffs, sell us up, and down would go our standard of living. It is not much different with countries. What has happened? We have an international debt and we are not producing or earning enough to meet those monthly repayments. Only it is not the bailiffs that come in; it is the International Monetary Fund. It comes in and says to the Government of the day, `We will reschedule your debts but you in turn have to put the following policies in place', and then our standard of living goes down. Quite frankly, we have to introduce a system of reform that will enable Australians to produce more, to meet the monthly repayments, to stabilise that debt and maintain our standard of living. Quite frankly, the Fightback package does just that.

The Fightback package is based on logic and equity, commonsense and fairness. Let us take a look at the heritage of this wholesale sales tax and how it began life. It began life in 1930 as a temporary tax. Back in 1930, most of the population was employed by making things. That is no longer the case. Most people who are in employment in Australia today are employed in either the production or delivery of services, yet we have a tax which currently raises between $9 billion and $10 billion, distorting the economy by placing that tax on things and not on services.

I think it is important that we look at the numbers, at the structure of the tax take. We now raise $90 billion per annum by way of taxation revenue. Of that $90 billion, around $50 billion is collected by way of personal income tax; $41 billion of it is collected by way of PAYE tax. Since I have been on the inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office, I have come to understand what PAYE really stands for: pay all you earn. Of the $50 billion, $41 billion is PAYE tax. We also have some Medibank tax, which is just part of the income tax system—it does not go into any special account—and then of course we have provisional tax. In other words, we are dependent on taxing income. We are dependent on a direct tax base. The Fightback package removes that onus by making us more dependent on an indirect tax base. It removes the unfair taxes that currently keep our savings at a dismal low, keep productivity at a dismal low and give no incentive to anyone to work harder.

Additional tax has been ripped off the taxpayer by that well-worn practice of allowing increases in wages and salaries, thereby pushing wage earners and salary earners into higher tax brackets—ripping off something like an additional $22 billion in tax; and nobody ever asked the taxpayer.

The Opposition is being totally fair and open. It has published its tax reform—the GST has become a shorthand term for saying tax reform—which is central to the theme of the Fightback package. That reform will in fact deliver an increase in savings, incentive to work harder and greater productivity.

One might ask why. Let us look at what happens now. Taxpayers have two choices about what to do with their hard earned after-tax dollar: they can either save it or they can spend it. Australians have chosen to be great spenders and poor savers. The reason is quite simple. On the one hand, if one saved that after-tax dollar, up until the recession we had to have, it would have been eaten away by inflation and tax would have been paid on it at the top marginal rate. On the other hand, if one spent it, one got instant gratification and got precisely what one wanted when one wanted.

Until now people have not understood that the price of the things they buy already has a tax component in it. I call it the Government's GST, the Government's secret tax. The Government is quite good at secret taxes. Mr Dawkins has put a few in the current Budget.

The reasoning behind the reform is that if people spend there will be a tax on their consumption but they will pay less tax because we will abolish seven taxes. We are going to abolish the wholesale sales tax, which currently raises $9 billion to $10 billion; we are going to abolish the tax on petroleum products, which raises between $6 billion and $7 billion; we are going to abolish payroll tax, which raises about $6 billion in States; we are going to abolish tariff tax, which raises between $3 billion and $4 billion; and we are going to abolish the compulsory training levy, lump sum super tax and the coal export levy. We are going to abolish $20 billion worth of taxes—taxes that are presently on business and are reflected in the price of everything we buy.

But more than that, out of that $50 billion of direct personal income tax we will give back $13 billion, around a third. Individual tax will come down by about a third. When we do our sums and abolish $20 billion of tax and replace one of those taxes, the wholesale sales tax, with a broad-based consumption tax, that is, removing the distortion of taxing goods only and spreading it across the full gamut of what happens in our economy—logical and equitable—there will be a one-off inflationary impact of 4.4 per cent. If we apply the implicit price deflator, we can probably get it down to 2.2 per cent. Or we can use Treasury's figure of 3.7 per cent. But we have chosen to abide by the conservative figure of 4.4 per cent. For that reason, we have chosen to increase pensions by 8 per cent and special benefits by 6 per cent.

So, as I said, the Fightback package is based on logic and equity, fairness and commonsense. It removes biases within the economy which have kept savings, incentive and productivity down. We will give Australians an opportunity to prosper and to keep more of their hard earned dollars. Somebody who is earning, say, $30,000 a year, who under the Fightback package will pay $30 a week less tax, will be able to more than double his or her income and pay no more than 30c in the dollar tax as a top rate of tax. We look forward to 95 per cent of the Australian work force paying no more than a top rate of 30c in the dollar tax.

When I say that we are serious about encouraging savings, not only will people pay less tax on the money they save, but for a family earning $50,000 a year or less which creates new savings, the first $2,000 that it earns will be tax free. Further, we will increase the tax threshold from $5,400 to $7,000, ensuring that 320,000 additional Australians will pay no tax at all. Fairness and equity.

Let us take a look at some of the anomalies. I will give the Senate some examples of the wholesale sales tax regime—and it is a regime; it was overseen by 763 public servants. I asked at Estimates committee hearings last time we met, `Tell me, do we still have 763 public servants overseeing 70,000 wholesale sales tax returns?' They said, `Oh no, Senator. We are downsizing'. I said, `How nice. How many have we got?' The answer was `740'. I said, `Did the 23 people actually go away or did they just get transferred to somewhere else?' `Oh no, Senator. They just got transferred somewhere else'. Perhaps they will just have to get transferred back again together with another legion of public servants to try to deal with the absolute mess this new legislation will introduce—the legion of questions and the areas of conflict that it will open up.

But back to the illogicality and inequity of the way it works. If a housewife goes into the supermarket—or even some of the fellows over there who might go in from time to time—and fills up her basket with soap, toothpaste, toilet tissue, disinfectant, orange juice, chocolate biscuits and a few other fundamentals, she is paying anywhere from 10 to 30 per cent on those items.

TALK.START.PARA: —And food.
—And food; food has a component part.
—Pet food.

—Yes. Every other item you buy in the supermarket also has a tax component. It is very interesting that the products that women buy are taxed the hardest and highest. Nonetheless, when you buy those things in the supermarket you might go across to the soft drink counter and get some Coca Cola, which has a 20 per cent tax, or some mineral water, which also has a 20 per cent tax. But mineral water is not quite so straightforward. If you buy mineral water with bubbles, there is a 20 per cent tax, but if you buy natural spring water with no bubbles, there is no tax. Natural spring water with bubbles attracts 20 per cent tax. Natural spring water whose label states that it has minerals in it but no bubbles attracts no tax. But if the word `mineral' is put on the label along with `natural spring water' and it still has no bubbles, there is a 20 per cent tax. That is neither logical nor equitable.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line—I am sure that Senator Button would be interested in this—is that a good Australian mineral water, locally produced, pays 20 per cent tax but good old Evian water imported from France pays no tax. If you are like Mr Keating and you are into imported Zegna suits and you like champagne, caviar and salmon, there is no tax. But if you are just an ordinary Australian who is getting by and you like a beer, a Vegemite sandwich and a few crisps, you are going to find your life more difficult.

Under the Fightback package Mr Keating will pay tax on his Zegna suits, his caviar, his champagne and his salmon, but the guy who just wants to go down to Grace Bros and buy his suit off the rack, and have a beer with his pie at the footy, will pay much less tax. So what is built into the system is some choice. If you are a big spender who likes antique French clocks, wants to buy into pig farms and wear imported Italian suits, you are going to pay a lot of tax. But if you suddenly decide that you do not want to pay that amount of tax and you are going to save it, we are quite pleased about that, too, because we need the savings.

I note that some of the unresolved questions in this sales tax legislation relate to how we deal with rulings and the inconsistencies that can flow. Let me give the Senate an example of the way it works now. I am sure we are all aware of a good product known as Aeroguard and another good product known as Rid—products used to keep away the mozzies and the blowflies. If you are up in the north of Australia they can actually stop you from contracting diseases such as Ross River fever. Until the end of last year those products were exempt from wholesale tax. But last year the Brisbane office of the Tax Office decided that they did not meet the criteria under the exemption legislation of being either a drug or a medicine and that, therefore, it would apply the wholesale sales tax to them. However, the Parramatta branch of the Tax Office disagreed. It said that the products did meet the criteria. So we had conflicting rulings.

So what do we do? We have an arbitration. We are paying for all this. We hear evidence and we hear statements. At the end of the day there is a decision that says that the products do not meet the criteria, that they are not a drug or a medicine—no reasons given—some case law is stated and the bottom line is that as from 1 March 1992 a 20 per cent tax is applied to Aeroguard and Rid. But of course the price to the consumer does not go up by 20 per cent; the price to the consumer goes up more like 28 per cent because the profit margin has to be put on the tax. In other words, it cascades; it is building all the time into a greater amount of tax. It is neither equitable nor logical. It is a mishmash.

As I said, the reports provided to the Australian Tax Office showed that the only way to proceed with this illogical and inequitable tax is to abolish it and to replace it with a broad-based consumption tax. That is part of what the Fightback package does. We will abolish seven taxes. We will abolish $20 billion worth of taxes, including $1.7 billion worth of taxes currently on exports.

In the Budget, Mr Dawkins could find a mere $75m which was going to expand the EMDG scheme, which is designed to keep people who were being excluded as being long term users of the scheme under the last piece of legislation this Government introduced excluded by a further three years. But with the introduction of the Fightback package, $1.7 billion worth of taxes now on exports goes. We will give Australia a chance to stabilise that international debt, to meet those monthly repayments and, ultimately, to use the proceeds of our privatisation program to begin the reduction process.

The program to abolish $20 billion worth of taxes, give back to taxpayers one-third of their own money—one-third of income tax—and raise pensions by 8 per cent and special benefits by 6 per cent is a restructuring of the economy that will allow that fierce Australian spirit that is still within us again to become productive and hard-working. We have slipped in Australia, because of the sorts of policies this Government has pursued, into accepting the adage that near enough is good enough—`She'll be right, Jack'. It is not good enough any more. We have to move to the situation where we say that only the best will do.

The tax reform package we are proposing is just that. It is not a bandaid job. It is not like the Budget that was brought in the other day, which I called a patchwork and panic Budget: patch over the areas that are in need of hiding because the Government is panicked into trying to find an election date. We should look at things from a logical and equitable perspective, using fairness and common sense. We should move away from dependence on the direct tax base, which has penalised ordinary Australians and denied them the right to keep some of their hard-earned money. We should put back into the system incentive: if people do well and work hard, they can earn more, again creating productivity, and fundamentally having something left over at the end of the day to save so that we can truly be more and more dependent on ourselves.

Our reform will mean that there will be a simplicity in administration of this tax reform. Because it is a single rate of tax, not a multiple rate like the wholesale sales tax, and across the board, it will be quite cheap to administer. Every three months a firm that has a turnover of $50,000 per annum is obliged to register. Every three months it will put in an A4 form. It is very simple. Up the top of the form is the name of the company and its registration number. Further down is the amount of GST it has collected to be remitted to the Tax Office. Down further is the amount of input taxes. That is the amount of GST the firm has paid on items it needs to do business. That amount is 100 per cent refundable. If the figure at the bottom of the page is higher than the figure at the top of the page, the Tax Office sends the firm a cheque. If the figure at the top is greater than the figure at the bottom, it sends the Tax Office a cheque.

The records that will be kept are the same records that are kept now in order to know, first, whether the firm is making a profit and, secondly, to supply its income tax return. The firm keeps the records in the same way that it keeps those records now—on the basis of several years in case it is subject to an audit.

The tax itself is simple and logical. It means that people who operate in the black economy are likely to come out of the black economy, as was the experience in New Zealand. When New Zealand had a similar provision about registration, it had more firms register than it knew it had firms. The reason was very simple: if the firm did not register, it was not eligible for the inputs tax 100 per cent refund.

As I said, the whole package is driven by logic and equity, fairness and common sense. For that reason, we zero rate health, education, exports, charities and religious bodies. We do it in education because we believe that education is so important that it needs to have additional money spent on it, and we are pledged to spend an additional $3 billion between now and the year 2000. We will certainly not put it on health because there is already a tax in place and we do not put a tax on a tax. Exports are vital for us to earn our way out of the huge debt this Government has plunged us into, and of course, compassion in the area of charities and religion is essential.

An exemption means that the consumer does not pay the GST but that the inputs taxes are not refundable. The two universal areas where this has been applied internationally are domestic rents and financial transactions. Financial transactions include such things as mortgage repayments, cheques, insurance payments and so on. They are all exempt to the consumer. At every turn, we are working to make it simple to apply. We already have 740 public servants who will no longer be needed to collect the wholesale sales tax, so there will be plenty of spare people around to do any administration that is required. Around Australia there will be at least another 1,000 who will no longer be needed to collect those other six taxes.

When I look at this pile of six Bills—and there is a seventh Bill that was the back-off, which only further confuses it—and at how our tax legislation gets bigger and bigger and more complicated, at how our tax laws are not administered in a fair way because of the complexity, and one has only to look at my correspondence to see the evidence of that, we truly have to simplify our tax system in accordance with the Fightback package and not complicate it in the way that this sales tax legislation does, pretending to simplify it when all it does is extend it and bring in extra tax.

Mr Keating, first as Treasurer and then as Prime Minister, has been ever ready and ever willing to collect more tax. Back in 1985 he had a good thought. He was going to introduce a broad based consumption tax. He was going to be on his cart until the wheels came off. He went out fiercely and said what he believed in. But at the end of the day the unofficial member of the Cabinet, Mr Kelty, told him he could not have it. Ever thus, the Labor Party is but the political wing of the trade union movement, which we are frequently reminded of as we listen to Senator Cook, a member of the BWIU and a former trade union official. When we remember those things, we see that the interests of reforming a tax system went out the window because the trade union movement, an unelected body, said that we could not have it.

The Fightback package has been published early so that people can become familiar with it. Many people spend hours in long discussions explaining how it will work, looking at the other parts of the package in the health area and so on, all of which benefit retirees. Unlike Mr Keating, who back in 1985 said `There aren't too many of those and they don't matter anyway, we cannot do anything for them', we have said that that is harsh and inequitable. We have policies for self-funded retirees so that they are compensated; they will all have a pharmaceutical benefits card, which is of enormous benefit.

It is a good package; it is a fair package; it is an equitable package and a logical package. When I say that we are going to vote against this mishmash of inequitable, illogical wholesale sales tax Bills, I do it in the full knowledge that when we win the next election and that tax is abolished, along with six others, when we abolish $20 billion worth of tax on Australian business, give back $13 billion of all income tax to hard-working taxpayers and raise pensions by 8 per cent and special benefits by 6 per cent, people will be better off. I say to the Australian people: `Do not be confused. Do not let the Labor Party confuse you, because you will be better off'.

It is a fair and equitable package designed to let Australia and the Australian people prosper, get out of the debt that is the legacy the Labor Party left us, and again become resilient and strong, proud of our heritage and our history, looking forward to the twenty-first century instead of cowering in a maze of debt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and related Bills. Most of my remarks will be directed to the Sales Tax Assessment Bill which, as Senator Bishop has just ably explained to the Senate, seeks to revamp a highly discredited and absurd tax. Once again, legislation has been put forward to try to rectify the glaring injustices that this Labor Government sought to impose on the business community in the first draft of the sales tax Bills.

PARA.TAB: Is it not amazing: we have had wholesale sales taxes in this country since the 1930s, yet this Government still is not prepared to make the tough decisions to fix it. At the end of the last Autumn session the Government brought together a set of sales tax Bills. However, over the recess it yet again had to come up with many amendments. The Government has no understanding of what it is doing with sales tax.

These Bills simply make the sales tax system far more complex than it has ever been. It is making the system far more prohibitive for a whole lot of companies. Of course, it is making a whole lot of things more expensive. At the same time as the Government does that, it continues to lie about the Opposition's Fightback package. Last Saturday when I was travelling up to Karratha, I picked up the West Australian and found that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I am sorry, Senator. We are frequently told by your people in this place that we cannot accuse senators and members of being liars.
—I did not accuse any individual of being a liar.

—No, it was a collective slander. You take this point all the time. I thought for once I would take it against you. Say what I say when I talk about you people. You might get pimples on your tongue. That is what Hewson has got—a pimple on his tongue.

—I withdraw because what Senator Button is really trying to do is use up time. If I cannot say the Labor Party lies about that—which I have withdrawn—what I might do is give an example of a problem that this country has.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, I was reading the West Australian when I was travelling up to Karratha. Senator McMullan is meant to be the hotshot on demolishing the Fightback package. I might say that a few weeks ago, at the request of the soon to be deposed sitting member, this hotshot visited the electorate of Stirling in Western Australia to bag Fightback. Senator McMullan was absolutely demolished by the business community. They said that absolutely everything he said was wrong.

But the same Senator McMullan—the hotshot who is meant to be demolishing Fightback—is reported in the West Australian as saying that ordinary cars were going to become more expensive. If that is not exaggerating beyond the realm of reality, what is it? Senator McMullan knows, as does everybody else, that the price of cars is going to come down under Fightback. Jeannette McHugh, the new fandangled Minister who leapt up from nowhere, said in the same paper that the cost of products used by women was going to increase. If that is not telling little whoppers, what is? Ms McHugh failed to say that the cost of products used by women—whether they be cosmetics, sanitary items or whatever—are taxed at 30 per cent. The tax of 30 per cent will go and be replaced by a 15 per cent goods and services tax. So if that is not another one, what is? I am not allowed to use that word, but I will let people interpret what I have just said in whatever way they wish.

Every Government member and senator is saying that the goods and services tax is going to add 15 per cent on top of everything. They know that that is wrong. They know that the wholesale sales tax is going to be removed. They also know that six other taxes are going to be removed. They also know that personal income taxes are going to be reduced by 30 per cent. Yet every single solitary Government member and senator continues to say in the other chamber and this place, and all around Australia, that the goods and services tax is going to add 15 per cent to everything. That is clearly incorrect. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is sitting at the table, is another one who continues to come in here and say that we are going to put 15 per cent on top of everything.

TALK.START.PARA: —On food.

—I am glad that the Minister is now being specific. Senator Button just said that we are going to put 15 per cent on top of food. What taxes does the Government place on the food industry at the moment? There are taxes right throughout the production chain of a box of Weeties before it is put on the supermarket shelf. There are taxes on the farmer. Under Fightback, all of those taxes will be removed. All taxes on business inputs are going to be removed, and Senator Button well knows that. If he does not he should; if he does not he should not be in the position he now holds.
—One of his colleagues did not recently.

—Of course, the Australian Democrats do not understand it either. The manufacturer has input costs on all of his machinery. A tax is applied to the truck that takes wheat from the farmer to the manufacturer. The fuel used by the truck attracts a tax of 26c a litre. The tyres and the battery are also taxed. Every single solitary thing is taxed. Under Fightback, all of those taxes will be removed. So Senator Button should not tell me that food is not currently taxed.

PARA.TAB: All of the gear used by wholesalers is taxed. Every single solitary item of gear used by the farmer, the manufacturer, the wholesaler and the retailer is taxed. The legislation that is now before us will simply increase the tax right across the board.

Why is it that the Leader of the Government in the Senate feels so precious today that he had to take a point of order when quite clearly I can demonstrate that day in day out Government senators and members are not telling the truth out there in the electorate? If he were to dare to ask me, I could go on further and give more examples of where the truth is not being told. There is already a tax on food; there is already a tax on clothing. The whole production chain of both is being taxed to the hilt and the legislation that is now before us will add to this tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pity no economist agrees with you, including your own.

—Is it not amazing that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was the very person who wanted a goods and services tax about five or six years ago because of the added costs that are put on to business—costs which the consumer has to pay for in the end. Because of political expediency, the Prime Minister has now backed off, not because he does not want to do it but because his political masters, the ACTU, have said, `You cannot do it'. The Prime Minister's political masters, the de facto members of Cabinet—Bill Kelty, Martin Ferguson and their ilk—are saying that the Government cannot have a goods and services tax. They are saying, `You cannot have a fair tax. We will not allow you to have a fair tax. We will not allow you to abolish six taxes. We will not allow you to reduce personal income tax by 30 per cent because we demand that you increase the Medicare levy, that you increase taxes and that you spread the sales tax burden across a wider area'.

PARA.TAB: Of course, this Government is very cute. It spends taxpayers' money promoting certain products that had previously been exempt and then slaps a tax on them. Let me give two examples. Low alcohol beer used to be fully tax exempt. Drink-drive promotions were undertaken to encourage people to drink low alcohol beer. Once people were quite satisfied that low alcohol beer was not going to poison them and they quite liked it, what did this Government do? It slapped a tax on it.

It is the same with sunscreens. Many people will remember not so long ago the `Slip, Slop, Slap' commercials which encouraged people to use sunscreens, and the use of sunscreens, thankfully, has grown enormously—simultaneously with the sales tax. Yet here we have the Government saying, `We don't have a goods and services tax'. Absurd!

This Bill also extends its web of tax across services. Most people do not realise that some of their services are already being taxed, and now we are going to have more services taxed. Take design services: there are an awful lot of companies that do not have in-house designers, so when they send something out to be designed on contract it is taxed, but that tax is not refundable, as it would be under the goods and services tax. At the moment not a brass razoo is refunded. Once again, we have a situation where neither the Senate nor the business community owes any gratitude whatsoever to a government and a Treasurer who condescend, for example, to modify a general anti-avoidance provision so unspecific as to have destroyed all certainty in sales tax administration.

This Government says that charities should be grateful it has now changed its mind on taxing donated goods. Charities should be grateful: is that not nice! Charities are fighting to provide services and facilities for people in the worst depression, created by this Government, in 60 years—and this Government is actually contemplating putting sales tax on donated goods. Now the Government expects, because it has decided, as a result of pressure, to take it out of the legislation, that charities should be grateful. How absurd for that even to be a consideration in the first place.

We should all ask ourselves the question: what would have happened to this legislation if we in the Opposition had not sought to have it sent to a Senate committee for further scrutiny and we had not had proper consultation? This Government sought not one day's proper consultation with people prior to bringing in the legislation—not one day. The Government spent two years preparing for this legislation and still has not consulted; and we had person after person coming into the Senate committee and saying, `We were not consulted`. The Institute of Chartered Accountants, for example, was not consulted. The same story was repeated by the Taxation Institute, the Retailers Council, the Jewellers Association and the Photo Marketing Association of Australia. Two years this Government has had, and not one zot of consultation.

It cannot be assumed that, just because the Government has made changes in six areas, there will not be major difficulties for the business community and its advisers. In supposedly simplifying this inherently complex indirect tax, this Government has confronted business with a whole new ball game. But the Government does not care about that. Business currently is striving just to keep its head above water; it is striving to retain its staff and to ensure that more and more people do not need to be put off. Right at this crucial time, what does this Government do? It gives business a whole new ball game of sales tax to deal with.

Business is saying, `We cannot cope with any more. We have exemptions, we have things included. There is no rhyme or reason for sales tax exemptions or inclusions. We just want a simplified system'.That is what a goods and services tax is all about. All inputs are fully refundable in terms of tax and all outputs are taxable. That is what business is asking for—not this mishmash and extension of the mishmash that is occurring. I quote from last week's hearing a remark by Mr Fernstone, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Sales tax has to be kept intensely practical. It is a tax which business has to deal with day by day.

That is the sad part. The Government does not understand the restrictions on business and how this legislation will affect it. It is a shame that I now have to conclude, due to the luncheon adjournment. It is very important that this legislation is looked at seriously, and I hope the Australian Democrats will act accordingly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, is overseas on Government business and will be absent from Question Time today and tomorrow, 9 and 10 September. Senator Evans is attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation ministerial meeting in Bangkok. During Senator Evans's absence, questions relating to his portfolio should be directed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray.
—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. How many full time jobs has the One Nation statement created?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have an exact measure of how many full time jobs the One Nation statement has created. As the Senate would know, the One Nation statement was an inspired economic initiative by the Government to encourage further economic growth by stimulating the economy through investment in public infrastructure and, therefore, investment in the rail system, improved access to ports, getting the National Rail Freight Authority up and running, and a massive commitment to expenditure in technical and further education, in respect of which agreement was reached with the States and which went ahead in July. There was a series of other initiatives aimed at stimulating the economy that have direct employment effects and further flow-on indirect employment effects.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is possible to disaggregate from the employment figures which jobs were due directly to the One Nation statement, which are the consequential flow-on jobs that were created because of that, and which jobs were created simply because Australian industry recognised the positive initiatives of the Government and the level of confidence in the community rose. What is true and what is clear is that the initiative of the One Nation statement has had a very positive effect on the economy and is contributing to the recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I note that the Minister recently announced an export contract worth up to $250m over eight years to the Sydney-based car components company Johnson Matthey. Can the Minister explain the significance to this contract of the Government's export facilitation scheme for the car industry? In relation to the export facilitation scheme, has the Minister examined the effects on the automotive components sector of a zero tariff policy?

—It is true, as Senator Maguire points out—having a keen interest in the automotive industry as a South Australian senator—that Johnson Matthey has signed a contract with the Rover group in the United Kingdom to supply components for their vehicles to be sold throughout the world.
—Let's have a full debate.

—Any time. The initial five-year contract is worth $160m, but with additional yearly contract extensions it should reach $250m. Johnson Matthey is a company with a very good product, good management and a sophisticated approach to marketing. The Rover contract now gives it credibility with other international car manufacturers. The point is that without the export facilitation scheme under the motor vehicle plan, as recommended by the Industry Commission—do not let us forget that in all the excitement that has been generated recently—Johnson Matthey would not have won this contract.
—What value is that to Australian manufacturers?

—Senator Lewis would leave this place as a wasteland, under his Leader's policies. I am talking about an important manufacturing activity to which the Opposition's shadow Minister, even in his party meeting, was not prepared to pledge his support, and Senator Lewis knows it. Why did Rover, a big international company, place an order with a Sydney-based company, an order which provides jobs in Sydney and exports from Australia? It did so because of the export facilitation scheme, which helps Rover cars in the import market in Australia, which will be very beneficial to people such as Senator Bishop, perhaps, if she wants to lash out and join her Leader in buying expensive imported cars.
—What do you drive?

—I drive a Commodore, made in South Australia. Something the Opposition does not understand is that the automotive industry operates in a global economy, and this is about operating in a global economy—
—What does Paul drive?
—Are Mercedes made in Australia now?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—There is not a suggestion in the utterances of Opposition spokesmen on these issues that they understand what that is all about. Operating in a global economy, the automotive industry exported $494m worth of components last year—a steady increase on previous years. The fact is that, if we do not have tariffs, we do not have export facilitation; we do not have the facility to operate in the global economy, which is what an industry such as this has to do if it is to sustain volumes in this country. It is all very well for those opposite to interject about payroll tax or anything they like. It has nothing to do with the issue of sustaining an industry in a global economy, which requires volume, which it has to obtain from exports.
—Of course it does.
—Senator Lewis would not have a clue about it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not lift tariffs; we acted on the basis of an Industry Commission report, which those opposite are departing from. Opposition members have to cop that, and they are going to cop it a lot in the next few months.
—Why don't you put up payroll tax?
—There are one million unemployed in this country. That is what your economics have produced—one million unemployed.

—Mr President, I do not mind interjections but I do mind vulgar abuse of the kind that comes from Senator Short. I was talking about the exports by the automotive components sector. In the past 24 hours, when Opposition spokesmen have been considering Mitsubishi and Ford, they have said, `Don't be concerned with what they say; be concerned with what they do'. McLachlan said that yesterday. Let us look at the components sector. Last week Robert Bosch, a huge manufacturer in terms of automotive components, internationally as well as in Australia, put on hold a $40m investment until this issue of policy for the car industry is resolved. That company had a look at all the benefits of Fightback and it put that investment on hold because it understands what the industry is about.
—Tell us about Pacific Dunlop.

—I will tell Senator Lewis. He is used to trotting around the place more than many of these other people. He should go and talk to Pacific Dunlop about export facilitation and see how he gets on. See how important export facilitation is to that company.

PARA.TAB: That Robert Bosch investment is one which would create significant jobs in Australia and it would not happen—it is quite clear from that company—under the Opposition's zero tariff threat. What the Opposition is about, and has been about for the last few weeks, is talking down the dollar, talking down the industries and talking down investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have talked the dollar down.

—Senator Crane interjects. His true representative in this place, Tim Fischer, does not even know what he is talking about in terms of trade policy for the wheat industry to which Senator Crane belongs.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. This answer has now been going on for more than seven minutes. I bring to your attention your request to Ministers that they keep their answers to a reasonable length. This is not a reasonable length and I ask you to ask Senator Button to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, the Minister's answer was six minutes long. I was about to raise the point that it was a very long answer, but I again appeal to members of the Opposition who make loud interjections and distract the Minister. There is no point of order, but I would ask Senator Button to conclude the answer.

—I will just conclude, Mr President, by saying I was much interrupted by interjections. People feel the heat a bit; they get very excited. As I said, automotive component companies have significantly increased their exports. The forecasts are that this will continue. There is even more at stake for the component companies than for the car manufacturers. Under a zero tariff promise, the car companies—
—No-one is talking about a zero tariff policy.

—Are not members of the Opposition? Nobody out there believes them. Under zero tariffs the car companies would sack most of their Australian workers. They would still make profits by importing cars and selling cars, of course, but at a price which would be a rip-off in the Australian market because there was no industry here to provide any competitive pressures in respect of car prices.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. —I raise a point of order, Mr President. In the space of less than a quarter of an hour, Senator Button has quite inaccurately reported what he thinks went on in our party room yesterday. In his point of order, Senator Alston also said that I had misled the Senate about what took place in the Liberal party room yesterday. I do not mislead the Senate about what one of the Opposition's Federal members said in the House of Representatives today when he talked about a `Rambo-like obsession' with the coalition's policy on tariffs—a Rambo-like obsession! I do not withdraw that because that is in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, in answer to Senator Short's question, in terms of the political situation in Victoria, I repeat: when I look at the quality of the Opposition, I do not retreat from the fact that the Government should be re-elected in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a decision by the National Party's Federal Council at the weekend to reintroduce knighthoods into the Australian system for honours and awards?
—The Honourable Terry Aulich!
—Actually, they do not give knighthoods to Germans.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Faulkner and Senator Kemp, will you please cease interjecting.
—Despite the interjections of Dame Marge of Parramatta, I ask the Minister: will the Government consider any such proposal?

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I wonder whether we could note that Senator Aulich—the Honourable Senator Aulich, who fought well to keep that title—had the decency to blush before he chose to cast aspersions upon the good district of Parramatta. I ask him to withdraw.

—Mr President, I would contend that thrusting Lady Marge of Parramatta onto the people of Parramatta may, in fact, be out of order, but as you have ruled otherwise, I will not contest it.It has been a big week for the coalition. It has been a week where it has exposed itself to the Australian people as wanting to drag Australia back into the nineteenth century, and I suppose that is probably where it does feel comfortable. The week was kicked off with the Liberal Party revealing—
—Will the Government take up that invitation to introduce these honours?
—You cannot just get up and speak. Seek the call.

—It is a point of order. What does the Minister think I am doing? My point of order is that Senator Bolkus was asked a question as to whether the Government would implement this suggestion and now he is talking about it being a good week because various things have happened. He should be required to answer the question. This is not a time for debate.

—Perhaps I may speak to the point of order, Mr President. I wonder how the question of knighthoods falls within this Minister's portfolio. I do not see that it is a matter for Administrative Services for this Government to be granting knighthoods. If anything, I would have thought that it was a matter for the Prime Minister. I think you ought to rule this question out of order, Mr President.
—Order! As far as I am concerned—

—I want to speak to the point of order when I have got your attention, Mr President. I was going to say that honours are within my portfolio. That is in respect of the second point of order. In respect of the first point of order, Senator Hill would do better to stand up for the South Australian car industry than to pre-empt an answer from me on this particular issue.
—Order! Senator Bolkus is clearly the Minister responsible for the question and I ask him to answer the question that he was asked.
—As I said, the Liberal Party kicked the week off by revealing its plan to destroy the Australian car industry and take us back to the horse and buggy days.
—That is not answering the question.
—Order! I am waiting for Senator Bolkus. I am giving him a reasonable amount of time, although not much longer, to develop an argument. I am asking him to answer the question he was asked.
—On a point of order, Mr President: before someone starts speaking in this chamber they must at least preface their remarks with `point of order'.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did. I said, `On a point of order'. Twice now Senator Hill has just jumped to his feet and started talking.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the honourable senator is not. He must seek the call. Mr President, my point of order is that you should draw Senator Hill's attention to the Standing Orders. He must at least signify why he is jumping to his feet before he is recognised.
—Order! Anybody looking at the conduct in the Senate over the last two days would consider it to be a very low point indeed. I am asking Senator Bolkus to answer the question that he was asked.

—Senator Aulich asked whether I had noticed the decision last weekend to reintroduce knighthoods. The answer is: yes, I had. It was a National Party decision. The Nationals weighed in over the weekend with their proposal for gongs, wigs and baubles—a proposal to reintroduce knighthoods into the Australian system of honours and awards. Had they been true to their tradition, they would also have wanted us to introduce them with brown paper bags.
—I rise to a point of order. The Minister was asked a question and the question was whether or not this Government would reintroduce the orders.
—Order! I believe at this stage he is answering that question.

—I have to say at the outset that I was astounded by a proposal for government to reintroduce honours. I was astounded that it came from a member of the Young Nationals and I was astounded that a reason for the proposal was the contention that government should do that to give greater public recognition of the current system.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the Parliament—we, the Government—see it as a nonsense and offensive to those Australians who have been recognised under our system of honours and awards that this sort of proposal has been put up in such a manner. We are proud of our achievement of having put in place for the first time in our history a comprehensive and indigenous system of honours and awards. It is not something that was imported from Britain; it is our own. It is a system that has been built up in close consultation with our community, the Queen, the Governor-General, the chiefs of our defence forces and community interest groups. It does not include knighthoods and titles, because those sorts of things do not matter to Australians.

Knighthoods were introduced by the Federal Government in 1976, but they were done away with by our Government. We will not go back to a system which is anachronistic, a system which has been proposed by the National Party. In Australia we have quite a number of people who have been distinguished and recognised by knighthoods and other titled awards. Also we have many more from our community who have been recognised by non-titled awards, such as the Order of Australia. They are artists, academics, researchers, business people and community people—all great Australians and all recognised as great Australians. Amongst them there are Arthur Boyd, Lloyd Rees, Harry Seidler, and the list goes on. There is no need for titles because each still commands the greatest respect across the nation.

It is the Government's view that any system of honours has to be accepted and esteemed by the public. The system we have in place is esteemed by the Australian public. We will not go back to a system such as that advocated by the National Party. Awards under our system are given by an independent council which advises the Governor-General, and they are free from political patronage. We will not go back to a system where the brown paper bag ruled the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy what he is doing about the application by the governments of the United States, Thailand and Denmark for the access of fresh, frozen and cooked chicken meat into the Australian market. Apart from quarantine concerns about avian influenza, Newcastle disease and other disease threats, what investigations are being undertaken to determine whether such imports have potential risks to human health? What assessment is being made, and by whom, of the economic and social impact of this unfair invasion of Australia's home market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a request by the governments of the United States, Thailand, Denmark and New Zealand to market chicken meat products in Australia. Obviously, the first requirement is that our quarantine laws be observed and the health of our own poultry industry be protected. The task of ensuring that falls to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. Its job is not to act as a non-tariff barrier to trade. Its job is to be a transparent, scientifically based organisation that looks at the health and disease implications of imports that might come into Australia. It is an organisation which works closely with the community on those matters, makes risk assessments and is entirely transparent from a trade point of view.

PARA.TAB: The first point that I should make is that we are not talking here about obstructions to trade. We are talking here about protecting the health of the Australian poultry industry. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has prepared a discussion paper on the importation of uncooked frozen chicken meat to Australia. That discussion paper is being circulated for comment at the moment. A number of State agricultural departments have made comment and a number of other technically qualified institutions and individuals are making comment too. I expect—if I can accurately recall the briefing I have been given on this subject—that a formal paper will be issued by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service at the end of this year for public comment before any decision is made.

The second part of the question asked what the economic ramifications were. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics—ABARE—is also preparing a paper on what the ramifications for the Australian economy would be of an outbreak of Newcastle disease, for example, which is a well known avian disease which would affect the poultry industry in Australia. The Bureau is trying to make some assessment of that so that the issues of risk assessment can be brought into some focus.
