The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has asked the relevant section of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to prepare some sort of commentary on its assessment of the economic impact of trade in this meat. There is no ability on the part of any country to import uncooked chicken meat into Australia at present.

Finally, New Zealand enjoys market access for cooked meat at the present time. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is preparing a discussion paper on cooked chicken meat and that will be available for circulation at the end of 1992.

In conclusion, some questions have been raised as to whether there should be an external review, outside of the formal government structure, of the findings of AQIS when its assessment process is completed. That is a matter that is before the Government. I understand that the Minister leans in that direction, but at this stage I do not think a decision has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Belgium, which is led by the President of the Chamber of Representatives, Mr Charles-Ferdinand Nothomb. On behalf of honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mr President to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a workplace agreement recently announced between Coles supermarkets and the Shop Distributive and Allied Trades Union? Does this agreement show how workplace bargaining, Labor style, which is based on cooperation and consultation, is becoming the norm in Australian companies across industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This agreement does show that our Government's approach to workplace and enterprise bargaining is succeeding in the economy and that a number of major institutions in important industry sectors are wholeheartedly and full-on embracing the concept. The conclusion of a successful agreement between the Coles supermarket chain and the shop assistants union, which was announced just last week, is an example of further change and improvement in this area. This is a significant agreement.
—Tell us about APPM and how you handled that.

—I will come to APPM. The agreement covers 35,000 Australians and is the first significant agreement of its sort in the retail sector. It is an agreement that follows on from and borrows the concepts already established in the finance sector, where work forces are largely comprised of women workers, of blending the responsibilities of family and work so that working hours are made flexible to suit the needs of families, and to suit the needs in this case of the Coles supermarket chain which is looking to develop a late night trading element in its trading pattern. From that point of view, it is quite a landmark agreement. As it is the first of its sort in the retail industry, I believe that it will be something of a template for other retail chains when they embrace workplace bargaining.

PARA.TAB: This agreement is not an example of the Big Bang. This is not an example of what the Opposition wants to do in industrial relations, which is to create a big bang, chaos, confrontation and conflict. This is an example of cooperation and consultation and unions and employers working together to conclude, on behalf of those employers and their work forces, cooperative workplace agreements.

On Sunday, I released a study by my Department on the first 100 workplace agreements concluded in Australia. This study reveals that the features of all those agreements effectively are flexible hours; more flexible working arrangements; a high level of consultation and cooperation between management and workers; and improved levels of productivity and competitiveness by the companies concerned. That study of the first 100 agreements will be a useful incentive for other companies to follow along those lines.

I was interjected upon by Senator Walters who said, `What about APPM?'. I can tell her about APPM: it just said to its work force, `You will go on shorter hours and some of you will be sacked'. The same week APPM said that, it decided to sponsor an elite sporting event concerning a yacht race from Melbourne to Launceston. On the one hand, the management sacked the workers because there was not sufficient money in the till to keep an active work force employed and, on the other, it sponsored an elite sporting event, which is open to only a handful of Australians, to promote the company.

The comparison between APPM and Australian Newsprint Mills is startling indeed. Australian Newsprint Mills, a best practice company, has its own workplace agreement which was described in the cover story on the Sunday program just this last Sunday as having all the flexibility in our system that it requires, of having moved its balance sheet into the black and of having a high level of cooperation in its workplace.

Contrast that with the conflict and division at APPM Burnie and the report in that company's balance sheet that the dispute it conducted against its own employees lost the company some $15m in company accounts. An amount of $15m was wasted by a bull-headed, confrontationist management whose style was, `We are here to direct, command and order', as opposed to the management style of ANM, which is, `The role of management in our company is to provide leadership to the team'.
The Coles supermarket agreement will inspire other companies in Australia to go down the road of reasonable industrial relations practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, this is becoming a very long answer.
—It will prove once again that this Government's—
—And singularly boring.

—It might be boring to Senator Knowles, but this Government's handling of industrial relations and its changing of the work culture in Australia is vastly superior to the Big Bang, confrontationist theories of the Opposition.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the Standing Committee on Civil Law Legislation from the Swedish Parliament, led by the Chairman of that Committee, Mrs Maj-Lis Loow. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate. I trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and follows his answer to Senator Colston yesterday on waterfront reform where he claimed that the Government had already got efficiencies out of the waterfront. Is it correct that a joint fishing venture in Tasmania that would have earned $20m per year and a further $50m per year from an associated dock has fallen through and been moved to New Zealand because an insistence on the use of Waterside Workers Federation labour in Hobart inflated the costs tenfold?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I reported that, by agreement, a further 900 waterside workers had voluntarily left the industry, thereby reducing waterfront labour by 5,000 since our reform program started, which is a reduction of 56 per cent. I reported as well that handling rates on Australian waterfronts on average now were competitive with major overseas ports. I reported that container productivity levels had increased by over 50 per cent and that ship turnaround time at Australian ports had increased by 40 per cent. International shippers have said of Australian wharves that, in the past, they could always be sure when our ships would arrive but never certain of when they would leave. Now they can be sure of when they will arrive and when they will leave.

PARA.TAB: The issue that Senator Walters has referred to is an issue in which a particular company has said that there are problems associated with engaging waterfront labour in Hobart. It is said of those problems that that is sufficient for this company to not proceed with the handling, as I understand it, of fish at this port.

TALK.START.PARA: —Crews always unloaded them in the past; why can they not do that now?

—All I can say about that allegation is that I understand there are other reasons as to why this company is facing financial difficulties. In the past, we have constantly seen industrial relations problems being used as an excuse to cover failure in other areas of industry. Industrial relations reasons in the past have themselves sometimes been the cause of failure in industry. That is the case.
—This is the new cultural change, is it?

—That is right. Since we have managed to obtain a significant cultural shift in the practice of industrial relations, that has been far less so. So I do not join that group, of which Senator Walters may be a part, that glibly says that the reason why this enterprise has not gone ahead in Tasmania is simply industrial relations problems.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Apart from the fact that the Minister has not answered my question, can I give him some more information?
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.

—Given that productivity in unloading the fish fell by 50 per cent from 16.5 tonnes per hour to 8.7 tonnes per hour and the costs increased by $110 per tonne after the WWF labour became involved, making the project non-viable, when will the Government undertake the genuine reform that enables the use of this competitive labour on the waterfront that the Minister was talking about, for the benefit of all Australians? I also ask the Minister whether he would give all the other reasons that this company moved its venture to New Zealand that he has indicated that he has knowledge about.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I did advise, Senator, that often there are other reasons, and not industrial relations ones. Senator Walters has now asked me to enumerate at least one of those other reasons. This is a bit like the advice that lawyers should be given before cross-examination: do not ask a question unless one knows what the answer to it is. I will answer the honourable senator's question. The advice I have before me is advice that the company had decided to abandon this enterprise before it had even started to negotiate what the terms and conditions would be for the handling of this fish on the waterfront in Hobart. It had not properly conducted, or indeed started to conduct, the negotiations on this matter. It is the honourable senator's allegation that the costs were too high. Until the negotiations had been started and concluded, that issue cannot be said in the way in which she has put it. Senator Walters asked the question and that is the answer. I think she ends up with egg all over her face.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is he aware of reports that the European Community has recently set a limit of 10 minutes advertising time per television hour for all member nations and that, compared to other OECD nations, Australia now has more advertising time per hour than all countries except the USA? Does the Minister believe it is likely that under self-regulation advertising time on television will increase, to the detriment of both the viewing public and the quality of television programs? Finally, how does the Minister intend to respond to this morning's request to him to ensure that self-regulation will not mean an increase in television advertising?

—Of course, people are irritated by commercials on television. What people fundamentally want in a perfect world—and I count myself among them—is commercial television without the commercials. But we cannot have that. Senator Bourne has issued a press statement which is headlined, `Television Advertising Set to Increase'. I am in the happy position of informing the Senate that, so far as the Government is concerned, that is not the case. I have made that abundantly clear both publicly and directly to the senior executives of all the Australian networks, and they have certainly accepted that as the Government's position.

PARA.TAB: Commercials, of course, do irritate people. I must say, expressing a personal view, that I find some of the commercials that are run of a far higher standard than the programs they sponsor. I have my favourites. I like the RSPCA commercial. I am very fond of the recent ad on home loans, featuring a bunch of little kids talking about the houses they live in, that has been run by a particular bank in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which bank?

—The Commonwealth Bank. I like those ads. I think they are creative and entertaining. The point I am making is that commercial television is a business. I do feel that occasionally some people have trouble accepting that. As a business, its chief revenue source is its advertising time. Without adequate revenue, television channels cannot provide the programs.
—You have never been in business, Bob.

—I will get on to that, if I am given a chance. The programs that will miss out if the advertising time is cut down are Australian programs. I have no difficulty in asserting something I have said before: in the world stakes, and I have viewed plenty of material on TV around the world, I think the quality of our drama programs—and I include the soaps in that—is as good as, or better than, in most cases, programs produced anywhere else in the world. That kind of local production is expensive.

PARA.TAB: I commend the television channels because the commercial TV channels are the chief sponsors of this Australian production. One is caught between these two pressures. On the one hand people, particularly the Democrats, are constantly urging more and more Australian production on Australian television, and on the other hand they want to cut out the means by which the commercial television channels want to support it.

Comparisons with overseas countries—and I have pointed this out again and again—are, to a large extent, extremely dangerous. I notice the United Kingdom is used as a comparison, although the US, of course, has a higher proportion of television advertising time than we do. We are a very large continent physically—3 1/2 million square miles, with 17 million people scattered across it in a number of very small markets. Of course, I am very familiar with the potential advertising market in my home town of Darwin, which supports a commercial television channel. Those comparisons are largely meaningless in terms of comparing us with closely settled countries such as the United Kingdom.

The situation is that the industry set a standard. It breached it; there is no question about that. As a result, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal came down on the industry, and mandated a standard which, as from the beginning of this month, is currently 13 minutes an hour in prime time and 15 minutes outside prime time. I have personally communicated to the industry that it cannot expect to come up with a voluntary code which is out of step with the current mandated standards. That is the message it has got. It understands that. The Government has certainly indicated to the television industry that if it does come up with a standard which is out of step with the current 13 minute standard, it is unlikely to get it approved.

I think Senator Bourne's fears are premature, as are the fears of those other people. People should wait until the industry codes are being presented, and they are open now for public comment. The television stations are calling for public input—provide them with some. It is then a matter for the ABA to consider whether that standard meets with its approval, and will then register it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is he aware that the cost of shipping alumina from Gladstone in Queensland to the Bell Bay refinery in Tasmania is twice the cost of shipping the same alumina from Gladstone to the west coast of America? What is the reason for this disgraceful state of affairs? What is the Government doing about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered a question just a moment ago from Senator Walters about how stunningly successful the Government's waterfront reform has been.
—This is shipping.

—Of course, it is shipping, and I am about to come to shipping. Before shipping can sail—this is a rudimentary fact—one must actually get the commodity or good on board the ship. Therefore, the starting point in terms of shipping costs is usually at dockside, on the wharf. If I may go back to my answer, I have reported the significant changes in efficiency and productivity gains on the Australian waterfront. I refer to a very good article in the feature pages of this morning's Sydney Morning Herald by its economic correspondent, Mr Ross Gittins, about the significance of that change, and verifying many of the things I have said in answers to questions here.

PARA.TAB: On the shipping front, however, the reform has been equally stunning. That reform started when we came to office, when there was an average manning level on Australian coastal ships of 35 crew per ship. That level has now been reduced, without industrial dispute, by agreement to a level of approximately 21 per ship and in some cases down around 18 per ship. I received a further report only last week from the Shipping Reform Authority. It is not appropriate at this stage to go into what its new targets are, but what is in the offing for Australian coastal shipping is significant further reductions. Those further reductions enable greater efficiencies to be achieved on the Australian coast by Australian ships.

I come to the first part of the honourable senator's question—the allegation he makes about costs. I have no immediate verification as to the accuracy of the figures he offers in this chamber or the dates for which the alleged figures applied—whether they are current figures or old figures. What I can say is that there has been significant improvement in the performance of Australian ships. That significant improvement is borne out by the users of Australian coastal ships as well as by the operators, and even greater improvements are in the offing. This is an ongoing cycle of change and improvement, without dispute and without disruption.

I believe that the Australian coastal service will become amongst the most efficient and competitive in the world. I will be prepared to study the particular case Senator Parer has offered to see whether it is justified and how that might fit with the reform strategy in order to overcome what he believes are the obstacles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's remarks—I think these were his words—that the gains on shipping have been stunning, I ask him again: if that is the case, how does he explain that the cost of shipping alumina to a refinery in Bell Bay, with the value adding going on in Australia, is twice the figure for shipping that same alumina from Gladstone to a refinery in the United States of America? I add that I got these figures three weeks ago in Gladstone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in concluding my answer to this question in the first place, I would appreciate it if Senator Parer supplied me with the facts of the matter. I know from my previous experience with Senator Parer when I held the portfolio of resources—and it is a sad thing to say—that when he asks these questions he supplies only half of the information, not all of the information, to enable a proper balanced judgment to be made. I will be delighted to add to my answer should Senator Parer avail himself of the opportunity to supply me with the correct figures and for there to be a consideration as to whether he accurately portrayed the position.

PARA.TAB: As I said, recrewing has been undertaken significantly. There has been a massive reduction in manning levels. There is now a greater degree of efficiency. Skills are much higher in Australian ships. There is greater flexibility in employment of their crews and the operational times have improved significantly as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware of concern about the activities of some people operating as `migration agents', in particular in relation to fees charged to applicants and the proper submission of applications? What action has the Government taken to regulate the activities of those people to ensure that those who use their services are properly protected?

—I think most honourable senators will have had unfortunate experiences where constituents have come to them to complain of those who have parasitically fastened themselves onto some ethnic communities and offered advice as to migration and visa matters but in fact have been totally incompetent, putting in applications late, if indeed they have put in any applications at all. Some should be subject to criminal charges in relation to the deceptions they practise unscrupulously on many members of these communities.

PARA.TAB: The Government has taken steps to ensure that migration agents are well versed in migration law, are of good character and able to offer proper advice in a way that does not lead people to believe that they can achieve miracles. We need to guard against that practice whereby certain migration agents claim to be able to influence the outcome of decisions by having inside running in particular departmental offices.

I believe that those abuses need to be safeguarded against. In fact, on 21 September a new scheme will come into place whereby those who offer such advice will have to be registered under a migration agents scheme. It is very important that those in various ethnic communities or in the older Australian community who involve themselves in migration matters or try to help friends or relatives from overseas to settle in this country or simply to get a tourist visa or some other visitor visa should get advice from either the Department or properly registered agents. If they do not, they certainly will be in a position where the advice they receive could be very misleading and they could pay a very high price for that advice.

It is intended that those who offer such advice be registered, otherwise they will be committing an offence. They will be registered only if they come up to the mark so far as their real knowledge of migration law and their being of good character is concerned. I believe that the ethnic communities and those in responsible positions within the migration advice area have welcomed this decision by the Government.

As I said, the scheme will be implemented late in September. Rather than facing the prospect of 10 years in gaol—that is how seriously the Parliament takes it, and it has made it an offence for people to offer this advice without registering—I believe that those who presently offer such advice should become registered. In that way, we will be able to ensure that this parasitical practice does not continue in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to recent critical statements by the Chairman of the AMP Society, Sir James Balderstone, and other business leaders that government regulation is stifling business development, especially in exports. I also refer him to the comments last week by the managing director of the National Bank, Mr Don Argus, who had this to say about the Budget:

QUESTION.PARA: When I look at the recent Federal Budget I wonder what, if anything, has it done to further promote incentives to invest and save. And what has it done to further reduce governmental related costs of doing business.
The answer is I'm afraid not much. . . Payroll tax, training levies and compulsory superannuation levy are further burdens on productive enterprises which reduce their ability to compete.
Has the Government any plans to abolish the costly tax and other imposts on business competitiveness?

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the Sir James Balderstone the honourable senator is referring to is the retiring chairman of the AMP Society. I saw the Business Council paper; I have not read it. The Business Council for as long as I can remember has been complaining from time to time about regulation in Australia, largely when it has not got much else to complain about. If one looks at the nature of the complaints, they are largely about the Federal structure of government in this country.

PARA.TAB: When reference is made to regulations inhibiting exports, I remind Senator Archer that the export performance of this country has never been better. There has been a 23 per cent growth in total exports over the last eight years. There has been, year after year, an average of 15 per cent growth in manufactured exports—those manufacturers are the ones most likely to complain about regulation, not Sir James Balderstone, the chairman of the AMP Society, which has never exported anything in its life.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not attacking the man, are you?

—Not at all. I was not surprised to see what Don Argus said about the Budget. Of course there was nothing in the Budget about payroll tax and other taxes—these sorts of things. The Budget was not about that. The Budget was predominantly about creating employment for disadvantaged areas in Australia which have been most adversely affected by the recession. These things are not normally the topic of Budgets; they are topics of ongoing policy considerations. So I am not surprised at all about Don Argus's speech. That does not concern me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Firstly, I refer the Minister to the shipment of 18 tonnes of toxic waste that was exported to France on the Maria Laura and to a further loading of toxic waste on board a ship in Brisbane two weeks ago. Was the Minister satisfied that the relevant countries had been informed and had given appropriate consent for the waste to pass through their territorial seas prior to the issuing of the permits, in accordance with section 17(1) of the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1990? Does the Minister accept the responsibility for this failure to fulfil the provisions of the Act? Secondly, given that the Independent Panel on Intractable Waste has recommended that no further waste be exported overseas and that BCD Technologies and other companies in Australia are developing environmentally sound and efficient technologies and facilities for the disposal of hazardous waste, is the Minister's decision to allow further exports of toxic wastes, as stated in the West Australian newspaper on Monday, 7 September, a contravention of article 4, subsection 9a of the Basel Convention?

—This whole issue has raised a question regarding the interpretation of this convention, which I think will be of significance not only to Australia but to all of the signatories to the convention and those interested in this matter—that is, the interpretation of the expression `transit states'. We are currently awaiting advice on that. The Department was of the firm view that all of the actions taken by the Government in this matter met the requirements of the convention. That is as we understood what, I think on any interpretation, is as reasonable a definition of `transit states' as one could expect to get. It was only after the question was asked and an answer provided, that the Department received advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that the conditions applied had led in its view to a technical breach of the convention. Definitive advice on this has now been sought from the Solicitor-General by the Department.

PARA.TAB: It is clear, however, that whatever the strict legal position is, Australia has met the objectives of the convention. There has been no risk to the environment. There was French Government approval to ship the wastes to France. The wastes were packed and transported to the highest standards of safety. The 16-tonne container in which they were shipped meets high environmental standards.

To give some context to this matter, I recall—I rely on my memory in this—that when the question of a high temperature incinerator was being discussed for establishment in the Northern Territory at Tennant Creek, I saw some of the figures about the amounts of wastes generally that are moved around. France has commercial facilities that make money out of disposing of this waste. I saw a figure that indicated that some 700,000 tonnes of waste generally were imported into France each year from Germany alone. Just to put it into context, this container held 16 tonnes.

The Department interpreted `transit states' to mean those states through which wastes were actually shipped, that is, involving crossing borders and customs barriers, which I do not think is an unreasonable interpretation. Subsequent advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was that a broader interpretation should be taken to include countries in whose ports a ship that is transporting the waste was simply to dock, that is, simply to take on fuel. In other words, the sealed container never actually left the ship or was interfered with or touched; it was simply on board. This other interpretation is that that should also be included in what a transit state is. The Department has in the interim been instructed by the Minister to take a very stringent interpretation of these requirements. As I said, we are currently awaiting legal advice as to which one of these interpretations is the correct one.

There seems to be an area of confusion here at the moment. States which may wish to send wastes abroad for safe destruction cannot regulate the behaviour of shipping companies which physically carry wastes around the world. It seems difficult to believe that they can. A very rigid interpretation of the convention would make these kinds of trans-boundary movements almost impossible. Most of these issues can only be resolved—and I am sure they will be resolved—at the first meeting of the conference of the parties under the convention, which will take place in November this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday in Question Time Senator Ferguson asked me a question relating to the effects of the preservation changes announced in the Treasurer's Security in Retirement statement on the Defence Force pension arrangements. At that time I indicated that the matter was close to being resolved. I can now advise the Senate that the Treasurer has confirmed that the DFRDB scheme will be exempt from the preservation changes announced in the statement that would have affected computation lump sums available to members immediately after leaving the Defence Force. All members are now being advised through their chain of command.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the additional answer by the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson on 8 September 1992 relating to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in the Senate I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel a question regarding the Defence pension scheme, DFRDB. I asked a specific question, hoping to get a specific answer yesterday. The reason I asked that question is that the future plans of Defence personnel were in limbo and at risk while this very important issue was unresolved. My question arose directly out of the Treasurer's Security in Retirement statement of June this year. The statement provided that, effective from 1 July 1996, all employer contributions to superannuation schemes will be preserved until age 55.

PARA.TAB: Under previous arrangements, DFRDB has been granted an exemption from provisions like this because of the special requirements of Australian Defence Force personnel. These special requirements include compulsory early retiring ages for some members who could be only 45 years old when they leave and who are, therefore, forced to start all over again. In fact, due to the transitory nature of Defence Force life, members are usually unable to settle down, buy a house and do all the other things that normal families can do.

The exemption granted to DFRDB allowed Defence personnel, at whatever age they left the Defence Force, after serving their 20 years to commute part of their pension to a lump sum. It is extremely important to Australian Defence Force members who are in the scheme to know that this exemption will continue to apply, despite the provisions of the Security in Retirement statement.

Yet all this was thrown into doubt by a rumour that has grown in extent in the past month that the exemption would not be granted. The rumour made its way into the Defence circles, even getting as far as South Australia, where I first heard of it through personal contact with people in the Defence Force. By the time it got there the rumour had become so twisted that some Australian Defence Force personnel were advised that the Government intended to abolish lump sum payments under the new defence superannuation scheme and not under the DFRDB scheme.

This is a matter of concern for many reasons. One of the reasons why it is so urgent is that Australian Defence Force personnel have to make the choice between the DFRDB pension scheme and the new superannuation scheme, the MSBS, by 30 September, only three weeks away. Yesterday I asked the Government to confirm whether, in the light of the Security in Retirement statement, there would be any change to the DFRDB scheme. I asked whether the Minister, given the confusion in defence circles, would extend the deadline by which personnel have to choose between the old and the new schemes beyond 30 September 1992. In responding to that question, Senator Ray said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is still discussion occurring about the consequences of these things. I was informed this morning that those involved were fairly close to a resolution. I will not be able to make any assurances until we come to a final conclusion on those discussions.
Yet just a few minutes after giving me that answer, Senator Ray's office contacted my office to inform me that the Minister's answer was not completely accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is untrue.

—That is true; that is exactly what was said. The Treasurer had decided the previous night, Monday, 7 September, that the exemption would be granted allowing Australian Defence Force personnel to commute part of their pension to a lump sum before the age of 55. Senator Ray's office also informed my office that it was aware of the urgency of the matter and that all Australian Defence Force personnel would be notified of the decision immediately.

PARA.TAB: I believed, in good faith, the advice of Senator Ray's office. Last night I put out a press release confirming the good news for Australian Defence Force personnel, while still calling on Senator Ray to publicly assure the Senate of the matters that I asked him about yesterday. Honourable senators can imagine my surprise when my office was contacted this morning by the Armed Forces Federation which knew nothing of the decision made by the Treasurer and was still planning ways to fight this injustice.

After many phone calls this morning and much toing-and-froing, I have been assured that the Treasurer has now advised the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) in writing that the exemption will apply. I have been assured yet again that the Australian defence forces will be notified of this decision immediately. It came to my notice as little as 10 minutes ago that Air Force personnel still know nothing about the decision.

As yet, I have not seen anything in writing. I would very much like to believe the Government but, given the answer of yesterday, I am not so sure that this is the case, especially given that in a debate on the DFRDB this morning Senator Ray mentioned that he was not dreadfully concerned about the fact that defence personnel only have three weeks left to decide between the two schemes. I believe he should be concerned, because if this exemption had not been granted, a major change would have been made to DFRDB. It cannot be equated with just moving the goalposts; it is almost like shifting the game to another field.

I realise that it is a difficult subject for everyone to understand but perhaps if I allude to a comparison that Senator Newman made in the Senate this morning it will become clearer. The Senate will recall that relatively recently Commonwealth public servants had to make the choice between two superannuation schemes known as the CSS and the PSS. The situation facing Australian Defence Force personnel in choosing between DFRDB and MSBS is similar, but there are two crucial differences.

Firstly, there was no provision that in order to qualify for benefits under the CSS public servants had to serve 20 years. Yet that is what defence personnel have to do in order to get benefits from DFRDB. If they leave before their 20 years is up, all they get back is their own contribution. They do not get a lump sum or a pension; they do not even get interest on their contribution from their wages and salaries. If members stay for 15 years they are forced to watch their so-called investment wither away so that when they leave they effectively get back less than they put in. Secondly, there was no attempt to significantly alter the rules to the CSS scheme or the PSS scheme only months before the decision had to be made, and it was not left until just three weeks before the final date to resolve the matter.

I thank the Minister for clarifying the situation in the Senate today but I still believe it is deplorable that Australian Defence Force personnel have been left in limbo for so long, while trying to determine the right decision to make with regard to their future security in retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no dispute with this particular issue, most of which has been canvassed by Senator Ferguson. But I must dispute one aspect of it and that is that he said that my staff contacted him to say that the answer I gave yesterday was incomplete, et cetera. The circumstances are quite simple. Senator Ferguson got the straightforward answer yesterday. In the meantime, when I returned to my office, we finally received the acknowledgment from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), not as a signed document but as an indication, that he was going to take the action he has taken.

PARA.TAB: The answer I gave yesterday was accurate. The normal procedure is that when additional information is available I come into this chamber, as I did this afternoon, and make it available. A mistake I obviously made, out of some generosity, was to ask my staff to contact Senator Ferguson straight away to let him know of the updated position. It is a mistake that I will not make in future if he comes in here and dissembles and distorts what my staff said to him. I am sure he has not done that deliberately.The circumstances were that it was not within my knowledge at Question Time yesterday that the Treasurer had finally made that decision. There was also a gap between the Treasurer making the decision and signing the letter off to me to make sure it was properly drafted.

Nevertheless, this is an important issue. When the decision was made as to the date of the cut-off point, 30 September, no-one—not Senator Ferguson, I, or anyone else—anticipated that other superannuation changes would be made in the meantime which could affect this.As I pointed out to Senator Ferguson yesterday, it is almost impossible to change the date. The only way to change that date is by way of legislation. It cannot be done by way of administrative direction and it cannot be done by way of new rules or regulations.

The Parliament was conscious of the fact that we had to pick a cut-off date. We did that a year ago. We picked now because, as Senator Ferguson would realise, we cannot leave people to make the decision over a number of years. It would become an administrative nightmare and certain inequities would result. I am also pleased that the Treasurer has finalised this particular matter in terms of whether the members of the old scheme and their lump sums would be affected.

In the same way, I was very pleased to hear Senators Short and Newman clarify the fuzzier aspects of Fightback some months ago as they applied to military superannuation. If Senator Ferguson were to go back and read that document, he would realise that it leaves it wide open. Those two shadow Ministers have indicated verbally that a future coalition government, if it ever be elected, would also look after the armed forces in this particular way.After a little argy-bargy over the last day in terms of misunderstood timings, the result is there.

I would not worry so much about people making a decision in the next 20 days. They have been thinking of nothing else for the last year. They know what the possible alternatives are in terms of this morning's debate and in terms of the matters Senator Ferguson has raised. They know that it can go one way or the other, and have made up their minds and now simply have to signal that particular decision. It is not as though they suddenly have to sit down tomorrow and think all this through.

A problem in the armed forces is what Senator Ferguson referred to as rumours. As Senator Ferguson probably knows, a rumour starts in one part of the Defence Force in Australia and becomes fact five minutes later. That is the bush telegraph and that is something that is the bane of every defence Minister. As Senator Ferguson said, certain areas of the armed forces suddenly got the idea that the exemption would not be granted and nothing would change that view until a statement was made. That, unfortunately, is a fact of life in the defence forces. If we ever wanted to get this particular signal out we would signal all commanding officers and they would put it on a board. It probably would have been better to brief one person in the Army in confidence, not to tell anyone else, and it would have been around Australia in five minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I chose my words very carefully when I was referring to the answer of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). I did not say that the answer was inaccurate; I said that it was not completely accurate. The reason I chose those words so carefully was that in answer to my question the Minister said `there is still discussion occurring', yet when his office rang it said that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) had made the decision the night before. It seemed hard for me to believe that there was still discussion occurring about the decision when the decision had already been made the night before. That is why I was very careful about saying that the answer was not completely accurate.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the fact that Defence Force personnel had only three weeks left to make the decision, the disturbing factor is that they have known about the Treasurer's Security and Retirement statement since June. For the past two months at least, many of these members of the defence forces have been

SPEECH.PARA: mulling over this decision because they did not know what the consequences would be with regard to lump sums. It is not so much the fact that they have only three weeks left in which to make a decision; it is the fact that they have been worrying about making this decision for two months. Who knows whether some people might have made a decision based on knowledge that was not completely correct as a result of the decision that was recently made by the Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the decision to exempt lump sums. I certainly believe that this will take away some of the confusion that currently exists in the armed forces. It will make it easier for defence personnel to make that decision.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a brief statement on the conduct of Question Time. Mr President, I want to refer to the statement that you made during Question Time about the low level of behaviour and the low standards that you believe are being exhibited within the chamber at Question Time. I think to some extent you were talking of yesterday as well as today. We on this side are disturbed as well. I think your statement is correct. It is something that obviously all of us have to consider carefully—particularly those who hold this chamber and institution in high regard.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, as I understand it, the offence on this side of the chamber is that you feel there are too many interjections. In that regard, if Ministers would comply with the Standing Orders and stick to answering the question, the number of interjections would be very much reduced. Yesterday the Opposition asked four questions in the first hour of Question Time. Today the Opposition asked five questions in one hour. Mr President, it is not surprising, therefore, that the Opposition should find this particularly frustrating.

We can also understand that Ministers, in the dire predicament in which they find Australia because of the economic mess which is the legacy of their Government, instead of being prepared to answer for their Administration would prefer to come in here and bag the Opposition. But that is not what Question Time is all about. Question Time exists to enable the Opposition to question Ministers about their administration. That is the opportunity to which we are entitled. We should be able to get answers from Ministers on subjects that are within their brief. We should not have to suffer the abuse that we receive in respect of matters which are totally irrelevant to the questions that are asked. If Ministers would stick to that responsibility and stick to the Standing Orders, there would be far fewer interjections and the standard of behaviour generally in the Senate would be raised to the benefit of the institution and all of us who are part of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I think any reasonable person would acknowledge that an insufficient number of questions have been asked and answered during the last two Question Times. In minor mitigation, I must say that a couple of the answers that were given yesterday, such as the one asked by Senator Hill about Cambodia, were extremely serious and needed a full response. Tolerance is usually shown when the Opposition asks such a question and there may be something like an eight-minute crafted response. This should not apply to every answer. This may happen once a week; it may be even once a Question Time. But I think we all have to put our minds to maximising the number of questions—
—Apart from a bit of personal abuse, he basically stuck to answering the question.

—The honourable senator's idea of what is personal abuse or what he defines as allowable in the cut and thrust of politics is not accepted on this side. Generally, the cut and thrust of this chamber is that if we are considering a major Bill the Opposition gets 25 speakers and, because of time constraints, we put up only one. I think the Opposition has become accustomed to kicking downhill with the breeze all the time. Honourable senators opposite do not like it when they are hit with a more confrontationist approach such as Question Time.

PARA.TAB: I think we should acknowledge that everyone knows that the Standing Orders as applied to questions are a joke. If the Standing Orders were followed, 90 per cent of questions asked by the Opposition and 100 per cent of questions asked by the Government senators would be thrown out. Maybe a real effort will finally have to be taken by someone in this chamber to actually look at the Standing Orders. A senator cannot ask about this or ask about that. A whole range of standing orders apply to questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It used to work well.
—Why has it suddenly gone bad?

—Mr President, as usual, I am being helped enormously by honourable senators opposite. They just cannot resist interjecting. I will not pursue that, other than to say that I think the Standing Orders should be looked at and totally rewritten—particularly those in respect of which the President is forced to get up and say, `Look, if I enforce Standing Orders I will have to knock out 60 to 80 per cent of questions.'

PARA.TAB: I want to make this point about interjections: I do not think Ministers object to interjections. There is nothing wrong with being speared by a witty barb that comes from the other side of the chamber. That is all good fun; that is part of the process. But sometimes as many as 15 interjections at one time can come from the other side. On occasions interjections are made non-stop during an answer. Senator Hill says that that is a tactic to punish Ministers. It is a chicken and egg argument. Once we go down that path of payback, once we go backwards and forwards, the situation deteriorates and the position is far worse. That is the position we are in at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It used to work well.
—I am afraid that the most inane of all interjectors is just proving my point. Opposition senators just sit there like Foghorn Leghorn, bleating away all through Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, Question Time can be improved but there will need to be cooperation from both sides. It is not simply good enough just to blame Government Ministers, to say that they are involved in giving long answers et cetera, when an absolute deluge of interjections of a repetitive nature comes from the other side. The only way in which this can be solved is by exhibiting a bit of goodwill and maybe by looking at the Standing Orders. We need to have decent Standing Orders. At the moment points of order cannot really be ruled on because of past rulings. If we are to be serious about this matter, I think we have to rewrite the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I do not wish to canvass the matters that have been covered by Senator Hill and Senator Ray, except to say that I do not think it is quite correct to suggest, as Senator Ray did, that this matter can be solved by looking at the Standing Orders. I have looked into this matter fairly closely and it is my understanding the Presiding Officer in the chamber has virtually unlimited powers to ensure that the conduct of Question Time and other aspects of the chamber are handled in a proper parliamentary manner. It is very clear that in some ways in that sense Standing Orders are a restriction on the powers of the Presiding Officer. Where the Standing Orders are silent, the Presiding Officer has a capacity to bring order and control during Question Time. Presiding Officers right around Australia are in fact doing that.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the Senate are vexed by the length of answers. I can supply Senator Ray with a list of rulings that Presiding Officers have made in the various State parliaments. They have applied a very tight time limit to the length of answers. I can supply the Minister with a list of Labor Presiding Officers who have very strict views on issues such as debating the question.

I think we hide behind the Standing Orders. I have to say to you, Mr President, that it is my strong view that the capacity of this chamber to conduct itself properly not only lies with senators on both sides but lies very much in your own willingness to impose authority on this chamber. As I say, you have the power to do that. You have the power to make rulings. In fact, you do so on the length of answers. You have the power to make tight rulings on the relevance of answers. You have the power to make tight rulings on whether a Minister is debating a question. Mr President, I do not think we should duck behind the Standing Orders issue that Senator Ray has raised. It is an issue which lies fairly and squarely in your own hands and you will be judged on that in the fullness of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage, honourable senators, I do not intend to make a statement. However, I have taken out some figures going right back to 1982. I am prepared to have a full debate on this. I had a conversation this morning with members of the Government, Ministers and members of the Opposition. I say one thing in conclusion to Senator Kemp: at Question Time, if Opposition and Government members behaved as he did and interjected as often as he did, Question Time could not be held.

PARA.TAB: Senator KEMP (Victoria)—I seek leave to move a motion in respect of an answer given by Senator Bolkus to a question from Senator Aulich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—We have to have an indication of the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —About five minutes.
—Five for us; 10 in all. Permission will be granted.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Aulich on 9 September 1992 relating to imperial honours.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer given by the Minister for Administrative Services to a question put by Senator the Hon. Terry Aulich was an attempt to gain a fairly cheap political point on this whole issue of whether or not people support titles. In my view, there is a debate in the Australian community about this issue. A lot of people like titles. Certainly doctors like titles; senators like titles—

TALK.START.PARA: —And some senators more than others.

—Indeed, and others do not. I believe that is a valid debate and it is certainly a debate we should have. But it is a little bit rich when the questioner, as I understand it, is a former State member of parliament who has sought permission to use the title `Honourable' in his name and the answer is given by a senator who also has the title `Honourable' in his name. I do not know whether the title `Honourable' is a title conferred by the Crown, and I probably will seek some guidance on that.

PARA.TAB: What we had was a hypocritical, cheap shot by Senator Aulich which was responded to with vigour by Senator Bolkus. In my view, if one does not like titles, one does not use titles and drops all titles. If on the other hand one likes titles, it is a matter of extreme hypocrisy to attack others who are interested in them and believe that titles serve some worthwhile function.

When we go through the Labor front bench, all Ministers in this Government carry the title `Honourable'. Senator Cook carries the title `Honourable'; in fact, Senator Cook will carry that title to his grave. That does not apply to Labor Ministers in State parliaments. Mr Laurie Brereton and Mr Frank Walker, on the fall of the Unsworth Government, had to write to the Governor of the great State of New South Wales and ask for permission to use the title `Honourable' in their names.

We find also that a love of titles does not extend only to those individuals. Senator Evans—I think this is probably the case; if not, I am sure I will be corrected—awarded himself the title of Queen's Counsel. Senator the Hon. Gareth Evans, QC, will carry the titles `Honourable' and `Queen's Counsel' until the day he also joins his maker.

Let us have a debate about titles. That is fine and fair and there are a variety of views about that. But let us not have the gross hypocrisy of people who glory in titles and insist on using titles attacking other people who also believe that titles have some appropriate role in a civil society. So I would urge—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is fascinating, but I do ask the honourable senator to withdraw his accusation—
—What is the point of order?
—The point of order is that I am asking the honourable senator to withdraw the accusation—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I want to hear the point of order.
—That is not a point of order.
—I will make up my mind on that, Senator Walters.

—I ask the senator—if he says he is not honourable, then that is his view—to withdraw the imputation he was making that I was being grossly hypocritical, to quote him when he was discussing this. I indicated quite clearly, when I asked the question, that there was no value judgment attached to my question—
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Order!
—I am speaking, Mr Deputy President, and—
—On a point of order—
—Order! Resume your seat.
—Both of us?

—Senator Bishop will resume her seat. Senator Aulich, you are not stating a point of order; you are stating a point of argument. If there is no point of order, I would ask you to resume your seat, and you can speak to the motion after the current speaker has concluded.

—Mr Deputy President, I shall indeed accept your advice in that area. I will return to my point of order. I am asking that the honourable senator withdraw that imputation he made against me that I was being grossly hypocritical. That is my point of order. It is the point of order I made right at the beginning and I am repeating it now. I ask for a withdrawal of the comment from Senator Kemp in which he implied or stated directly that I was grossly hypocritical. It is an unparliamentary term, he well knows that, and he should withdraw.
—Order! I cannot recall that Senator Kemp used those words. If he did, I ask him to withdraw. If he did not, I ask him to continue.

—Frankly, I am not too sure whether those words were used or not. If those words were used and the honourable senator takes offence at them, I will certainly withdraw them. However, it is an astonishing thing for someone who has a title, who has sought a title, a title that I think is possibly awarded by the Crown, to attack members on the other side who also support the use of titles, albeit a different title.

PARA.TAB: In my view, no group in society loves its titles and perks more than the Labor Party; no group loves them and glories in them more than the Labor Party. If Senator Aulich does not want titles, if he does not believe that titles are appropriate, let us scrub the whole lot, kit and caboodle. Then we would not have `Mr the Hon. Dr Blewett', `Queen's Counsel' and all the rest of them, all with their titles, on the Government front bench.

What Senator Aulich and Senator Bolkus did today was to draw to the attention of the Australian public another important point: the obsessive hatred of the English by their Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the man who believes in a multicultural society and believes that we should all remember our origins, with the sole exception of those who come from Britain. That is what we saw today—the obsessive hatred of the Prime Minister in this ridiculous attack, this ridiculous question, in an attempt to score a cheap political point off the National Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is to a large extent a facile debate. Why Senator Kemp raised this matter is a little beyond me, other than that Senator Bolkus during Question Time hit a very soft personal point with some members of the Opposition. What we have just heard is a fairly shallow view about titles.

PARA.TAB: The issue here is not that there should or should not be titles; the issue here is on what basis they are conferred. Are they the old imperial titles conferred by the Crown on the colony of Australia, selecting citizens in the colony for recognition by the Queen of England; or are they titles that come under the generic `Australian', recognising distinguished citizens in this country because of services to this country?
At its weekend conference, the National Party apparently called for a resumption of the old imperial system—the knights system, the ladies system, a system that belongs to the aristocracy of Britain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Could I just set the Minister right?
—No, he cannot.
—If you have a point of order, you may raise a point of order. If you want a point of discussion, you will resume your seat.
—If he is telling the truth—
—Resume your seat.
—He is not telling the truth, Mr Deputy President.

—The issue that Senator Bolkus dealt with in his answer to the question by Senator Aulich—a question perfectly in order, although it was tried to be ruled out of order by the Opposition in its sensitivity but found to be in order by the President—was whether we were going to bring back knighthoods and ladyships. Speaking for a Labor government that is proud to have introduced the Order of Australia to recognise Australians with particular Australian distinction, we are not going to bring back the old imperial order. It says a lot about a country and its standing and recognition, its self-identity, its self-definition of what constitutes an independent, sovereign country, that we do not wish to abrogate an order of imperial recognition that belongs to another country, no matter how esteemed in terms of our own origins.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Kemp says that there are QCs on our side of the House he is pointing to the fact that there are no QCs on his side of the House, as far as I am aware. When he points to the fact that there are those who have professional recognition and bear the title `Dr' or academic recognition and bear the title `Dr', that is not a matter of imperial versus Australian orders; that is a matter of professional or academic recognition for achievement and distinguishes people in their professional field or in their academic field. That issue is not in debate here. When Senator Kemp raises the question of the title `the Honourable', there are more people walking around Australia bearing that title who are Liberal or National Party former members or members of this place than there are Labor Party members.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Sir John Kerr? He was a good Labor man.

—Sir John Kerr was not a good Labor man; he is a disgrace to the cause of the labour movement, and Senator Macdonald knows that full well. The title `the Honourable' is a title bestowed on members of the Parliament, on my understanding, by the Parliament in recognition of their eminence in the Parliament. That is to be seen, I believe properly, in terms of the responsibilities that those members of the Parliament have held and their position in the Executive over a length of time. It is a recognition of those who are eminent by their peer group.

PARA.TAB: The issue here is: are we to adopt or readopt a colonial system of recognising distinguished service and citizenry in this country or are we not? Senator Bolkus was saying that there may be those on the other side of the chamber who want to return to the days of knights and ladies but that as long as this Government graces these benches—according to the latest opinion polls, that will indeed be a long time to come—we will not go back to the past and we will stick with a unique system of honours that recognises the nationhood of this country and honours people for service to our Crown and to this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to correct what the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has just said in this matter. The substance of the motion passed by the National Party council meeting was that the Federal coalition, on returning to government, will reintroduce the knighthood and dameship of the Order of Australia. The motion provided for a further knighthood and dameship at the level of knight bachelor within the Order of Australia—and I hope the Minister can hear that—as a means of encouraging positive community perceptions of our existing and historical links with the Crown. It did not say go back. If the Minister listens for a minute, he might get the facts right. He has always been pretty quick to stir, but if he listens for a minute he might learn something. I have never become quite so excited with the Minister, but at this stage I think he is blatantly wrong. It is not within the imperial system; it is within the Order of Australia. That needs to be made very clear.

—I rise to speak on Senator Kemp's motion to take note of Senator Bolkus's answer. I normally would not bother, because I believe the Opposition is entitled to move a motion to take note of a statement made by a Minister, and time should not be taken up by members of the Government. But it ought to be made very plain, as any reasonable reading of my question would show, that when I asked that question absolutely and utterly no value judgment was attached to it. It was a very simple question. I did not use any word which was value laden. I simply asked: is the Government planning to bring in a system of orders—knighthoods, et cetera—which would be similar to the sort of thing that the National Party obviously accepted at its conference? The response from the Minister was as it was and we all heard that. No-one in this chamber knows my views about knighthoods.
—Yes, we do.

—No, they do not. I have never been on record about that issue. No-one knows my position, for example, about the flag. But since the honourable senator raised the issue, I will now inform him of it. First of all, I do believe that in our society we should recognise achievement and position; that is traditional in any civilised society and I believe we ought to continue that. Dr Hewson is entitled to be called `Dr Hewson' by virtue of his success in an academic field. Similarly, other doctors in this House are entitled to be called `Dr' by virtue of their profession and the qualifications they gained to get into that profession. I accept that.

PARA.TAB: I accept that people in this chamber ought to be called `Senator' both in this chamber and outside this chamber. That is the title that accrues to their position. It is a title which in many ways glorifies their achievement of getting into this chamber and staying in here, and that is not to be belittled in any way. Any political system requires a respect for those who sit in the ultimate houses of authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good Roman title.

—I have no problems at all with titles being used in the Australian community, especially if they happen to be titles which are indigenous to this country. Maybe `senator' came originally from the Roman system, but in many ways it gives us a sense of tradition which this country needs. I am not against tradition. I am quite conservative on these matters because I do not believe that we should keep inventing political systems or honorifics every decade or so to prove that we want to just keep up with the times. People ought to be entitled to accept that political systems have a certain consistency and history about them.

PARA.TAB: Let us not say under any circumstances that, firstly, I came into this chamber and asked the question with any value judgment being attached to it. Secondly, let it not be said that I am anti-English. My family background is like that of anyone else's in this chamber: it is a real mixture. We are in the most multicultural country in the world outside Israel. I am Irish, I am German and I am English. That is my background. It is a good mixture; it is an appropriate mixture, with all the strengths of those nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What went wrong with you?

—I have the thoroughness of the Germans, the passions of the Irish—presumably the paranoia of them as well—and the civility of the English. So some honourable senators opposite got the wrong end of those particular ethnic spectrums. But I simply rise to put on record that my question was asked not on the basis of being anti-English and not on the basis of being against knighthoods. There are many people in this community who already have knighthoods and for whom I have a great deal of time and respect.

PARA.TAB: If the Opposition wants my view about the question of knighthoods, the unfortunate problem in Australia is that many people who have had knighthoods have been given them in unusual circumstances in some States, and I think that is inappropriate. Knighthoods have been given a certain degree of colour that they should not otherwise have had. I will not refer to particular States, because it was done by all political parties many years ago. It was done by one political party quite recently, and it was inappropriate.

The Canadians have had their own home-grown system of honours going back 60 years or more. When will Australia grow up? When will we accept that we have a system that is already now well established and which is uniquely Australian? Let us not fiddle around with it. Most people in this society accept that our current system of Australian honours is appropriate. It is a waste of time to try to go back to some system that approximates the British system, the imperial honours system. It detracts from the position of those people who are now recipients of current Australian Orders.

The question is not just whether we are anti-British or not. We are citizens of the world. We do have a unique and mixed cultural heritage. Let us accept that. But, for heaven's sake, let us not go back in a difficult period of our history to 20 or 30 years ago when knighthoods were handed out like lollies. Let us not go back to a system which has in fact been well and truly replaced with the acceptance of all political parties—or at least the Liberal Party and the Australia Party. It has been replaced by a system which is accepted across the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do think we have to put this debate into its logical perspective. Senator Kemp rightly took issue with Senator Aulich purportedly making a cheap shot to enable the Minister of the day to have a go. Quite frankly, when Senator Kemp raised the question of the fact that Senator Aulich uses the title `the Honourable', he did so because Senator Aulich had to go to a deal of trouble to enable himself to keep it because it notes he is Tasmanian.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: the honourable senator is misinterpreting the situation.
—That is a point of argument.
—Let me listen to the point of order.

—I am on my point of order. The point of order is that I did not have to go to a degree of trouble. That is a misinterpretation. That honour was given to me by the Premier of Tasmania from that Parliament. I had only to say yes or no to his offer to give me that title.
—Order! There is no point of order. If you wish to indicate that—
—In fact, Mr Deputy President—
—Order! I am indicating to the honourable senator that, if he wishes to indicate that he has been misrepresented, he can do so after Senator Bishop concludes her speech.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Actually, Senator Aulich's very sensitive intervention at that point was due to the fact that he did have to go to trouble. The title `the Honourable' is given by the Governor. It is not given by the Premier at all. It is in many ways like any other title—
—The Queen's representative.

—Yes. It is bestowed and it is a privilege, not a right. Very simply, in this debate Senator Aulich has denigrated the title that is held by many distinguished Australians, which they hold under the Order of Australia and for which they carry the title either `Sir' or `Dame' according to their sex.

PARA.TAB: Very simply, there was a period in this country under that Order of Australia when those honours were bestowed. They were bestowed properly: they were bestowed to mark the sacrifice or indeed the contribution that those people had made to this society. Indeed, many of those people who hold that title under the Order of Australia previously held imperial honours. But under our system of honours—and I hope it will be helpful to Senator Aulich to know this—the Order of Australia takes precedence over imperial honours. For that reason, people who had been given imperial honours and were further recognised for their contribution were given that higher honour under the Order of Australia.

Very simply, for the National Party to state that it wishes to see that practice again put into operation is a perfectly proper question to be debated. It is, I think, low and mean of honourable senators on the other side to talk about people such as Dame Joan Sutherland as somehow not wearing an honour with grace, style and dignity. If we could learn some demeanour and some manners in a debate such as this, this whole Senate would be enhanced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate this afternoon in this Senate chamber highlights the determination of the Australian Labor Party to divorce Australia from its links with the Commonwealth, particularly the United Kingdom. This divorce is apparent in so many areas. Liberal-National Party senators on our side have repeatedly drawn attention, for example, to some of the criticisms by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I raise the criticism of the flag and his distorting of the facts of history, particularly when abroad. This has culminated in the sort of debate that has taken place this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: In addition to that divorce that has been perpetrated by this Australian Government, I draw the attention of honourable senators to a subtle change that has largely gone unnoticed in this very chamber—namely, the manner in which legislation is presented to this Parliament. The change that has taken place in recent times is that when Bills are introduced for debate here the wording now is, `The Parliament of Australia enacts'. This ignores the fact that the Queen has a role in the passing of legislation.

This subtle change of removing the role of the Crown, the words of the Queen, is symptomatic of what is going on in this general debate on the flag, republicanism, distorting the facts of history and so on through the very wording, `The Parliament of Australia'. There is no such body. It fails to acknowledge the Federal-State relationship that exists under our Constitution. The Queen is an essential part of the passing of legislation. In recent times, we have seen the withdrawal of the words `enacted by the Queen', et cetera, to be replaced with `The Parliament of Australia'. This is a Commonwealth parliament rather than a parliament of Australia, because that title ignores the respective and important roles of the States and Territories.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Michael Baume proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Government's Budget to provide long-term sustainable jobs and the Government's refusal to undertake the significant structural reform necessary to address the economic crisis facing Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance I am presenting today concerns the failure of the Government's Budget to provide long term sustainable jobs—and I underline the word `sustainable'—and the Government's refusal to undertake the significant structural reform necessary to address the economic crisis facing Australia.

PARA.TAB: The essential first point is that one cannot solve a problem unless one understands and recognises it. This Government has yet to understand or recognise the crisis of unemployment that it has imposed upon Australia. It keeps pretending that things are not nearly so bad; that things are getting better all the time. It is almost as if Government members were in some kind of fairyland. While they keep saying that they do regret the level of unemployment, they say, `It is not nearly as bad as those rotten people opposite or the Australian Bureau of Statistics or anyone else is trying to say'.

Of course, the fact is that it is a disaster. It is far worse than the official figures reveal and will stay dreadful. This Government is failing to provide any long term sustainable jobs in any form of response to this crisis. I suggest the reason is that they simply do not know how bad things are. For example, they look at the 960,000 people who are presently unemployed—11 per cent of the work force—and say that that is it. The Government does not take regard of all the hidden unemployed—all the underemployed—in Australia and I will deal with them later.

The big problem is that this Budget the Government brought down, which has already been destroyed by ballooning balance of payments deficits, the disaster of foreign debt and moves in interest rates—all of which destroy the basis on which this Budget was built—was already saying that even official unemployment would remain at disaster levels. It was going to remain at about 10.5 per cent for the year compared to the average for the previous year of 10.4 per cent. However, the Government hoped that by the end of June next year unemployment would be down to about 10 per cent.
Let us see from the Budget itself—this Budget which is already destroyed—what the Government was expecting if everything went well. The Budget states:

SPEECH.PARA: Employment growth is expected to resume in 1992-93. However, with continuing extensive business restructuring, employment is likely to respond more gradually to the recovery in demand than in previous cycles.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an understatement.
—That is an understatement, as Senator Watson says. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: As the recovery gathers momentum, businesses are forecast initially to utilise their existing workforce more intensively and to engage a greater proportion of part-time and casual workers rather than full-time employees.

I will come back to that. It is an absolutely vital point. It then says that the unemployment rate is expected to decline slowly over 1992-93 to around 10 per cent by mid-1993 and that the participation rate is expected to remain broadly unchanged. Let us get to the key issue which is that employers will be engaging in a greater proportion of part time and casual workers rather than full time employees.

PARA.TAB: This Government has carefully avoided any discussion of what has happened to full time jobs in Australia and what has happened to the breadwinner in Australian families. Of course, that is the crucial issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Work one hour and you are deemed to have a job.
