—As Senator Knowles says, someone who works for one hour is listed as having a job and is out of the unemployment figures. The simple fact is that this massive increase in the number of people who can get only part time jobs and who, under this Budget, will increase as a proportion of the work force, indicates a massive level of underemployment which hides the true unemployment situation in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In fact, what has happened over the last two years from July 1990 to July 1992 is that there has been a collapse of 363,100 full time jobs in Australia. They have been wiped out by this Government. However, the number of part time jobs has increased by about 180,000. So, in fact, the total jobs lost as far as the unemployment figures are concerned is about 180,000. In other words, something like half the real fall in full time jobs has appeared in the unemployment statistics because of this

SPEECH.PARA: diversion of people into the part time area because they cannot get full time jobs.

PARA.TAB: In other words, part time workers who just a couple of years ago made up only about 21 per cent of the total number of Australians in jobs, now hold just under a quarter of all jobs in Australia. That trend will continue and it is a trend that hides the truth of the unem-

SPEECH.PARA: ployment crisis in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which I regret to say I have not yet shown to the Minister. I ask him to look at it and seek his leave to incorporate that table in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows —

SPEECH.PARA: [TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 618]

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. One can say that this is no sudden trend. In fact, it has been going on for a few years, particularly under this Government as this Government's policies have priced people out of work. It is even more serious when one looks at what has happened to private enterprise and how the number of jobs there has been decimated. A report in today's Sydney Morning Herald showed that over the last 12 months something like 180,000 private sector jobs were wiped out, but, of course, only 19,000 public sector jobs were wiped out. So it is in the private sector—the engine room of Australia; the place that does things, creates things and establishes Australia's wealth—that the jobs are being destroyed.

PARA.TAB: In figures prepared by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for up to February of this year, we see that a total of about 300,000 private sector jobs were wiped out over the last four years, but only something like 8,400 public sector jobs were lost. The reduction in full time jobs in the private sector was about 338,000. When one takes account of part time jobs it is about 300,000. The situation is that the very sector which is being belted by this Government is the sector which is the major employer—the private sector.

Over the last five years the number of people in part time jobs has grown by 4.3 per cent a year while the country has been losing full time jobs at the rate of 4.6 per cent a year. In the 12 months to February there was an even greater fall in the number of full time jobs, when 243,000 full time jobs disappeared, or 5.4 per cent of total full time jobs. This is a disastrous situation which is not reflected in the unemployment statistics. That is the key point, but what is this Government doing about it? Of course, that is the key question.

There are about 600,000 people who are now underemployed according to the latest figures put out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They are working part time and they want to work longer. Those figures are up something like two-thirds—62 per cent—in two years. In some States there is an absolute disaster, for example, South Australia and Victoria. Fortunately, the people of Victoria will soon have the opportunity to express their views about this matter. There is a massive level of underemployment which has brought about a most interesting situation: the combination of the officially unemployed and the underemployed gives an unemployment and underemployment rate of about 17 per cent in Australia now, compared to only 12.8 per cent in the last recession of 1982-83. Yet we keep on hearing from this Government these nonsensical claims that somehow this recession is not all that bad; that somehow if the figures are fiddled enough, the Government can pretend that there is not this kind of crisis.

I am concerned that this Government is doing absolutely nothing to fix this problem except to throw money at some public sector jobs. We have already seen that there has been a very small reduction in the number of jobs in the public sector but a massive fall in jobs in the private sector. What is the Government doing to create jobs in an area that provides 70 per cent of the jobs in Australia? Private enterprise is where all the jobs have been, where all the jobs are being killed off, and where this Government is doing nothing to resolve the problem.

What has One Nation done to create any jobs or to end this jobs disaster? Since its release in February, a further 28,000 full time jobs have been wiped out in Australia. Unemployment has jumped by 52,000 over that period, and the unemployment rate has risen from 10.5 per cent when One Nation—or `One Notion'—came out to 11 per cent.

What has it done in these States that are now facing State elections? In Queensland, in the four months since One Nation came out—the proposal that was supposed to rescue Australia—unemployment has gone up by another 26,000 approximately to 169,500, or 11.2 per cent, which is worse than the national average and represents a sudden deterioration since the 9.7 per cent unemployment rate in April. We can now understand why Premier Goss is rushing to an election. All of a sudden, from being the State with the lowest rate of unemployment, his State has worse unemployment than the Australian average. So we know why, before it deteriorates further, Premier Goss has had to rush to cover up the clear indications that his State is as bad as, in fact worse than, the average in Australia.

In Victoria, which is a basket case, over the last four months unemployment has worsened by a further 24,000-odd, and the unemployment rate is up from 11.2 per cent to 11.9 per cent. We all know that Victoria is a disaster and that Premier Kirner is serving out her last days in that job.

Let us look at youth unemployment. In Victoria, the proportion of young people aged 15 to 19 looking for full time work is 43.2 per cent of the work force. We will hear the usual imaginative accounting from Senator Cook, who will pretend that it is nothing near as serious as that, that it is only about 10 per cent. He, like the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), has the ability to convert disasters into minimal statistics. The fact is that 43 per cent of young Australians seeking full time work in Victoria cannot find any. The unemployment rate for adults in that State, not seasonally adjusted, is about 11.3 per cent, which gives a total non-seasonally adjusted figure for Victoria of 12.8 per cent. That is a disaster.

Queensland is now getting near that figure. In Queensland, the number of people looking for full time work but unable to find it is up to 12 per cent. This is a severe reversal in recent times. In Queensland, the youth unemployment rate is about 28 per cent. I concede that that is nothing like as bad as it is in Victoria, but nonetheless it is steadily worsening.

One Nation has done nothing for Australia. Attempts by the Government to try to resolve the unemployment problem have been a farce. We heard more of that farce today when the Government tried to justify how its so-called waterfront reform results in companies having to go to other nations such as New Zealand to do their processing or whatever it is they do because of the failure of industrial relations reform and waterfront reform in Australia to provide reasonable sorts of opportunities.

There is a clear need to fix up this problem. A recent paper prepared by the Government Centre of Social and Economic Modelling demonstrates that almost 11 per cent of the incomes of the poorest 10 per cent of households is spent in paying Labor's hidden wholesale and excise taxes. Here we have a government which is belting around the ears the poorest people in Australia: 11 per cent of their income goes to pay Labor's hidden wholesale tax. By the way, that even includes taxes on toilet paper, soap and detergent. People do not realise this, but they are the sorts of taxes this Government is imposing, as well as adding new taxes such as the one on ice cream and flavoured milk. The people of Australia do not realise that this Government has imposed those sorts of taxes on them.

This Government claims that a GST would somehow be unfair. The fact is that 11 per cent of poor people's incomes is spent on paying Labor's hidden taxes but only 5 per cent of rich people's incomes is spent on paying Labor's hidden taxes. That claim is not according to me; that is according to the Government's own Centre of Social and Economic Modelling.

The Commonwealth Treasury has estimated that the tax changes in Fightback alone—that is, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the fuel excise and their replacement with a goods and services tax that is fully rebatable for business—would result in a $5.4 billion reduction in costs for the manufacturing sector. Remember: where are the jobs being lost? In the private sector of Australia. Here is one section of the private sector—manufacturing industry—whose costs would be reduced by $5.4 billion under the coalition's Fightback plan. That is exactly the sort of action required to give the private sector the opportunity to offer more jobs.

Fightback is a more jobs policy which leads to lower taxes and massively increased job opportunities and takes the heavy burden of government taxes off the very sector that has been so hit with taxes by this Government that it has had to shed hundreds of thousands of jobs while the Government's own public sector has increased. This Government in this Budget is trying to solve the unemployment situation largely by putting more people on the public payroll. They are not lasting and sustainable jobs; they are jobs aimed at covering up the real unemployment level.

It is interesting that it is not only the Government's own bodies that are demonstrating the benefits of the sort of structural reform the Opposition wants to introduce and which this Government is attacking in an extraordinary way. The Government is telling the most dreadful untruths about the consequences of the Fightback package, pretending that it means an extra 15 per cent on the cost of everything when we know that to be totally false. It is a lower tax policy.

The Chairman of the AMP Society, Sir James Balderstone, and other business leaders are saying that government regulation is stifling business development, especially in exports. The Managing Director of the National Bank of Australia, Mr Don Argus, said this about the Budget:

SPEECH.PARA: When I look at the recent Federal Budget I wonder what, if anything, has it done to further promote incentives to invest and save. And what has it done to further reduce governmental related costs of doing business.
The answer is I'm afraid not much . . . Payroll tax, training levies and compulsory superannuation levy are further burdens on productive enterprises which reduce their ability to compete.
We want to know what this Government is doing to reduce the regulatory and tax burden on business. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate on a matter of public importance, which is a formal procedure in this chamber to debate matters put on the Notice Paper by the Opposition, the Democrats, Independents or the Government. This proposal is one put by the Opposition. It alleges that the Budget has failed to provide long term sustainable jobs and that the Government has failed to undertake significant structural reform to address the problems of the economy. Both of those allegations are false. Both of those allegations are consistent with the Opposition's campaign to talk down the economy, to knock the economy, to knock the recovery, to knock the Australian dollar, and to knock, in the most recent manifestation of this carping criticism, Australian car manufacturers for daring to differ with the views of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

PARA.TAB: It is a knockers' proposal. We have just heard a knocker's speech. I say that in order to use the English language precisely. If it had been a speech which contained program, which compared a program of how recovery can be engaged in to the program laid out in One Nation or the program laid out in the Budget, it would not have been properly characterised as a knocker's speech. But it did not contain such a program.

It contained this chanting mantra: Fightback, Fightback, Fightback, which is, by the impartial analysis of the Australian Treasury, a proposal which, hopefully, will never see the light of day, but which will impose higher taxes and lower wages on Australia and, in its most recent manifestation, as I have said, which will reduce protection to help wipe out critical areas of the Australian manufacturing industry. So the recipe for recovery, the recipe to restore confidence in the economy and the so-called recipe for growth is one of higher taxes, lower wages, less protection and more damage to the competitive edge of Australian manufacturing industry.

We have not seen a comparative manifesto. We have not seen a comparative program. What this Government has been consistently honest and straightforward about is admitting, realistically and sensibly, what are the problems in the Australian economy and then trying, with practical means, to address those. In a practical, realistic way, the Australian economy is now recovering from the recession faster than other international economies of a comparable nature. That is of considerable merit to the Government.

It is also recovering along an economic strategy line similar to the line now being used in Japan. Japan is, after all, one of the most successful capitalist countries in the world. Japan has suffered the ravages of the international economic recession, just as Australia, Europe and North America have. Japan has adopted the strategy of One Nation, but has done it in a bolder way than we have done. We have done it in a more modest, careful way, but it has brought down a budget which stimulates its economy, which invests in public infrastructure spending and, by that investment, pulls through the private sector into areas of greater growth, as the private sector supplies the goods and services to the investment in the public sector and the improvements in infrastructure.

What we have heard is a knocker's and a critic's rendition of the problem. We have not heard any constructive alternative. I think that simply puts the performance here this afternoon in line with the immaturity and the erratic performance recently displayed by Dr Hewson.

There are two elements to this proposal—employment is one and structural change is another. On employment, let me say that in the One Nation statement and in the Budget we set out directly to stimulate growth in the economy by investment in public infrastructure. In One Nation, there is investment in rail and port facilities and road facilities around Australia, all of the materials for which will be supplied by the private sector and therefore lift growth in the private sector, and there is investment in training and skills through a massive commitment to the technical and further education program. We will have a skilled economy able to undertake sophisticated work in a growingly complex and sophisticated world. They were the positive initiatives in One Nation.

In the Budget, we have gone straight to the level of government that is closest to the ordinary Australian. We have gone straight to the level of local government. It has told us that it has significant programs ready to roll. We have provided the funds for those programs to move immediately. This will result in a huge commitment to local government and investment in capital expenditure by local government, as local government sets about improving the community assets at local level accessible by ordinary Australians and not by elites. We will fund that. This will create work in the construction industry. This will create work in all the industries that supply that construction industry, right across the scope of the economy. These are positive stimulatory measures. So, in terms of employment, we will be putting people in work. We will provide training. We will stimulate growth and we will keep inflation down.

Our commitment on the wages front is to maintain Australia's historically low level of inflation, as achieved under us. That must be compared to the consumption tax and the proposal of the Opposition. It must be compared to the element of the consumption tax which will take $7 billion out of the economy. At a time when the economy requires to be stimulated by a commitment from government, the Opposition's consumption tax proposal will remove $7 billion, deflate the economy and turn it into a downward spiral as growth turns negative and unemployment figures ratchet further up. It will kill all the employment prospects.

The other element of this proposal which has been put this afternoon is about restructuring. I will talk a bit later about the reform steps which we have successfully undertaken. Greater reform than has ever occurred in the Australian economy has occurred in the last six to eight years under our Government. It is a reform which is racking up positive achievement and results—reform without conflict, reform without dispute and reform without the social division inherent in the unequal, unfair proposals of the Opposition right across the board.

Before I talk about the particular steps we have taken, let us look at the scoreboard, because it is important to see whether the reform we have taken is achieving the results that we hope it will achieve. The best area of the scoreboard to look at is that of manufacturing exports. The greatest joy of any person looking at economic statistics out of Australia most recently has been to look at the area of manufacturing exports. This indicates a fundamental transformation in the nature of the Australian economy, as we sell more of the manufactured goods that we make in this country overseas, and as we provide more skilled and sophisticated employment for Australians.

We are moving the Australian economy away from being a farm and a quarry to an economy which sells to the world—and a competitive, cut-throat world it is—competitive manufactured goods. If we look at the current performance, we will find that manufactured goods now are worth, in their export value, $15 billion to the Australian economy. We now export one-fifth of all things we make in this country. Manufactured exports are second on the list of exports and are ahead of agriculture. This used to be a country that rode on the sheep's back. That is no longer the case. This country exports minerals and manufactured goods in that order, with an increasing component of the manufacturing sector, being elaborately transformed manufactures, and then it exports agricultural goods.

The other interesting statistic is that, in the six years to 1991, the growth in manufactured exports in Australia has been the fastest in the whole of the OECD and is twice the average of the OECD. So compared to our own economic peers, we have done better and we have doubled the performance of the average of our economic peers.

The two elements upon which this so-called matter of public importance has been based are employment and restructuring. On both fronts, we have positive plans which will turn the result around and which already have improved the performance of the Australian economy in comparison to like economies suffering equally with us from the ravages of international recession.

Let me now go to the Budget and One Nation in particular. Over the next four years, the effect of the Budget and the One Nation statement will be to add another 800,000 new and sustainable jobs to the market. This will return our jobs growth to the record levels of jobs growth that we racked up during the 1980s when Australia led the OECD and the world in its ability to create employment. This will generate the necessary economic growth and confidence to keep the economy going.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just an absolute incompetent fool.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! Senator Knowles, you will withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Withdraw which comment—that he is an incompetent fool?
—Thank you, Senator.
—I will withdraw the remark that he is an incompetent fool.

—I did not hear it and it is of no account to me that I am abused personally because that is an indication of an inability to come to grips with the argument. This will generate the necessary growth. The important thing is that economic growth does not overheat the economy and push inflation levels up. This has been a problem for Australia over the last several decades: as soon as we move into boom times, up shoots the level of inflation and a cyclical approach of an ensuing down time reappears.

PARA.TAB: I point out, as ought to be well known in this place, that during the recovery from the 1983 recession, the level of inflation fell, the level of employment rose and the level of real wages fell but with compensatory payments through reduced taxes and improved social wage to households so that living standards were maintained. That was our record until now.

We intend to replicate that because we are the only party able to assume government in this country that has a wages policy. It has a wages policy based on providing the best and most efficient economic outcomes for the economy but also the fairest and most reasonable outcomes for the citizens of the economy. We have a wages policy which is not the law of the jungle, the devil take the hindmost and `If you have no bargaining clout you suffer with a wages reduction'. We have a best and fairest wages policy which enshrines the cooperative ethic in wage fixation and industrial relations and not the conflict and confrontationist ethic that so typifies that of the Opposition.

When we approached the question of the Budget and One Nation, we identified five important elements: first, that there needs to be a significant and sufficient fiscal boost to the economy; secondly, that the levels and investment in skill and training in the economy need to be lifted to skill up the Australian work force to make it a more sophisticated work force best able to absorb high levels of technology and best able to adapt to the new emerging manufacturing cultures; and, thirdly, that we undertake the necessary structural changes in the economy.

The One Nation statement set out a program of structural reform for the economy that has been achieved and that is to be continued. Many of the elements of our structural reform program bear repeating. We have now reformed the finance industry. Telecommunications and aviation, central to a big country like Australia, have been reformed significantly. We have completed their restructuring and placed them on a more competitive footing.

We have achieved significant reform on the Australian waterfront and in Australian shipping. I know that this achieves a horse laugh from members of the Opposition because they cling tightly to their prejudices and bigotries about the Australian waterfront and about the performance and efficiency of our coastal shipping. I simply refer those opposite to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald written by that newspaper's economics specialist writer, Ross Gittins, in which he pays due recognition to the significant changes that have occurred there.

As well, the Government has invested significantly in this nation's infrastructure so that it runs efficiently and effectively. The national rail freight initiative is one of the elements of that investment which is transforming the efficiency with which freight is moved around this country. It is also instituting a highway of rail around Australia which will operate to the level of the best in the world.

We are establishing a national electricity grid—no longer six States all with their own independent electricity generating and distribution authorities, some of them overgenerating, some of them undergenerating, and with inequities applying between States. We now have the States—one of the hardest achievements in the Federation—along the eastern and southern seaboard of this country agreeing to pool their electricity generating competence and develop a national grid system.

Importantly in structural reform, we are easing down tariff protection to gradually expose Australian industry to world competition. No big bang, no sharp shock, no overnight change which leaves industry defenceless in the horrifying terrain of international competition to be wiped out or burnt to the ground, but a gradual easing over time so that there is stretched targeting encouraging more efficiencies and greater international competitiveness. We are doing that in stark contrast to what the Opposition proposes on tariffs. Whether its carefully crafted phrase `negligible tariff' or whether their real intent, zero tariff, is the order of the day, what is clear to this nation's industry is that there will not be a car industry in Australia if the Opposition ever gains the Treasury benches in this Parliament. That is not the Government saying that; the leaders of industry are saying that.

When we came to the debate about tariffs and our changes in tariff reform, we asked ourselves as a government, `What sort of industry does a modern industrial State such as Australia require?'. One of the key elements of a modern industrial State is a car industry because so much other manufacturing hangs off a car industry. So much other supply of componentry, so much other electronics, so much other sophisticated manufacturing hangs off a car industry. If there is no car industry, there is none of the rest of the industry that supplies those parts either. So we structured our tariff reforms in order that this country will have a car industry and so that this country, as well, will have a textile, clothing and footwear industry, both of which will be more competitive, more efficient and more productive but both of which will exist, so that people who live in Elizabeth, South Australia, in Geelong, Victoria, in Fishermans Bend and in other places where cars are made in this country know that they will have work to go to when we continue in power and not the dole as the Opposition promises them because of their removal of protection and the wiping out of those industries.

The fourth and important element of our program is that of social justice. We talk in this place often about economic efficiency as if economic efficiency distributes its gains fairly to the community and not in an unequal way to people who are best placed to take advantage. We recognise that there are people in this community unable to protect themselves for whatever reason. In their case, there needs to be a caring hand of government reaching down to look after them. Therefore, in our Budget, we provided for a significant reform and boost to the health care system of this country—so essential to a good quality of life for ordinary Australians. We provided a big improvement to community housing programs, We lifted the age pension above the indexed level that we proposed and we have increased rental assistance to those in need of rental support. That ought to be compared with the $10 billion worth of expenditure that would be cut out of the Budget under the so-called consumption tax package by reductions in expenditure on health, community services and welfare so that in an Opposition future, if there ever is one, the poor will suffer and be made the victims of society.

The fifth area that I go to in my last few seconds is that of industrial relations. Perhaps I can best summarise that by quoting what a number of business leaders said in the cover story of the Sunday program broadcast last weekend. The Opposition is so fond of characterising Australian industrial relations as inflexible. What did Mr Earnest Hacker, the General Manager of Australian Newsprint Mills, say about that? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that there is enough flexibility now within the system. It has helped us.
. . . we now are a productive and world competitive organisation.
What did Toyota say? It said the same. What did BHP say? It said in fact very much the same as did the other business leaders. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a certain sadness in entering this debate. We have had debate similar to this one before. I think the public is becoming sick and tired of the shadow-boxing which is going on in this place.Essentially, the differences are not between the Government and the coalition, both of which are pursuing policies of economic rationalism, but rather between what is going on in Canberra and what is going on in the rest of Australia. The divide is there. The divide is felt very acutely by ordinary citizens who are, as Senator Baume said, losing their jobs. Industries are going to the wall. People do not see any hope with either the Government or the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: So at one level we can indeed agree with the matter of public importance that has been put forward by Senator Baume this afternoon:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government's Budget to provide long term sustainable jobs and the Government's refusal to undertake the significant structural reform necessary to address the economic crisis facing Australia.

The Opposition is pursuing precisely the same sorts of economic policies, based on the same blind economic ideology, as the Government. It is particularly cynical of Senator Baume to begin his remarks by accusing the Government of not observing what was actually going on—`failing to recognise the problem' was his term. It is not only the Government that is failing to recognise the problem. We have heard the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) talk about how the economy is doing so marvellously. In fact, our debt is still increasing hand over fist. There has also been a failure to recognise that Senator Baume and the coalition would continue the same sorts of policies.

PARA.TAB: The Minister, Senator Cook, has just referred to the reductions in tariffs. As we know, the coalition would be even more vigorous and more brutal in the way it would reduce tariffs. There is no doubt at all that many industries would go to the wall. One could accuse Senator Baume also of not opening the window, looking outside and seeing what is really going on in the rest of Australia.

While we would agree with the wording of the matter of public importance, we totally reject the implication which lies behind the words—the implication that somehow Australia would do better under a coalition government. We totally reject the notion of economic rationalism—the idea of small government, small taxes, leave the economy to competitive forces, strip away all protection, strip away all defence—

TALK.START.PARA: —You want big government, big taxes.

—We were elected to this place to look after Australians and Australian industry, not to look after some abstract ideology which it has imported from somewhere else, which is what the coalition would do. The coalition has no concern whatsoever for Australians, for Australian industry or for Australians who are unemployed. It does not open the window and look outside.
—We are taking taxes off them.

—In that connection, let me remind the Opposition that of all the OECD countries we are the second lowest in terms of taxation. Opposition members are committed to greed. They want more money for themselves. They want more money for their mates. They want very little money for government which will actually address the serious problems of unemployment and the demise of Australian industry. It is not a matter of big government; it is a matter of adequate government to address this problem—something that the coalition totally rejects. There is nothing whatsoever in its Fightback package which directly attacks the problem which the Opposition has identified this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition is saying that economic rationalism, more vigorously applied, more brutally applied, will somewhere further down the track turn the economy round and, out of that revamped economy, will come jobs and a return to a vibrant Australian industry. It has not happened. It is not going to happen. It has not happened anywhere else. The Opposition is simply ignoring reality, as Senator Baume himself accused the Government of doing.

The Opposition is right at one level, in calling for structural reform. But the sort of reform it would propose, as I have said, would increase unemployment, increase poverty and increase the gap between the rich and the poor. In that connection, the Minister a moment ago said that we were following the Japanese model. The Opposition is committed to increasing inequity. We have seen that under the Government's program. Since 1984 there has been a marked increased in inequity in this country.

What one notices about Japan since the Second World War is that there has been remarkable equity across its economy. Business managers do not get paid exorbitant salaries compared with the workers. That contrasts very sharply with the situation which obtained in the 1920s. Japanese industry was very brutal to its workers. So it has been pursued as a deliberate policy by the Japanese to equalise the sharing of wealth, the sharing of those things which are created by productive enterprise. But Australia is pursuing, and the Opposition would pursue, quite a different policy.

We see that, for instance, in Dr Hewson's proposal for a $3 youth wage. Dr Hewson's capital assets alone indicate that he must have been earning about $100 per hour for every hour since he was 20 years of age. Yet what he is offering youth is $3. What Dr Hewson is about and what the Opposition front bench is about is greed in protecting their privileged position, not caring a damn about what is going on outside in the street.

The Democrats, on the other hand, have proposed a fully funded way of addressing this problem in our Getting to Work document. We recognise that the problems of unemployment and indebtedness need to be tackled not by increasing the deficit, which is what the Government is proposing, but rather by increasing taxation, by actually finding the funds which will address this problem and also by shifting money out of the defence area.

We recognise that the problem in defending Australia is no longer defending Australia against an external military threat—all the experts say that we do not face in the foreseeable future any external military threat whatsoever—but addressing those situations within the country which are a very severe threat to our future. There are problems such as this desperate number of 10 per cent, 11 per cent or more unemployed; youth unemployment; the middle-aged unemployed; the people who are disillusioned; the people who are alienated; and the people who are turning to drugs, crime and suicide as a way out of their predicament. We recognise that they are the problems that this country faces and, appropriately, we should shift a substantial amount of our defence budget across into restructuring industry.

We recognise that, rather than going for smaller government and lower taxation, which is what both the Government and Opposition are committed to, and recognising that we are a very low tax country—contrary to what the coalition tries to tell the Australian people—it is appropriate for those of us who are in employment to pay some portion of our income by way of higher taxation. We are proposing a jobs levy of 1.25 per cent structured in exactly the same way as the Medicare levy, to create a fund, not of a few hundred million dollars, which the Government is talking about, or nothing at all, which the Opposition is talking about in its Fightback package, but a fund of $2.5 billion every year for the next five years which could be used to address the problem of unemployment, to create a large number of, as the Opposition says, `sustainable jobs', jobs which will produce long term environmental and/or social benefits.

One of the criticisms one would make of the Opposition is that the Minister has talked about the money going to local government. When one talks to local government and looks to see where that money is going, one sees that there are no good criteria laid down to ensure that that money will go into areas which will ensure long term social, long term environmental and long term sustainable benefit to the community. Some of those programs of spending are certainly in danger of falling into the trap which we saw in the old RED scheme.

The Opposition is talking about waterfront reform. Certainly, one can improve matters on the waterfront very substantially. However, the thing which has been identified more particularly is to do with management rather than labour on the waterfront—the way in which the waterfront is actually managed. The Opposition fails to recognise that as we improve efficiency on the waterfront, that will reduce both the costs of imports and the costs of exports, so imports will be just as competitive within our economy as they are today. That in itself does not make the Australian economy any more efficient.

The Opposition has repeatedly extolled the virtues of Fightback in terms of the abolition of payroll tax. Recognising that this is a State tax and that it will require the cooperation of the States before it can actually do that, nonetheless, the Opposition fails to recognise that because its goods and services tax is a tax at the point of consumption, it implies a tax both on the labour component and the resource component of all goods and services made.Many recognise that tourism is a very important industry in Australia. There are currently no taxes whatsoever in that industry. If the GST is imposed on the high labour content of the tourist industry, it will impose a very severe penalty on an industry which many people regard as one which needs to be encouraged.

The failure of the Government and the Opposition to support an inquiry into tariff reductions needs to be put fairly and squarely on the record either by way of an inquiry here or by way of a Senate inquiry. Senator Spindler, from the Australian Democrats, has commenced a very comprehensive inquiry, supported by a large number of both union and industry groups. The inquiry has taken a considerable amount of evidence, indicating that the reduction in tariffs is sucking imports into the Australian economy and decimating Australian industry.

We have had this message from the Victorian Employers Federation, the Victorian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, the textile, clothing and footwear union's Federal Secretary, the Chemical Industries Council of Australia, the Heavy Engineering Manufacturing Association, the Queensland Sugar Corporation, the Council of Small Business Organisations, the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers and the Metal Trades Industry Organisation, among a number of others.

For the Opposition to continue to abuse industry in the way it has and, more recently, as we have seen with the motor vehicle industry—ignoring again, shutting its eyes to the reality of the way in which its reduction in tariffs, part of its Fightback package, will decimate the Australian industry which is left—flies absolutely in the face of the claim which Senator Baume made in his opening remarks that the Government is not recognising the problem. The Opposition is also failing to recognise the problem and will apply even worse so-called remedies.

The Government and the Opposition are pursuing a scorched earth policy with respect to Australian industry. It is their policies which are leading to the decimation of Australian industry, to the high level of unemployment and to the large and growing foreign debt. There is nothing in Fightback or in the Government's proposals, either in the Budget or the One Nation statement, which in a practical and funded way will comprehensively address these problems. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last 35 minutes have been an interminable length to listen to such nonsense from both Senators Cook and Coulter because both of them can tell a lot of stories without even blushing, knowing full well that those stories have no basis in truth at all.

PARA.TAB: It is fascinating, when we are debating a matter of public importance such as this about jobs, that today in Question Time Senator Hill asked Senator Cook how many jobs have been created as a consequence of the One Nation statement and Senator Cook, the Minister responsible, could not give an answer. Does that tell a story or does it not? Obviously, not one single, solitary job has been created as a result of the One Nation statement. The Minister talks about other jobs that have supposedly been created. Senator Baume has consistently asked him how many are full time and how many are part time and he cannot answer. What is this Minister doing?

Then we get, endlessly, the politics of envy of the Australian Democrats. If someone else has got something, it must be wrong because the Democrats have not got it; therefore, the others must have gained it corruptly, wrongly or whatever. The Democrats do not know and they do not care.

Here we have the Government and the Australian Democrats in collusion to put more people out of work. I think that is a very tragic state of affairs. Any claims whatsoever that this 1992 Budget will make any impact on Australia's unemployment tragedy can hardly be taken seriously and has, fortunately, not been taken seriously by many people in the community and a number of Government senators and members. The failure of this Budget is inevitable, given the refusal of this tired, discredited Government to tackle the structural problems that cripple wealth creation and destroy incentive.

The Democrats have come in here today saying, and they have said it repeatedly, that under Fightback the Opposition cannot abolish the highest single tax on employment—that is, payroll tax—because it is a State tax and we cannot do it without the consent of the State governments. Every time dopey Democrats say that, it proves that they have not read Fightback!. If they had read Fightback! they would have discovered, much to their amazement, that every single, solitary State Premier or Leader of the Opposition has at some stage in the recent past supported the removal of payroll tax. If Labor Premiers want their States to be the only State to say, `No, we don't want to abolish payroll tax', be it on their heads. But it is simply wrong for the Australian Democrats to come in here and pretend that we will not be able to deliver that. If Senator Coulter had read Fightback! he would have known that they all support the abolition of payroll tax.

Senator Coulter also had the temerity to come in here and say that the tourism industry currently has no tax on it whatsoever. That is wrong and he knows it, and if he does not know it, surely he should not be a leader of a political party. Does he not know that there is payroll tax on the employees? Does he not know that there is a fuel tax on the fuel and transportation of things associated with the tourism industry, to say nothing of people who jump in their motor vehicles and travel from point A to point B? They have paid tax on their car, they have paid tax on their tyres, they have paid tax on their parts and they have paid tax on their fuel—the whole thing. They get to the motel and there is tax on the bed, there is tax on the blanket, there is tax on the floor coverings, there is tax on the light globe, there is tax on the cash register and there is tax on the computer. There is tax on everything throughout the industry.

Senator Coulter comes into this chamber and says that the industry is not taxed. It is absolutely remarkable to think that he could be so ill-informed. Of course, under Fightback all of those taxes will be removed. By removing payroll tax, jobs will be created. Does this Government want to take that hard decision and remove all of those taxes to create jobs? Will the Democrats commit themselves to agreeing to remove those taxes to create jobs? No they will not.

This Budget is clearly based on the premise of `don't just do something; stand there'. This Government is just standing there, hoping that something else will happen and that someone else will do it. The only thing that the Government has done in this Budget is a bit of old style pork-barrelling. Is it not remarkable that one of the largest sums to go to local government in my State of Western Australia happens to be allocated to the most marginal Labor seat in Australia—the seat of Stirling which, thankfully, in the next few months will have a new member. Eoin Cameron will best serve that seat.

We have a situation at the moment where, to retain the sitting member, this Government has engaged in the old practice of pork-barrelling by pushing money into the seat of Stirling and hoping to high heaven that it will all come good. That is what the Government has been doing unashamedly in Victoria. Look at the recent comments that were made on the disastrous economic state of Victoria by Ian Macfarlane, the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. He said:
Obviously there are some forces at work on a regional basis that have given us this uneven outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: He commented that only 0.3 of a percentage point of the 4.7 percentage point gap in employment falls between Victoria and the rest of Australia could be attributed to manufacturing protection reductions. Therefore, the other 4.4 percentage point gap was a result of the Victorian Labor Government policies. This was a disaster.

PARA.TAB: Premier Kirner is trying to say that the removal of tariffs—the policy of both the Government and the Opposition—is going to cost her State jobs. Yet the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank clearly points out that it is her fault. It is her fault—not the fault of some pixie at the bottom of the garden. Of course, that simply means that the Victorian Government is 94 per cent to blame for the economic collapse of that State. It does not mind how many jobs it keeps on losing.

We have a Budget that will saddle Australia with $50 billion of debt by 1995-96. It is a Budget designed to create difficulties for what Labor now knows will be the next Liberal-National government. They do not have any responsibility in this Budget because they know that they will not be in government for any longer than next year. So this Budget is irrelevant to them.

The failure to create long term sustainable jobs is compounding what is already a massive human disaster. Conservatively speaking, there are in Australia 926,000 unemployed people, together with 82,000 workers on short time in supposedly full time employment and 591,000 people working part time who want to increase their hours. I say that there are supposedly only 926,000 people unemployed—a million people unemployed—because the real number is in fact much larger than that. The real number is well over a million people. This Government has not included in these figures people who might have a job for one hour a week. This makes them ineligible to be counted in the unemployment figures.

The unemployment figures do not include people who are in receipt of sickness benefits or various other forms of pension. Some of these people are not sick and they did not need to be pensioned out. Their real problem is that they are unemployed. This Government has constantly shifted them off into other areas. Therefore, the real figure would be closer to 1 1/2 million.

There are at least 140,000 discouraged job seekers who have simply just stopped looking. Seventy five per cent of these people are women who have been kept out of the job market not only by the Keating recession but also because of the continual refusal of Labor to allow the industrial reforms that will let them into the work force. Also, 300,000 Australians have been unemployed for more than 12 months and this number can only grow in the wake of the absolutely pathetic Budget of this Government.

More than one child in six under the age of 14 does not have a family breadwinner with a job. And 265,000 unemployed Australians are in families where no-one has a job—a rise of 25 per cent in 12 months. That is a tragic figure. One child in six is in a family where no-one has a job. What chance have those children got? Does this Government care? No, it does not because it keeps on increasing taxes.

We are in the throes of debating in the Senate this very day increases in tax. Yet this Government just keeps on increasing taxes in stark contrast with what the Liberal and National parties want to do, and that is abolish seven taxes and lower personal income tax by 30 per cent.

Labor boasts of the jobs that were created before the Keating recession. But we need to remember that for every 100 jobs created between 1983 and 1988, unemployment was reduced by only nine people because of Labor's refusal to offend the ACTU by undertaking structural reform. The Labor Party simply will not undertake real structural reform because its masters, the ACTU, will not allow it to do so.

This Government and the dopey Democrats are saying that young people should be denied a minimum youth wage. I stress the word `minimum' because this is another area where this Government and the Australian Democrats continue to mislead the Australian public by somehow suggesting that a suggested minimum youth wage is going to become a mandatory youth wage. They know that that is not true and yet they hope people will believe it if they say it often enough.

Surely it is better to have young people employed at $3 an hour, or $3.50 an hour depending on their age, than not have them employed at all and consigned to the tip forever. We are facing a very real prospect of having young people leaving school, going onto the dole and then going onto the pension, never having worked a day in their lives. That is not the type of Australia we want to be saddled with. That is not the type of Australia young people wish to look forward to. We want to change that. And it can be changed. The only way it can be changed is by real reforms—structural reform and taxation reform, and making sure that jobs are available.

But this Government simply puts the blinkers on and pork-barrels its marginal seats. It has no intention of creating policies for all Australians. It has no intention of creating policies that will benefit young people. It has no intention of creating policies that will benefit people over 40 years of age who have dependent children and who have lost their jobs. Many face the real prospect of never getting another job. The Government does not care about them. All that members of this Government are now interested in is pork-barrelling and pouring money into marginal seats so that they can selfishly try to retain government and retain their jobs. I contend that that is totally unfair to the people of Australia.

This Government should show far more responsibility by looking at young people and those who face the real prospect of never getting another job. I certainly hope that the Government will do so before it loses office. I hope that the Australian Democrats will look very seriously at the truth behind Fightback, the truth behind the abolition of taxes and the truth behind the lowering of personal income taxes in terms of the creation of the jobs that are necessary for the future of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a proposal put forward by Senator Michael Baume citing:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government's Budget to provide long-term sustainable jobs . . .

I reject this proposition outright. This proposition is totally hypocritical coming from an Opposition which, when last in government, destroyed thousands and thousands of jobs in Australia; it is a clear case of the pot calling the kettle black.

PARA.TAB: The Liberals now want to embark on a new proposal to destroy more jobs in the Australian economy. They have the motor vehicle industry in South Australia and Victoria firmly in their sights with this proposal to have minimal tariffs for the Australian motor vehicle industry. They want to tear down the tariff wall that protects the South Australian and Victorian motor vehicle industries from an influx of imported motor vehicles—and in the process they would destroy thousands and thousands of jobs in the Australian car industry.

The reality is that the Australian car industry does need tariff protection. It is supplying a small market. It cannot get the economies of scale which are achieved by overseas producers. The firms in the industry know that. The companies themselves know that tariff protection is necessary for the Australian motor vehicle industry.

Labor has taken a number of actions in recent years to help promote long term job creation in the Australian economy. I want to focus particularly at this point in time on the question of inflation—on price rises and on Labor's record of getting price rises out of the Australian economy.

It is interesting to go back to the rhetoric of previous Liberal administrations. I can remember them saying things like, `High inflation works to destroy jobs in the Australian economy'. That was their rhetoric in earlier years of this decade—that high inflation destroys jobs in the Australian economy; that it takes work away from many potential employees by pushing up wages and cost structures and, therefore, by making firms uncompetitive. That was the Liberal Party rhetoric—fight inflation first; fight inflation to provide for long term jobs in Australia.

But the Liberal Party left office in 1983 with inflation running in the double digit range. It left office with an inflation rate for the year—the rate for price rises—of 11 1/2 per cent. Under the Labor administration, the rate of price rises is no longer in the double digit range. In fact, the last consumer price index for the June quarter showed very clearly that we have now an annual rate of inflation in this country of 1.2 per cent. That was the figure recorded by the consumer price index.

In other words, inflation now under the Labor administration is just over one-tenth of the 11 1/2 per cent rate that the Liberals left Australia with in 1983. So, on the basis of the Liberals' rhetoric taken at its face value, if it is true that inflation destroys jobs, the fact that Labor has got inflation largely out of the system and is making further progress in that regard must mean that it is underpinning long term job creation in the Australian economy.

The reality is that Australian firms are now more competitive. They are in a better cost position relative to overseas suppliers of competing products as a result of these policies of getting inflation out of the system. It is very interesting indeed to look at how our inflation rate now compares with the rates of our overseas trading partners. The average inflation rate—the average rate of price rises per annum—in the countries with which we mainly trade is now 3 1/4 per cent per annum. That is the average of all the countries. In Australia, as I have pointed out, our inflation rate is below 2 per cent per annum. So every month that goes by means that Australian firms are becoming more price competitive because the Australian cost structure is not rising as fast as cost structures facing firms in other countries. So, basically, looking at the Liberal Party rhetoric about inflation destroying jobs, we have got inflation out of the system; therefore, we are doing a lot for long term job creation in the Australian economy.

Prices have been cut by a range of policy weapons in Australia. There has been the accord with the ACTU in regard to wage rises. Interest rates now being part of the base for the consumer price index means that every time interest rates are reduced inflation comes down—and that is very important. That is one of the reasons inflation has come down so significantly—the recurring cuts in interest rates by this Government.

There has also been the increased competitive pressure on the Australian economy as a result of Labor policy. We have deregulated some particular parts of the Australian economy. I notice, for example, that we now have a third airline flying between major cities in Australia. Under the Liberals we had a policy called the two-airline policy. Labor has opened up the airline industry; there is now a third supplier of airline services in Australia—and that is symptomatic of the policy change under this Government which is introducing more competitive pressure into the Australian economy and, therefore, helping to keep prices down.

I turn very briefly to interest rates. It is interesting to look at the history of the reductions in interest rates that have occurred. This Government began reducing official interest rates through the operation of monetary policy in around January 1990, 2 1/2 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —You put it up to about 24 per cent.

—It is interesting that at that point in time Dr Hewson berated this Government and criticised us in the media. I tell Senator Macdonald that Dr Hewson is on record as saying that we were premature, that we were acting too hastily. In January 1990 he said that we were acting too hastily in bringing interest rates down. Senator Macdonald obviously does not realise that. Dr Hewson is the man who now wants to slash tariffs for the car industry—the man with the totally rigid, dogmatic thinking who said, in January 1990, that this Government, in embarking on a round of interest rate reductions, was operating prematurely and acting too hastily to ease monetary policy in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have had now, I think, 13 rounds of official cuts in interest rates. Rates are now in the range of 5 to 6 per cent for overnight cash. They are very low rates indeed and very competitive. They are very low rates when compared with those in other countries. But the important thing, as I have pointed out, is that every time interest rates have come down, now that interest rates are part of the cost base for the consumer price index calculations, so too has the consumer price index—and that has been very important.

It is interesting to note that the interest rate reductions are impacting already on the Australian economy in two key sectors. There are two areas where households make major purchases—very infrequent but very expensive purchases. I refer to homes or dwellings and to new motor vehicles. It is interesting that both sectors are responding to the cuts in interest rates. Those items depend heavily on finance. People do not typically pay for motor vehicles or homes out of their cash incomes. They require finance for them and interest is charged on that finance.

In the three months to July, on the latest figures we have available, there has been a 22 per cent increase in approvals for new dwellings compared with last year. More than 40,000 new dwellings have been approved in the three months to July compared with 33,000 last year—a very big increase. The housing industry, of course, is a very labour intensive industry. As this proposal is about job creation, I make the point that, as those housing approvals feed through into bricks and mortar in real housing starts, we are going to see significant increases in employment in the Australian home building industry.

New motor vehicle registrations also have increased. In the three months to July there were 115,000 registrations of new motor vehicles; in the three months to July last year there were 104,000. So there has been a 10 per cent increase in registrations of new motor vehicles. That is a very important indicator for one of the largest industries in Australia.

But again I refer back to the policies of Dr Hewson and Mr McLachlan, who would tear down the tariff wall that protects the largest private sector industry in my State of South Australia, the new motor vehicle industry, and probably the largest private sector industry in the State of Victoria. These crazy people with these obsessions—

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Labor Party has reduced them from 40 per cent to 15 per cent.
—You are going to wipe it out.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Can we just let Senator Maguire have the floor, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —These people—with their dogmatic thinking and their obsessions about unique economic solutions, who think that by following a text book literally they are going to run economic policy successfully—are the people who are dangerous; they are the ones who would tear down the very important tariff wall around the Australian car industry.

PARA.TAB: I want to spend some time tonight talking about the profound and grave danger posed to the Australian tourism industry by the goods and services tax—an issue that I am sure will be of interest to Senator Macdonald from Queensland. It is an absolutely undeniable case that this major, long term creator of jobs in the Australian economy is at risk as a result of the policies of Dr Hewson and the crazy dries in the Liberal Party. Let us look at the record.

Look at the job creation under Labor in the tourism and hospitality sector. In 1981-82, under the Liberal Party Government there were 337,000 jobs in the tourism industry. Now, under the Labor Party Government, there are 450,000 jobs in that industry. That is an increase of over 100,000 jobs under this Government. Under the Liberal Government in the early 1980s, there were less than half a million overseas visitors to Australia per annum. Now, under the Labor Government, there are 2 1/2 million overseas visitors coming to Australia per annum. Jobs have been created in the tourism industry because of the increased numbers of visitors coming here.

We now have forecasts from the tourism authorities that suggest that another 200,000 jobs could be created in that industry by the turn of the century. Based on current policies, policies in place now, another 200,000 jobs could be created in that industry. However, we have the spectre of the goods and services tax, a policy of the Liberals, which would bring the tourism industry to its knees. It could destroy any prospect of another 200,000 jobs being created in this major export earning industry.

Australia earns $7 billion a year from the tourism industry, yet the Liberal Party wants to subject it to a 15 per cent goods and services tax. It is a major export industry for Australia and these crackpots, the dries driving these crazy policies in the Liberal Party, want to put a 15 per cent tax on this industry. Again, it is a reflection of Dr Hewson's obsession with neatness. He wants a 15 per cent tax on everything. He will not make any exemptions, unless pressure is put on him to do so, as it was recently. He will not even give the tourism industry—a major export earner—an exemption from this proposed tax. He has this obsession that, by having a single rate of tax on everything, he will somehow fix the economy's problems, yet he has this blind spot about this major export earner for Australia. I am pleased to say that Liberal Party policy is being driven up a blind alley by these dries and there is no way out.

We see people in the Liberal Party like Mr Jull, a member from Queensland, proposing that the tax subsidised lunch, the business lunch, be brought back. The rest of us taxpayers would have to subsidise people to go out to lunch. He is proposing that to counteract the damage which will be caused to the tourism and hospitality industry by the goods and services tax. What a crazy policy. Those opposite want a bad policy to cancel out a bad policy. That is what they are on about. It is a serious proposal being floated by these crackpots in the Liberal Party. They want to bring back another bad, crazy, looney policy.

Let us look at the reality of the goods and services tax as it affects the tourism industry. In 1990, Sweden brought in a value added tax—a goods and services tax—on tourism. What happened in Sweden? A year later there was a 13 per cent fall in the number of inbound tourists. There was a 13 per cent reduction in international visitors to Sweden after the value added tax was brought into that country. If I were Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I would be very worried about what would happen to the tourism industry in Queensland as a result of these crackpot policies being introduced into Australia. This year, Sweden has been forced to lower its VAT rate on tourism because it has acknowledged that it is damaging the industry. France has a concessional rate for tourism; Dr Hewson will not have a concessional rate for tourism. Canada has a rebate for international tourists; Dr Hewson will not be into that.

The problem we face with these crackpot policies is that those opposite are going to make Australia a more expensive tourist destination. They are going to put up the price of tourism in Australia compared with destinations overseas. By proposing this policy, they are throwing away a relative price advantage that the Australian tourism industry has. They are going to throw it away by bringing in a GST. Senator Knowles says, `We will get rid of payroll tax', but the reality is that 87 per cent of firms in the tourism industry do not pay payroll tax now. They are small businesses which are exempt from payroll tax by the exemptions operated by the States. We are creating long term jobs by boosting the tourism industry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—Tell us about the tariffs.

—I will get to that in a few moments and I will point out the utter hypocrisy of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and his colleagues in regard to this matter. This matter of public importance is of relevance to hundreds of thousands of unemployed Australians because it highlights why the recent Budget should be the last Budget of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and it explains very clearly why it will be his last.

PARA.TAB: This Government's bankcard Budget has been widely condemned, not only by the Opposition but in the media, by economists both in Australia and overseas and, more importantly, by many ordinary Australians. It has been condemned rightly for what it is—nothing more than a bagful of stop-gap solutions for artificially lowering the unemployment levels in order to buy votes for the next election.
A telling report on the Budget reached me this week from ANZ Group Economics. In its overall assessment and summary of the Budget, the report said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Budget should be viewed as a response to the highest level of unemployment in 60 years, an economy that remains sluggish, and a Federal election that has to occur by the middle of 1993.
That last clause is the most telling remark in that assessment. It goes on to say:
Those looking for strong signs of micro-economic reform in the Budget or steps that will bring the public sector back into surplus in the mid-1990s will be disappointed.
Need I say any more to sustain the terms of the Opposition's matter of public importance this afternoon which is:

The failure of the Government's Budget to provide long-term sustainable jobs and the Government's refusal to undertake the significant structural reform necessary to address the economic crisis facing Australia.

PARA.TAB: The ANZ report reflects the mood of people generally that the Labor Government has not learnt from its past mistakes and that it has learnt little from the over-optimistic forecasts it made in its February One Nation statement. Prime Minister Keating and Treasurer Dawkins have attempted a conjuring trick. They have tried to hide the unemployed by putting some 400,000 of them into training courses. What they have not done is provide long term, sustainable jobs for all of these trainees when they emerge at the other end, or at least create the circumstances in which those jobs will be available by the end of those training courses. They are just putting off the inevitable, scraping the dole queues under the carpet while they try to win another election.

As my Leader said, we will just end up with the most educated dole queues in the world. Even if the Government can get the unemployment figure down to 10 per cent by next year, that still means there will be some 870,000 people without jobs. Currently, more than 11 per cent of Australians are—at this very minute—unable to find work and therefore unable to properly care for and provide for their dependants.

TALK.START.PARA: —My husband.

—As Senator Sowada says, even her husband is unable to find work—a man as obviously well educated as he would be. A great many of these job seekers are young, inexperienced and disillusioned. Not only are they victims of today, but they represent Australia's problems of tomorrow, our nation's problems of next year and, most uncomfortably, our nation's problems of the next century.

PARA.TAB: Eleven per cent of Australians are suffering in anguish and great distress because this Government has been telling lies for the past 10 years about what it is going to do for them, but it has done nothing but let them down and let them down badly. I need not repeat here the misleading statements made by the Prime Minister when he was Treasurer, year after year in Budget Speech after Budget Speech, which gave the people of Australia false hope and which were nothing more than what could be politely described as misleading statements.

In my home State of South Australia the unemployment figures are a lot higher where, thanks to State Labor mismanagement, we have the highest levels of debt and unemployment in the country, particularly among young people. The indications for future employment growth are nothing short of appalling. The ANZ Bank's most recent survey of job vacancies shows that advertised job vacancies have remained virtually unchanged in the last two months and have actually fallen since April.

The August unemployment rate, due out tomorrow, is forecast to be between 10.8 per cent and 11.5 per cent. The simple fact is that in this country we have over one million people unable to obtain work and, when we add the number of unemployed with those underemployed, we have a figure approaching some 20 per cent of the Australian work force who cannot gain jobs—20 per cent of the work force of this nation which is now supposed to be out of recession. That is a ludicrous scenario as we bound towards the twenty-first century.

But what is the response of the Government to this social disaster? Mere diversionary tactics which do not address the heart of the problem. And we heard it again in the debate today from Senator Cook and Senator Maguire trying to create the perception of false differences between the Government and the Opposition as regards tariff policies, and I will deal with that in detail in a few moments. But the Government refuses to recognise that young people are the future of this country and they are being destroyed by this Government's foolish and thoughtless policies. They are the cruel victims of a pea and thimble trick.

The 11 per cent, of course, is a national average and, as I indicated, the problem in South Australia is much more severe than that, and will not be helped by the State Budget handed by Premier Bannon before he resigned, which simply increases the debt burden for South Australians to more than $5,000 a year for every individual living in the State—hardly an incentive for the creation of jobs by the business sector in South Australia.

The Keating Government intends to spend some $1.2 billion on employment schemes over the next two years—employment schemes that are essentially creating jobs out of thin air, paid with money the Government simply does not have and can only borrow. Of course, as a result of that we find a Budget deficit projected to be some $13.4 billion, which will no doubt blow out to be much greater than that.

At the same time, the interest on our debt will be increased by $2.6 billion over the next two years. Labor cannot seem to grasp the simple fact that it is the private sector, not the Government, that creates the real wealth and the jobs in this country, which in turn provide the taxes and revenue for the Government to use to administer essential services. Nor is it willing to undertake the desperately needed significant structural reform to our economy to create the circumstances in which the private sector can create that wealth and long term sustainable jobs—the concern of this matter of public importance.

Instead, as I said, we get irrelevant diversions—republicanism, the flag and, most recently, a fabricated difference between the Government and the Opposition about tariffs on motor vehicles, which has been the only issue raised in the debate this afternoon in response to our MPI by both Minister Cook and Senator Maguire. This attempt to create this perception of difference, above all, demonstrates the utter hypocrisy of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating.

When this Government came to office, motor vehicle tariffs stood at 57 1/2 per cent. In addition, there was a local content requirement and an effective tariff of 93 per cent as a result of quotas. That certainly equates to a tariff rate of at least 100 per cent if not more.

By 1998 tariffs under this Government's policy will be down to 15 per cent from that more than 100 per cent. That represents an 85 per cent or more reduction over a period of 15 years—5 2/3 per cent a year. Under the Liberal and National parties, by the year 2000 tariffs are intended to be 5 per cent on the motor vehicle industry. That represents a reduction of some 95 per cent over 17 years, which is just under 5 2/3per cent per year—exactly the same as the rate of reduction by the present Government.

The final difference in tariff rates of 10 per cent is absolutely negligible under a floating exchange rate, which this Government introduced some years ago, because the effect of the floating exchange rate from time to time could well more than offset that 10 per cent, and it has during the life of this Government when tariff reductions have occurred periodically with regard to the motor vehicle industry. We have seen the effect of those tariff reductions on the effective protection rate of the motor vehicle industry more than wiped out by the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. So that difference of 10 per cent is absolutely negligible.

But, more than that, under Labor, car manufacturers will not get the benefit of the substantial reductions in the cost of production, which it is widely recognised and accepted will be provided by the coalition's Fightback package. This includes the abolition of seven taxes, the most notable of which are the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the fuel excise. The abolition of those seven taxes represents lifting a burden of some $20 billion of tax off the backs of business. In addition, there will be a $10 billion saving in government spending. Why will this Government not negotiate with the State governments for the removal of payroll tax, which is a direct disincentive to employment?

Also of great importance is the fact that under Fightback we will ensure that the long overdue reforms to Australia's industrial relations system take place. This will ensure greatly improved productivity. It will also allow us, for example, to get things like the on-costs of employment down from their current level, which is in excess of 50 per cent, nearer to the New Zealand level of 17 per cent and thereby provide greater incentives for employment; but, most importantly, reduce the costs of production for industry generally and, most importantly in the context of the issue that we are discussing, the costs of production for the motor vehicle industry, which will much more than offset the minor differences in rates of tariff to apply between the Government and this Opposition.

But the Government is unwilling to take any of these initiatives which are so desperately needed to reform our economy and provide the basis for long term sustainable jobs. Instead, the Government chooses to demonstrate its hypocrisy on tariffs, as I have just indicated. More than just this attempt to create the perception of difference on tariffs, let us have a look at what the Prime Minister said only a couple of years ago on this very tariff issue when he was the Treasurer.

Remember in May 1990 when he accused the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, of dragging the chain on tariff reform? According to the then Treasurer Keating, Senator Button was dragging the chain. He accused Senator Button of wanting to do private deals with the car companies and other clients of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce about future levels of protection. More specifically, on 14 May, Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button is on record as saying that tariffs should be cut. I applaud him for that. But he does not want to cut them as much as I do. He did not want to cut them as much as I wanted them cut, and had them cut, in 1987.

This is the then Treasurer, the now Prime Minister, who is trying to create this false perception about the difference between the Government and the Opposition over tariff cuts then condemning his own ministerial colleague for dragging the chain on tariff cuts. What utter cant and hypocrisy!

PARA.TAB: We have also heard Senator Button in the last couple of days in relation to this issue raise the matter of export facilitation and how important this is to the Australian car industry, its retention of jobs and its continued survival in Australia. The bottom line with regard to export facilitation is that the Australian car buyer, the Australian consumer, is providing a subsidy for overseas car buyers to buy Australian cars and Australian motor vehicle parts. That is the bottom line as a result of the tariff mechanism and the export facilitation program that relates to it. The effect of that is that cars can be sold cheaper overseas because Australian car buyers pay a higher price than they otherwise would have to. Thereby, Australian consumers, who can ill-afford to do so in the present recession, are subsidising overseas car buyers who are probably in better economic circumstances than are many Australians to buy those vehicles.
