Many people have raised with me the question of why a Ford Capri can be sold cheaper in the United States than in Australia. It is directly as a result of that export facilitation under the tariff mechanism that ensures that Australian car buyers subsidise overseas car buyers. How ridiculous is that, that we are paying the penalty for selling cars overseas! It stands to reason that, if the industry needs a high tariff to survive in Australia but can still be sold overseas, there is that strong subsidy element.

In 1987, it was estimated that for every motor vehicle sold overseas under export facilitation, the Australian consumer was subsidising to the extent of $10,000 per vehicle or, in total, as was then expected with 40,000 units to be exported, a total of $400m. That means that $400m of Australia's wealth is being exported overseas—given to overseas residents rather than Australians. So it is a nonsense for the Government to postulate this strong difference between the two parties on tariff protection.

SPEECH.PARA: We really need the Fightback package, which will ensure that industry remains competitive. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in this debate, because the point made right at the end of his speech by Senator Chapman was a very relevant point. He asserts that there is no difference, in fact, between the two major political parties on the questions of tariff reform and internationalisation of this economy.
—He's right.

—That is what he says and Senator Sowada—of course, from the viewpoint of the Democrats—says there is no difference. I assert that there is a difference. If one looks at everything in black and white in politics, one could look at this issue and say, yes both parties are the same. They both approve of a reduction in tariffs and they both approve of the internationalisation of the Australian economy. They approve of restructuring of various infrastructure arrangements in Australia, such as the waterfront, the airlines, et cetera. But the matter really is one of degree.

PARA.TAB: There is a difference between those who say yes, we should have tariff reform, but a reasonable tariff reform which takes into account the fact that changes to any major economy will come about gradually. They involve a change in the ethos of a particular society; a change in work practice; a change in attitudes; and a change in the entrepreneurial instincts which may or may not be present in a particular society. It will not happen overnight.

Most of the countries where major restructuring changes have been forced on an economy by the government of the day have proved to be dismal failures. Look at the Thatcher experiment. It is true that she did, in fact, offer a genuine alternative to the British people. She went out of her way to restructure British society and she left in her wake large pools of unemployed and an economically and politically disenfranchised northern sector of Great Britain—certainly the Scottish area. In fact, inflation was at a higher rate than ours and there were extreme difficulties with the British economy.

America is the same. George Bush is close to being defeated as President of the United States, not because of his foreign policy or the fact that he himself appears to be an unacceptable individual to the American public, but because the American public is saying loudly and clearly at the moment that the great experiment of the Reagan years, Reaganomics, and Bushenomics—if I can call it that; or perhaps it is more beating around the bush—has failed. Unlike Senator Chapman, the Americans are saying, `Okay, we may get relatively cheap cars from abroad'. It is not just the Capri which is being sold there more cheaply; one can buy a 164 Alfa Romeo in America for about $32,000 and in Australia the same car costs about $60,000—and I am talking in Australian dollars.

All cars are cheaper in America, but the problem in America is that the consequence of that type of `consumer first' approach has been the creation of a wasteland in Detroit and in all the car manufacturing areas of the United States. There has been complete and utter destruction of the American car industry, one of the great linchpins of the American economy. What has happened is that the consumer may have benefited slightly in the US, but the workers in those northern industrial states have not benefited at all. I believe that the rise in crime rate in the US and the absolute factionalising of the politics there is a direct result of some of the policies practised by Bush and Reagan over the last 10 years.

Like a lot of the policies which have been practised or accepted here, those policies have been driven by classic economic theorists who believe that internationalisation means destruction of base industries. If a country's base industries are destroyed, then it has nothing to go on because very few countries can be service trading nations on their own account. All economies must be a mixture which involves having an industrial base, a service base and other bases attached to it. This complexity enables a country to survive changes in world markets. That is the nature of world trade; it is not putting all your eggs in one basket.

Unfortunately, the theorists who, I believe, have influenced the Keating viewpoint over the years, and very strongly influenced the Hewson viewpoint, have in fact had too much sway not only in the bureaucracy here, but especially in the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is incredible.

—It is incredible, because we as politicians have sat here year after year and accepted the views of these dry economic rationalists and economic theorists, many of whom have never been outside the finance sector in their lives; who have gone through the same sorts of training grounds in the University of Sydney economics department or getting MBAs from Harvard. I ask Senator Bjelke-Petersen, what would they know about running a farm, putting their job on the line every day, letting the elements of the weather or world markets decide whether they are viable or not? What do they know when they talk about subsidies being bad? They would not have the faintest idea, because most of them have never run a business on their own in their life.
—What about your side? You are all union members or ALP workers.

—Senator Macdonald says that we are all union members here; we are all ex-organisers for trade unions. That is not the case. He should have a look at the statistics for this place. We are in fact a pretty fair representation of ex-small business people, teachers, lawyers and small businessmen of all kinds. It is a very unusual mixture.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that it is about time that politicians started running the agenda instead of being run by these economic theorists, who could be instantly categorised as being between 35 to 45 years of age, primarily from the finance sector and educated in classic economic theory, but with no idea of how the real world works.

Those opposite quite rightly ask what is happening to small business in this country under the rule or the regime of these dry economist rationalists who have prevailed on both sides of politics. I will tell them what has happened. Small business has not got off the ground because small business relies upon government support; it relies upon government cutting out those stupid bureaucratic procedures which stand in the way of organising a small business; and upon government actually going into the small business area and saying, `How do we form clusters of small businesses attached to big businesses, so that all of them grow together?' Each can give its own expertise to the other. The big businesses can give marketing and prestige to the small ones who may have the ideas. That is the way to build up small industry.

I have not heard Professor Dr John Hewson talk about that. I have not heard the dry economic bureaucrats talk about that approach. It is happening in some areas under Senator Button. He is one of the few around this place who has actually sat down and looked at what makes industry grow and survive. Obviously, Senator Button has said to himself and his bureaucrats, and in discussions with people who count in this area, `The Australian car industry is in great difficulty. How do we make it survive and make it internationally competitive?' That is a reasonable question to ask.

The Liberal Party has come in here with simplistic solutions, often at odds with its National Party counterpart, and said that all we need to do is drop tariffs almost to zero, deregulate the labour market, bring in lower wages for young people, maintain the British flag in the left-hand corner of the Australian flag, destroy the unions—that is really its agenda—and throw the balance of power and influence in the community towards business people rather than unions. That is its simplistic view about how to get the Australian economy going again.

But that is not the way to do it. As I said, the way to do it is to start rebuilding the base: get big industry working with small industry; get people thinking internationally; and ensure that the current protections on Australian industry are not destroyed in the vain hope that market hopes will generate new jobs and new industries elsewhere.

What happened to the 30,000 or so people who have gone out of the textile, clothing and footwear industry in this country? I bet that they are not sitting in new jobs around the place. Under the Dr Hewson policy, those people would be thrown on the scrap heap permanently. There would be pockets of unemployment and degraded industry all around this country. Some areas, such as the financial centres, would do well. Sydney people would probably do fairly well, except for the small manufacturers or businessmen in the western suburbs.

Dr Hewson's view is the view basically of a financier. He is not a farmer, a small businessman or someone who is selling a service to the community that will grow and employ people. Dr Hewson is a man who has lived fairly well over the years from the finance sector. The finance sector is but one part of a total complex of an economy. He has come out of one section and brought his prejudices and academic, classic economic theories to the Liberal Party.

Dr Hewson has not always held these views. If these were the views of Dr Hewson and they had been systematically worked through over the years, I could understand. But Gerard Henderson was perfectly correct to say in his article in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday that Dr Hewson has not always held these theories. Just listen to this:

SPEECH.PARA: In February 1985 in his column in Business Review Weekly Hewson came out in support of the ALP-ACTU Accord maintaining that "the economic Achilles heel of the Fraser Government was its failure to develop a viable and relevant income and wages policy of that [i.e. Accord] sort". In May 1986 he advised Howard that his (modest) industrial relations policy was "too confrontationist" and "could therefore be counter-productive" and suggested that the Liberal Party should not "pin all of its hopes on labour market deregulation".
That is the Dr Hewson of 1985. His is a considered opinion in the Business Review Weekly when writing for the type of businessman that he is now abusing quite roundly today. That is his view there.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson was right then because the accord is the greatest achievement of this Government. It has been, and probably still is, its greatest achievement and will be in the future. What is more, we have gone through difficult times and not caused the social dislocation that is now occurring in the United Kingdom and the USA. I return to the article. According to Gerard Henderson:

These days Hewson is unshakeable in his belief that a 15 per cent GST is an essential part of the Fightback! package which alone can restore the Australian economy. Yet, even here, it was not always so—

SPEECH.PARA: in Dr Hewson's mind. He continues:

In April 1990 Hewson criticised those whom he maintained believed that "a consumption tax is the saviour of the Western world". Interviewed by the Herald's Mike Steketee he also queried whether a GST would have any significant effect on savings.

That is Dr Hewson in his more reflective moments, before the smell of power got into his nostrils, before the fear of other people criticising him became a very important part of his psyche and before he decided that he needed to attack the people who produce the jobs in this community—the car industry, the BHPs and the people who underpin our industrial situation.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson is touchy about these people when they criticise him and say, `You cannot destroy an industry and hope that things will just automatically improve. Fightback will not save the Australian car industry; it is destroying a major industry which has increased its exports three times since 1984'. When they criticise him for attacking them and causing them problems, what is his response? He says, `You are just dinosaurs'. He gets very personally aggressive towards those people who in good faith had hoped for better things from a Liberal government. I know that the National Party does not share those views, and that is the tragedy of this whole economic debate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Preliminary Advice on Planning for the 1993-95 Triennium

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The document before the Senate is the preliminary advice of the HEC on planning for the 1993-95 triennium, in which we find that the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council is offering advice that we believe has a great deal of merit. The HEC and NBEET are trying to tell the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley)
what the Opposition has been trying to tell the Government for quite some time.

PARA.TAB: The HEC makes several observations and basically comes up with the not too astounding fact that the rapid increase in demand for higher education services over the next three years will place a great deal of strain on the higher education system unless extra money is obtained. It then goes on to advise that the solution is more money for the sector and that this money has to be provided by the Government or by the higher education institutions being given the freedom to raise extra funds themselves.

This is precisely what the Opposition has been trying to get the Government to see. It is the exact philosophy of the Opposition's Fightback package. The advice notes that retention rates for 1991 students in year 12 have increased nationally to 71 per cent from 64 per cent last year. The extent of this growth was not predicted and therefore has not been taken into consideration in calculating the current triennium funding. If the transfer rate from year 12 to higher education is to remain stable—currently at 42 per cent—additional growth will be needed.

In terms of applications, the data from State admissions centres reveals that unmet demand is at the highest levels ever. Fifty thousand eligible students are now unable to find a place in higher education. The advice continues by saying that it is possible to argue that some of these students may be better matched with courses in TAFE. But it is very doubtful that TAFE could absorb these numbers, especially given that the TAFE area reports significant unmet demand of its own—that is, 150,000 students wanting to get into a TAFE course.

The report also points out that opportunity for access by the mature age groups has suffered as demand for places by school leavers has risen. Several States have reported that demand for places by mature age students was higher than for year 12 places in 1992. New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland have all had approximately a third more additional mature age applications than year 12 applications.

Meanwhile the number of mature aged entrants nationally has dropped from 55.7 per cent of undergraduates commencing to 47.3 per cent over the last seven years. Now that the Higher Education Council has established what we already knew about the lack of places in higher education and the increasing demand for such places, it goes on to make the profound observation that the solution is increased funding. It then gives these two options:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council therefore sees only two main options available for increasing the funds allocated to higher education:
.more Commonwealth funds to permit the growth; and
. enabling the higher education system to generate some of its own funding.
The Council plans to establish a working party in 1992 to look at options for financing growth in higher education.

On the second option the HEC notes that, although it is government policy to exclude fees for undergraduate studies, it is questionable whether it should extend to everybody at every level of award and under all circumstances.

It is pleasing to note that a body set up by this Government has finally become familiar enough with the higher education sector finally to agree with what the Opposition has been trying to tell the Government. The education policy of Fightback addresses the urgent demands of the crisis in our higher education institutions. We will give back to the universities the right to accept Australian fee paying students.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address one aspect of the Automotive Industry Authority annual report. The automotive industry has been the subject of much heated debate and discussion. Most of this debate surrounds the fairly simplistic attitude which the Opposition has adopted towards the car industry by promising zero tariff cuts if it were elected to government.

PARA.TAB: Mr McLachlan's attack on the car industry betrays ignorance, I submit, of the real world. Zero tariff cuts, it is now well and truly on record, would kill off the Australian car industry. In turn, this would have serious repercussions throughout the Australian manufacturing industry because the car industry is a major user of products manufactured by other industries. Figures show that, apart from automotive equipment makers employing 30,000 workers and its own work force in the assembly plants of 26,000, the car industry takes a substantial slice of the output produced by industries employing a further 80,000 workers.

I give some examples: non-ferrous diecasting 40 per cent; fasteners 23 per cent; plastic mouldings 10 per cent; tool and die 67 per cent; machine tools 60 per cent; ferrous foundries 12 per cent; glass 8 per cent; industrial paint 10 per cent; and steel 8 per cent.

However, the Opposition is not the only party guilty of a tariff cutting frenzy. The Government's current aim under the car industry plan is to reduce tariffs on passenger motor vehicles to 15 per cent by the year 2000. This annual report states that to survive under such a tariff regime by the year 2000 will require `further significant changes' to be made because the automotive industry's productivity `remains low by world standards'.

However, the report does not go on to detail just how this additional productivity margin could be achieved. It is fairly clear that one of the reasons may be low production runs, but there may be others. There may be standards of safety, environmental protection and corporate behaviour which we in Australia enforce which our competitors in other countries disregard. I think we need to be quite clear that we have a choice. Certainly, the Opposition appears to be prepared to disregard such standards, to let our standards drop to a world low. Alternatively, we must be prepared to consider employing whatever measures are needed to maintain not only our living standards but the standards of our industries. We must consider that our industries are handicapped by distance, by the size of our market—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Democrats.

—The Opposition should look at its own handicaps. It is trying to reduce the tariffs for the car industry to zero and is obviously quite indifferent to its future. But there are other measures that should be taken in this situation. At a recent presentation by the Ford Motor Company of Australia Ltd, the company's President, Mr Jac Nasser, hinted that Australia should follow the lead of most key auto manufacturing countries and introduce quotas on the import of vehicles.

PARA.TAB: This is supported by the findings of the tariff inquiry which I am currently chairing. It is an independent parliamentary inquiry which, I might add, was opposed by both other parties, which did not even want to know the facts. Yet at this inquiry the evidence shows that there are two major trends. The first is that tariff cuts are producing a substantial increase in imports and, as a result, factory closures and loss of jobs. The second is that the promised savings of micro-economic reform are lagging far behind tariff cuts. What we need is a pause in tariff cuts to develop a more interventionist economic strategy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, want to say a few words on the 1991-92 annual report of the Automotive Industry Authority. The report outlines briefly the role of the Authority and the work that it has been doing in the last 12 months. I do not want to go into full detail on the report, other than to draw particular attention to what I think is one of the most important statements in the report, on page 4 under the heading, `Performance Indicators', where the Authority talks about the progress that has been made within the industry towards achieving greater international competitiveness in the motor vehicle industry, and pointing out the good things that have been done. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: While these are substantial achievements for the industry and a positive reflection of the Government's policy, they are not a cause for complacency. The industry's productivity remains low by world standards and further . . . changes will be necessary if the industry is to survive at a tariff level of 15 per cent by 2000.

It is in relation to that point, the productivity of the industry, that the coalition has been addressing its attention and all its activities in the preparation and future implementation of the Fightback proposals, which are designed specifically to help industries like the car industry to achieve the objectives that we all want for that industry. Those objectives are to have a vibrant, growing car industry in Australia as part of a vibrant, growing manufacturing sector. There is no dispute about that at all. The question is: how does one achieve it?

PARA.TAB: The debate about how to achieve it and what is in the best interests of the industry, what is in the best interests of the manufacturing sector in Australia and what is in the best interests of the Australian consumer is not being helped one iota by what can only be described as the lies being peddled by the Government and the Democrats in this whole debate. Let me take up one point of Senator Spindler's.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like Senator Short to withdraw the word `lies'. I believe it is unparliamentary.

—I do not believe that Senator Short was referring to you, Senator Spindler, as being a liar. He was talking about the peddling of lies by two different parties and I think that is a little different.

—One of the chief lies that is being peddled by both parties, both the Government and the Democrats, is that the coalition's policy is for zero tariffs by the year 2000. That is not true. The coalition's policy is for negligible tariffs in the year 2000, which we have stated categorically is 5 per cent. What we are saying—this is where we differ from the Government—is that to get tariffs down we have to take costs off the back of business, off the back of manufacturers. We have to allow them to grow and be more efficient and more productive. That is why all of the coalition's policy proposals for industry, including in particular for the motor vehicle industry, are to get those costs down. That is why we will abolish wholesale sales tax. That is why we will abolish payroll tax. That is why we will abolish fuel excise tax, and the training guarantee levy, and freeze the superannuation levy. All of those things will get the costs of producing goods and services down massively.

PARA.TAB: All of those measures will occur in 1994 before the slight—compared with the Government's—acceleration of our tariff reductions takes place. The benefits of those cost reductions, the efficiencies flowing through industrial relations reform and in all those other ways, will swamp the difference between a 5 per cent tariff and a 15 per cent tariff by the year 2000.

The car industry itself has admitted that, on all the figuring, up to at least the year 1996 it will be far better off in terms of costs and opportunity to compete under the coalition's Fightback policy than under the Government's existing plan. What we are talking about is a matter at the margin. The overall benefits for the car industry from the Fightback proposal are overwhelming. (Time expired)

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Before I call Senator Parer, on behalf of Senator Calvert, who was the previous occupant of the Chair, I acknowledge the presence in the gallery of former Senator Messner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this motion because I want to counter some of the remarks made by Senator Spindler, who takes a most simplistic view. As my colleague Senator Short has said, the coalition has said that we will have negligible tariffs by the year 2000, but in conjunction with the removal of a whole lot of expenses that the industry now has to put up with—payroll tax, the fuel excise levy, the wholesale sales tax and so on. Senator Spindler is saying that there is some massive difference between the Australian Labor Party's 15 per cent tariff and the negligible tariffs of the coalition.
—They are both bad.

—He says they are both bad, as though if somehow tariffs are increased the motor car industry will be fixed. The Automotive Industry Authority annual report says quite categorically that productivity remains low by world standards and that significant changes will be necessary. That is what we are addressing. We are addressing the structural changes that are absolutely vital if we are to have a significant motor car industry. If the Fightback package is implemented, we will.

PARA.TAB: Let me just tell Senator Spindler where his magical answer comes unstuck. About 10 years ago, the exchange rate was such that one Australian dollar bought $US1.49 and 440 yen. From that time to the present, the dollar has decreased in value to buy US72c, which is equivalent to a 100 per cent tariff, and will now buy 88 yen, equivalent to something like a 300 per cent tariff. The question has been asked: `Why aren't we booming?'. That is not the solution. Senator Spindler has taken a simplistic, populist approach, as the Democrats always do, and of course the Labor Party has run down this track speaking with a forked tongue.

The only way to address not only the motor car industry but also every industry in this country—if we are to revitalise our industries to increase our exports, to have more import replacement and thus employ more people—is to address the structural problem. If Senator Spindler can see anything wrong with that logic, I challenge him to get up and say it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will destroy it before you have a chance to do anything.

—The Democrats want all the cars off the roads! Senator Spindler is worrying about the motor vehicle industry, but he wants all the cars off the road! He wants to increase the fuel excise levy by 16c a litre. He wants everyone to be like Fred Flintstone, peddling around on bikes, and he gets up here with this feigned concern about the motor car industry. Some people would say it was hypocrisy; others would say it was fairies at the bottom of the garden. I choose the latter.

PARA.TAB: We must address the structural problems. There are no magical cures. It has been going on for too long. The Fightback plan will remove $20 billion from the backs of business. It will not pay these taxes it has been paying up till now. The reforming of industrial relations is critical to the Fightback plan. In fact, it is probably the centrepiece of the plan, because we must have a situation where the employees of every organisation take the view that their success depends on the success of the company for which they work or that they will fail if the company for which they work fails. That approach is incorporated in Fightback under the enterprise based agreements. It is not the phoney enterprise based agreements of the Labor Party which will produce thousands of identical agreements which it will call enterprise based but which will not be done by the employees and their employers. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the preface by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to this document states, this is the first strategic document to be publicly released. The Minister lauds this as an example of Labor's commitment to open government. Indeed, if that were true, it would of course be welcome. However, to release a document which is 2 1/2 years old and which contains nothing we did not already know from other government statements can only be described as opening the gate after the horse has bolted.

PARA.TAB: This document really shows its age. It refers frequently to the Soviet Union, addresses in some detail the future of United States bases in the Philippines, and considers whether or not Australia should contribute to future peacekeeping operations in Cambodia. It is an insult to this chamber and to the public to parade this release as a blow for democracy. One hopes that the next version is released while it is still relevant. The overwhelming impression one gains from reading Australia's Strategic Planning in the 1990s is that the Minister and his Department are struggling to justify the huge sums of taxpayers' money being poured into armaments expenditure.

This report acknowledges that Australia's geostrategic position is unique, which on the whole works to our strategic advantage. It acknowledges that Indonesia is not a threat to us. It assesses that the security environment in South East Asia is generally improving. The paper also admits that the domestic instability in South Pacific island states will not of itself change the regional strategic equation, that the Soviet Union, as it was then, was adopting a more cooperative stance, that there are limits to India's naval expansion, that Japan's military posture is most unlikely to change radically and that China's preoccupations will remain internal.

It goes on to conclude that regional countries lack the capabilities to launch a major assault on Australia and are not planning to acquire them. If this document were to be written today, some of these assessments would remain the same and others would be even more favourable. Not one would indicate a deterioration since 1989, when this paper was actually written. The fact is that fundamental improvements in the political cohesion of our region are under way. It is astounding, therefore, that the tables in this document which show the evolution of our military forces from 1983 to the mid to late 1990s indicate no fundamental change in posture.

What is lacking in this assessment, and in the policies of the Government and the Opposition in general, is any serious acknowledgment that Australia faces a variety of security threats, none of which are simplistically military in nature. Our conflict with the United States over export subsidies is a case in point. Our unemployment crisis is another. Land degradation and the greenhouse effect are further examples of serious security challenges for which military solutions do not exist and are totally irrelevant.

Surely it is time that we started to ask ourselves whether pumping $10 billion each year into military operations and construction programs is a rational allocation of our limited security resources. There are real threats which have yet to be effectively addressed, yet we are pouring vast sums into solutions to a problem which does not exist. The Australian public has for years been conned into believing that we are vulnerable and defenceless. In recent years the scales have begun to fall from their collective eyes. Sooner or later the voting public will demand a peace dividend or, more accurately, a security dividend. This document suggests that the Government and the Defence Department will be caught flat-footed, but the Australian Democrats will continue to push for a reduction of at least 10 per cent in the Defence budget of this nation and for the application of these funds to address our real needs and our real threats to security.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

LOAN BILL 1992

This Bill is a machinery financing measure to enable certain defence expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund and to supplement the moneys available to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Successive Governments have adopted the practice of introducing a Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to meet expenditures that have been appropriated by the Parliament, but for which insufficient funds are available in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Legally, expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed the moneys available to that Fund.

The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective 1992-93 Budget deficit. The Budget deficit in prospect for 1992-93 gives rise to a deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund some $6 billion greater than the Budget deficit. This situation arises because appropriations from the Fund include various items that are classified as financing transactions rather than Budget outlays, and thus do not affect the Budget outcome. These items include payments to the National Debt Sinking Fund and superannuation payments made by the Commonwealth on behalf of public trading enterprises.

The Bill provides authority for the loan fund to meet defence expenditures incurred after the passage of the Bill that otherwise would have been met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and to supplement the Consolidated Revenue Fund so that it can meet its other commitments. The Bill also provides the borrowing authority to cover these payments from the Loan Fund. The Bill does not authorise expenditures additional to those already appropriated, or currently before the Parliament, apart from loan raising expenses, which will be small.

I emphasise that the Bill does not in any way impinge upon the prerogative of the Parliament to appropriate public moneys, but simply provides the means to finance expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: SWIMMING POOLS TAX REFUND BILL 1992
Mr President, this Bill deals with one of the measures relating to sales tax on swimming pools announced by the Treasurer in his Budget speech.
It will ensure that refunds of amounts paid as sales tax on swimming pools constructed in situ since 1986 are passed through to pool purchasers.
In February of this year the High Court of Australia found amendments made by the Parliament in 1986 in relation to these pools to be of no effect.
The Court ruled that the amendments do not conform with a requirement in section 55 of the Constitution that laws imposing duties of excise deal with duties of excise only.
The purpose of the amendments was to overcome an anomaly in the sales tax law that some pools were subject to tax while others were exempt.

An unfortunate effect of the decision, however, is that pool builders, who were able to pass on to purchasers any amounts payable to the Commissioner of Taxation as sales tax on in situ swimming pools, may have been able to get the benefit of refunds payable by the Commonwealth as windfall gains.

This Bill will ensure, in line with the refund code in the sales tax law, that there are no windfall gains and any refunds paid by the Commonwealth as a result of the Court's decision go to the person who actually bore the `tax'.

The effect of this Bill is not to deny the Commonwealth's liability to refund amounts paid as sales tax on in situ swimming pools, but rather to place a condition on the eligibility of a pool builder to a refund by requiring that, if the amount paid as sales tax was passed on to the purchaser, the refund must also be passed on.

Importantly, Mr President, the Bill will also provide for the payment of interest to pool builders as compensation for any period that they are out of pocket as a result of the decision and these amendments.
The proposed changes are not expected to have any direct impact on revenue because an estimate of the refunds has already been included in the base line estimates.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (EXCISE) BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (GENERAL) BILL 1992SALES TAX AMENDMENT (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1992SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was talking about these sales tax Bills and the way in which this Government had cobbled together this legislation over two years to try to make some sense out of the wholesale sales tax scheme, yet had not bothered to consult the major people within industry who are affected by such extensions of wholesale sales tax. I want to go on and say that all the accumulated rulings that have gathered upon the existing sales tax laws simply become obsolete and a new range of uncertainties result, which is causing great concern to businesses at a time when they are trying to keep their heads above water and retain the jobs that presently exist.

PARA.TAB: It is the very nature of sales tax, whether it is multiple rates or multiple exemptions, that recourse must continually be had to administrative and legal intervention. If this Government had any courage at all it would abolish the wholesale sales tax system and put in place a very simple system that cannot be evaded and that will be fairer right across the board. Mr Fernstone has now expressed the concern that private rulings obtained under the new legislation may only apply very specifically to the person addressed, although business practice now dictates that traders rely on rulings concerning identical or similar goods.

The retail industries also made it clear to the Committee that a manufacturer, under proposed new section 77 of this legislation, could obtain an exempt classification for a product and then have 20 or 30 distributors around Australia required to obtain similar rulings. Once again, why on earth will this Government not take the simple action of abolishing this iniquitous tax—this highly complicated, unfair tax system—and replace it with a fair tax system?

One of the interesting things about a goods and services tax that has been repeated time and time again by those who live under it—and as recently as about a month ago in New Zealand by people from the trade union movement, the teaching profession, the aged, large industries, small industries, small business and retailing—is that a goods and services tax is a fair tax because it cannot be avoided. There was not one person in New Zealand out of all those groups that I just mentioned—and I remind the Senate that I did include the trade union movement, the teachers and the aged—who would prefer to go back to pre-GST days.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about in Canada?

—I can always rely on Senator West to pipe up with a little gem that I can really linch on to. Senator West is still as ill-informed as she was prior to the release of the Fightback package because she has not read it. She does not know the difference between Fightback and the goods and services tax that we are proposing in Australia as opposed to the Canadian system. If she had bothered to read Fightback! or if she had bothered to do any research into the Canadian system, she would know that the Canadian system is entirely different and that the problems with it of multiple rates and multiple exemptions are not part of Fightback.

PARA.TAB: I can always rely on Senator West to put in a loopy comment right on cue. Senator West would much prefer to go ahead with a crazy system of wholesale sales tax that is cascading throughout the system. Senator West would much prefer to have farmers pay an extra 26c a litre on their fuel. Senator West would also much prefer to have private motorists pay 19c a litre extra on their fuel than they already do.As I said, I can always rely on Senator West for the most idiotic interjection that enables me to prove the point that this Labor Government and its senators and members do not have the faintest idea of what is contained in Fightback. They do not have the faintest idea of the difference between the goods and services tax that we are proposing as opposed to the Canadian system or the value added tax in the United Kingdom. I thank Senator West for that because it gave me an opportunity to explain the difference.

The retail industry is particularly concerned about these changes that the Government is promoting. The possibility was also raised in the Committee that made the Government change its position on this legislation that one distributor might obtain an exemption while another faces the competitive disadvantages of a 20 per cent tax. These are the inevitable consequences of persevering with the present system of sales tax and the wholesale sales tax, which presumably this Government is just going to cling on to and claw on to until it is put out of its misery at the next election.

It is all very well for officials of the Australian Taxation Office to state in perfectly good faith that it is purely an administrative problem. I concur with the concerns expressed by my colleague Senator Watson on 12 August when he said that if it goes to a court of law, the court will uphold the exact words of the new legislative changes. This Labor Government always forgets that we are dealing not with discretionary rules but with laws that this Parliament has a deep responsibility to consider as they stand, not simply as how we may be told they will be interpreted. You can bet London to a brick that the way in which they are interpreted will be against the individual and against the businesses.

If we have an uncomplicated system where the interpretation is crystal-clear as to what it is designed to do, and the way in which it will be interpreted by law, we cannot make a mistake. Everyone knows the rules. That is not the way the wholesale sales tax system operates. It is certainly not the way it will operate in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —What non-prescription pharmaceuticals will be zero rated?
—I realise that Senator Walsh is interjecting out of his seat, but I will answer that interjection. All prescription drugs—
—Non-prescription!

—All prescription drugs will be zero rated and all the non-prescription drugs, for the information of Senator West, who is impatient once again, will have all the wholesale sales tax taken off and all the tax taken off throughout the manufacture of that drug. This means that it will not cost the same as it costs to produce today, but Senator West is not bright enough to realise that.

PARA.TAB: This is another little furphy which the Government spread about last week. There was the furphy that wheelchairs would be taxed. I categorically state that they will not be taxed. The Government said last week that artificial limbs will be taxed. They will not be taxed. All of these things are zero rated. One of the lies that we will get throughout this campaign is that health will cost 15 per cent more. There is no goods and services tax applied to health; there is no goods and services tax applied to prescription drugs; there is no goods and services tax applied to wheelchairs and all those sorts of things. At the moment, what a doctor is confronted with—

TALK.START.PARA: —Truly, it is like sitting in the middle of an aviary with Senator West over there. What we are confronted with at the moment and what doctors are faced with at the moment is that every single, solitary business input that they have has a wholesale sales tax on it. If they want to buy a stethoscope, it has a wholesale sales tax on it. Non-refundable. Under us, it will have a goods and services tax on it, but they will get every single, solitary cent back on it.

PARA.TAB: At the moment doctors have to pay a wholesale sales tax on examination couches and visitors chairs. That cost is passed on to the patient. Under a coalition government they will get back all of the goods and services taxes that they pay and they will not pass on that cost to the patient. Unfortunately, Government senators such as Senator West are not bright enough to be able to comprehend all of that. I confess that it is complex. But I just wish that people would stop going round misrepresenting the position.

This Government is extending its tentacles further and further into the goods and services area. As I mentioned prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, it is absurd for this Labor Government to suggest that it does not have a services tax at the moment. It is absurd for it to attack the concept of a goods and services tax because it is actually placing a tax on services through its own legislation.

The very legislation that we are debating today seeks to tax a service. It singles out a particular innovative service that is essential to competitive manufacturing. This Government is seeking to apply a 20 per cent tax to external design work in the development of a product. That is what I was talking about prior to lunch. We are talking about a service. Business will have to pass on this non-refundable tax to the consumer. All of this will add to the cost of the product. This Government has slammed on another tax. It has extended this tax to the service area. The big difference between this extension of sales tax and a goods and services tax is that the Opposition proposes not only that the goods and services tax be applied evenly but also that it be applied fairly and that business be able to claim back every cent so that this cost does not have to be passed on to customers.

This legislation also deals with other taxes. Senator Button said prior to lunch that there is no tax on food. The Government is crying crocodile tears over the little piece of legislation that is now before us—legislation which proposes an increase in the tax on containers for take away food. If that is not part of a tax on food, what is? This tax is to be built into the cost of buying food. Unfortunately, low income people generally consume more take away food. That is another area of concern that should be addressed at another time in another debate. We need to examine why low income people are consuming more take away food.

This Government proposes in this legislation to extend sales tax to take away food. It proposes to increase the tax on food containers from 10 to 20 per cent. This means that an extra $61m will be taken from the taxpayers. That $61m increase in tax will be paid by guess who? It will be paid by the consumer. So it is hypocritical of anybody to suggest that there is no tax on food at present. We know that in many cases food itself is taxed. However, food containers as well as transport, manufacture and production are taxed. Under the Fightback package none of them will be taxed.

It is about time that this Government understood that it is exacerbating a problem. With every stroke of the pen, taxation compliance costs are being pushed even higher. The Government increases the compliance cost to business without any regard whatsoever for the job implications.

Let me give some further classic examples. Sensors and thermostats for electrical appliance will lose their exempt status and are going to be taxed at 20 per cent. Plastic and rubber sheeting will lose their exemption. Hot water tanks are going to be taxed for the first time and are to lose their exemption. This Government, which cries crocodile tears, is extending and extending taxes. How dare the Government do that when it knows and understands that all of this will cost the consumers more.

As Senator Bishop said earlier this morning, there will not be just a 20 per cent increase in wholesale sales tax because the 20 per cent is put on before the product is marked up for resale. So the real increase could end up being about 28 per cent. Of course, a number of people would not understand that because they have never been in business. They have never been in the wholesale business; they have never been in the retail business. Therefore, one can understand why they do not understand these things. Nonetheless, these people will go around and spread untruths.

Just what has the Treasurer got against all of these industries, including the take away food industry? Under the time honoured absurd discrimination which is characteristic of sales tax, a container used for microwave hamburgers sold by a wholesaler is exempt but someone who makes a hamburger and then buys a container has to meet the 20 per cent sales tax.

Therein lies a number of the reasons why we will abolish the wholesale sales tax. It is full of anomalies, it is unfair and in a lot of instances the burden is quite clearly forced on lower income earners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad to have the opportunity to speak in this debate on the Government's proposed simplification of sales tax. I have an opportunity to do what I promised to do when I first came into this chamber, and that is to bring to the attention of the Senate some of the concerns that people have about sales tax in general.

PARA.TAB: The proposed simplification is not really a simplification at all. If a caring government had bothered to consult with the people and the businesses concerned, as it promised to do, it would know that there is nothing simple about sales tax Bills. Of course, there is only one way really to simplify sales tax legislation and that is to get rid of wholesale sales tax completely. If that had happened, we would have been able to avoid some of the confusion and anger which the introduction of this sales tax legislation has caused, particularly in a lot of areas of rural South Australia where people were not aware of the ramifications. This Government promised that it would consult with business and individuals before making any changes to the legislation. What a hollow promise that turned out to be.

My special concern has always been the effect that this tax would have on rural areas and, in this instance, the farm machinery dealers in rural Australia. I can state categorically that they were not consulted about any of the changes that they believed might affect them.

If the Government had succeeded in rushing the sales tax Bills through before the winter break, I and many others would not have had time to consider any of the implications of the proposed changes. But thank goodness we did have time. My office has been inundated with telephone calls, letters and faxes from concerned and confused farm machinery dealers in rural and regional South Australia. These dealers are not tax experts; they never have been. All they know is that they were selling agricultural machinery and spare parts to primary producers who were tax exempt. For all of this time they have been exempt from paying tax.

Dealers have been exempt from paying tax on items that they buy. As Senator Short has already pointed out, the machinery they stock is sometimes worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. If dealers had been forced to pay sales tax and then wait until the stock had been sold before claiming a refund, this would have spelt the end for many businesses. In fact, if dealers had had to pay sales tax all along, I am sure that many of them would never have opened their doors. Along with many other businesses, dealers cannot afford to have stock which sometimes sits around for an enormous length of time waiting to be sold to tax exempt producers.

Why should these dealers lose out, not only in terms of interest but also in terms of stock that they cannot afford to buy? After all, tens of thousands of dollars in sales tax on a single piece of machinery could translate into a very significant purchase of things such as spare parts.

As honourable senators would be well aware, because machinery dealers had not been consulted and informed of the changes to the sales tax laws, when they first heard of them they believed that they would have to pay an up-front sales tax of 20 per cent on their current stock, both large machinery and spare parts. I now understand from the Tax Office representatives that they did not believe machinery would have been affected—it was only spare parts under threat of a 20 per cent sales tax.

Furthermore, the Australian Tax Office, under pressure from the Federal coalition, the Tractor and Machinery Association of Australia and the Farm Machinery Dealers Association, subsequently gave an assurance that dealers would not have to pay sales tax. However, it should be noted that under the proposed `simplification' of the legislation, all the current arrangements with the Commissioner of Taxation for tax exempt status will cease to exist.
As a result of this, according to Arthur Anderson's submission to the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, taxpayers will have to reapply for rulings and:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . entrust that the Commissioner of Taxation will provide a satisfactory response within sufficient time for the taxpayer to be able to proceed under the new legislation with the commercial certainty which is important in its business operations.
Therefore, under section 84 it would be at the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation to decide whether or not a farm machinery dealer or dealers could be tax exempt.

PARA.TAB: This is quite obviously an unsatisfactory arrangement. When farm machinery dealers sell agricultural machinery exclusively for use by tax exempt primary producers, why does the Tax Commissioner need to make a ruling? Surely there is nothing more certain than that in most cases agricultural machinery dealers will be selling to exempt primary producers—they buy almost all of the harvesters and combine harvesters and other agricultural machinery that is handled by these dealers.

However, as I have stated, even this was not understood by the dealers' associations. There had been no consultation and no information was given to them, so they did not know where they stood under this new legislation. They were under the impression that the legislation would be amended so that dealers would have to pay sales tax of 20 per cent when buying machinery and spare parts, and then wait until the items were sold before claiming a refund from the Tax Office.

Confusion about the proposed changes has been the order of the day. Considering that many farm machinery dealers in South Australia, including in my area, hold stock worth up to a million dollars, it is not surprising that they reacted badly to this news. Like Australian farmers, many dealers are asset rich but money poor. If they had to pay that 20 per cent sales tax on current stock, according to figures from the Tractor Machinery Association of Australia, it is predicted that the average dealer would be looking at an up-front payment of $60,000 and the larger dealers an up-front payment of $200,000.

I do not think it is any secret that in the current climate, particularly in most of our rural areas, farm machinery dealers, who in many cases have been the hardest hit of all businesses in those rural communities, cannot afford to pay one extra dollar in tax, let alone tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars.

If it was decided that some or all dealers were not tax exempt, selling stock, particularly small spare parts, would have become an administrative nightmare. Sales tax would have been payable on every individual nut and bolt sold by any one of these dealers. The dealers also would have had to bear the cost of increased paperwork, which would have to have been regarded as more than just a nuisance because dealers simply could not afford to put on the extra staff that would be required to process the necessary paperwork. Then, of course, there is always the possibility that some dealers and some businesses would refuse to sell small items at great inconvenience to those whom they service.

Given all this, if this sales tax burden were to be borne by Australian farm machinery dealers, the potential risk would be the closure of many dealerships, even if the sales tax applied only to spare parts. With the closure of many dealerships, farmers would be forced to travel further than they already do—and they already travel enormous distances because of the effect of the recession in rural areas—maybe just to get a small item for the equipment that they are using.

Honourable senators might say that I am overreacting, but in the mid-1980s there were 2,500 dealerships across Australia; in 1992 there are only 800, and a staggering 16,000 jobs have been lost in the rural industry through dealerships and machinery agencies throughout Australia.

I will give my fellow senators an idea of the hardship that would have been caused had the dealers, who in some cases would not have been exempt, been forced to pay this 20 per cent sales tax on current stock and parts. These details have become known to me because, as I mentioned before, I was inundated by phone calls, letters and faxes from farm machinery dealers throughout South Australia—and I know that most other senators' offices have been inundated in the same way. It is a mistake to underestimate the importance of this issue to machinery dealers. Their very livelihoods are at stake and they have not hesitated to let us know about it.

The managing director of a farm machinery dealership in a small town in South Australia told me that the proposed changes would be a major impost on all rural Australia. In the case of his dealership and those of many other dealers like him, it `may well be the last straw'. He also told me that, as he understood the proposed changes at that time, dealers would have been forced to pass on to their farmers some of the cost of the 20 per cent sales tax. This, in turn, would cause producers to reconsider buying new machinery—and farmers have been finding it difficult enough to afford new machinery as it is without an increase in prices. They may have looked to repairing older machinery with spare parts to keep things running for longer than they would have normally—but of course this dealer was concerned that those prices might have risen too.

He was also concerned that the proposed changes would have resulted in less stock being held by businesses and dealers. As I have pointed out in my communications on this issue, farmers would then have to wait while the machinery or spare parts they wanted were ordered in. Honourable senators can just imagine the concern that this would cause at a time when many producers in rural Australia would be reaping and harvesting perishable items. Not only that, but emergency orders often attract a 5 per cent surcharge as well as freight charges.

So it is not difficult to see that it would not have been only dealers who suffered if forced to pay a 20 per cent sales tax; those whom they supply, the farmers and primary producers, would also have suffered by waiting longer and paying more for any stock that they might wish to acquire. This gentleman's letter to me concluded by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I manage a family company that has survived since 1905, with no thanks to the present Government. Six years ago I had two premises employing twelve people. Today I have one premise and employ four people, including my wife and myself.

PARA.TAB: Can't these people realise the pain, suffering and heartache that we in rural Australia have already been put through due to this Labor Government. Obviously they don't realise or don't care, seeing how they would think up something as potentially damaging as this legislation. I hope some commonsense will prevail.

SPEECH.PARA: Another farm machinery dealer also wrote to me telling me that the payment of a 20 per cent sales tax would send him and many other dealers broke, and I can cite letters from at least a dozen other small and large machinery firms throughout the whole of rural South Australia. In the past few years, these companies have reduced their staff by somewhere between 20 per cent and 60 per cent. None are in a position where they can afford to have any further imposts on their current business costs.

PARA.TAB: The Farm Machinery Dealers Association of Australia and the Tractor and Machinery Association of Australia have also been inundated with desperate calls. I am told that every one of the dealers who contacted them said they would have to reduce staff or shut their doors if a 20 per cent sales tax were imposed. When legislation such as this is being brought before this House, when people have been told that they will be consulted, when they have been told that they will be able to have input and express their concerns, we should not forget we are playing with people's lives. It is all very well to get carried away with debating or scoring points or winning votes, but at the end of the day people could be losing businesses and jobs because of the decisions we make. In fairness to all those people who have struggled through difficult times to try to keep these areas going, they should at least have been consulted and have had an opportunity to have some input into this legislation.

I know of dealers who were worried sick for a couple of months about the effect of any of these changes to the tax legislation. They live in many small country towns where they have no hope of getting a job if their dealership is forced to the wall. They are almost all family companies. So it is not just one job that is lost; it is the jobs of families.

In the Budget, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) talked about this Labor Government being a caring government which is creating jobs. Surely, the Treasurer must be jesting. Jobs would not need to be created if it was not for the thoughtless decisions—when legislation such as this was brought in in such haste and passed through the House of Representatives in such haste—that caused those jobs to be lost in the first place. This legislation was pushed through this Parliament almost without any proper debate, either in the other House or in this place, and, equally worrying, without consulting any of the dealer associations or the dealers themselves. The only way the Government could get away with this was to try to push this legislation through as quickly as possible.

I am glad to say that did not happen because dealers have now had the chance to voice their concerns to all members of Parliament, to all of their dealer associations. They have been able to make representations so that people are aware of many of the difficulties they are facing. This legislation would have only meant further difficulties which would have added to the imposts that the dealers already have. I am glad they had the chance to voice their concerns and, with Democrat support, the legislation was sent to a Senate select committee where these concerns were able to be expressed. Because of the pressure applied during those past weeks, the Government has been forced to back down in many significant areas of this legislation.

Naturally, I was happy to learn of the Government's about face in some areas of this so-called simplification, as detailed in the press release of 11 August 1992 which states that there are six areas of change, including those affecting leases, exempt use and deemed manufacturers. The Australian Financial Review of 12 August 1992 described these changes as an `embarrassing backdown', and I certainly agree with that. However, I am less than happy with the way in which the changes were announced—on the eve of the Select Committee's public hearings. The disruption caused by this late announcement is unacceptable, particularly to those people who were preparing submissions for the Committee.

The bottom line, however, is that this legislation should not exist at all and I will be satisfied only when this tax is abolished in its entirety and replaced with a goods and services tax where everybody knows what the sales tax charge is. The goods and services tax will get rid of this hidden consumption tax—the wholesale sales tax.

Given that we do have to suffer this legislation, the Tractor and Machinery Association of Australia and I are still very concerned about one aspect of the proposed legislation as it relates to farm machinery dealers; that is, that the Commissioner of Taxation still has the discretion to determine whether a machinery dealer can claim sales tax exemption at the time of purchasing his equipment. I understand that it has now been agreed that farm machinery dealers will be granted exempt status in 99 per cent of cases. But I believe that this exemption should be enshrined in legislation.

The Tractor and Machinery Association, other farm machinery dealer associations and the dealers themselves are still concerned; and some of them are still confused. The associations are unable to guarantee their members that the Tax Commissioner will give them a tax exempt status. I am sure that, despite the assurances the Tax Commissioner has given, there will still be farm machinery dealers losing sleep over whether their dealership will be one that is not granted a tax exempt status. The dealer associations, like me, do not think this legislation has been simplified at all. The community and business concern over the proposed changes has shown clearly that this Government has misjudged its own abilities to simplify anything, let alone something as complicated as the existing wholesale sales tax arrangements.

As I stated previously, I look forward to the time when sales tax, along with six other discriminatory and unfair taxes, is abolished in its entirety and replaced by a goods and services tax. There will then be no need for farm machinery dealers or any other businesses to be worried about whether they will be granted a tax exempt status. There will be no need for the Tax Commissioner to make the decisions. The dealers will collect the GST on the items they sell and pay the GST on the items they purchase, but there will be no imposition on them because this will be refunded before it ever has to be paid. They will be secure in the knowledge that all machinery sold to exempt primary producers will be exempt from this tax. There will not be classification disputes and there will be a single rate of tax that will be enshrined in legislation. I can only repeat a statement made by Coopers and Lybrand in its submission to the Select Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: As sales tax is a self-assessing tax, it is imperative that this "new" law, which replaces the existing sales tax legislation, meets all the tests of a good taxing statute, ie simplicity, equity, efficiency and certainty. In the generality, in our opinion, the legislation as it presently exists, fails all four tests.

I also echo the calls of my colleagues yesterday for Senator Kernot to apologise to Australian farm machinery dealers for the extra concern she has caused them by providing them with incorrect information about the way the coalition's goods and services tax will apply to their businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —She hasn't a clue about it, has she?

—She does not have any clue at all. In light of her comments, I will be writing to all farm machinery dealers in South Australia providing them with detailed and correct information about how the GST will apply to them and how they will benefit from the implementation of the rest of the Fightback package, including the abolition of seven other taxes which the Government seems so fond of but which the rest of us hate, including payroll tax, fuel excise and, perhaps worst of all, the wholesale sales tax.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that the manner in which the Government has dealt with this sales tax legislation has not endeared it to rural Australia. In fact, I believe it has merely put another nail in the coffin of Labor and this Government. It is arrogance in the extreme to try to pass legislation which would cause further hardship in the hardest hit sector of our whole community. That hardest hit sector is still the rural community throughout Australia.

I am very fortunate that in my own home State rural communities are presently enjoying the best season they have had for years. However, when we look around the rest of rural Australia and see the hardship in northern New South Wales and Queensland, we realise the hardships being experienced throughout rural Australia still make it the hardest hit community of all of the communities in this country of ours.

How much more does rural Australia have to suffer before this Labor Government wakes up to itself and the suffering that it has caused in those areas? How much longer before the Labor Government gets up the nerve to go to the polls, only to discover what we have known all along: that this country is in rack and ruin particularly in rural areas and a government is needed with new and innovative ideas and a course of action which will put the economy of this country and those areas which are hardest hit back on the right track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of six sales tax Bills highlights the very strength of the Senate and the absolute ability of the Senate to get some legislation actually looked at and hopefully made better than it could have been. These six Bills were rammed through the House of Representatives, as we all know, in some 45 minutes after the application of the guillotine. There was an attempt for the same thing to happen in the Senate. However, the committee system certainly stopped the Government from railroading flawed and faulty legislation on an unsuspecting and unwilling public.

PARA.TAB: With these Bills we have yet another example of the Government writing policy on the run—not once, but twice. Having pushed the Bills through the chamber, the process of the Senate Committee examination was well under way when the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) tried to abort the whole process by announcing major amendments to the legislation, almost negating the work that the Committee had done. I might add that this was done by the usual method that this Government has of determining policy—by press release. I refer the Senate to a press release put out by the Treasurer on 11 August with an embargo, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of introduction of the Bills, I gave a public commitment to consult widely to ensure that the new system will operate as smoothly as possible.
It has not been quite as smooth sailing as all that. He goes on to say:
The Government has received a number of submissions regarding the operation of the Bills which identify key areas of concern.

Basically, there are more than a few submissions that have expressed key areas of concern. There are quite a number of areas which have caused concern and which have been very well enunciated by the previous speaker, Senator Ferguson from South Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short has suggested elsewhere that this move by the Treasurer caused confusion to the work of the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. It also confused industry witnesses who had prepared evidence for the Committee based on what they had thought were the Bills to hand at the time. To my mind, the Treasurer was in contempt and showed utter disregard and disrespect for the work of the Senate and its committees.

The Australian Taxation Office has supposedly been working on this legislation for two years. What on earth was it doing for that length of time? It did not speak with industry, or it supposedly did not speak with industry. It did not examine the consequences of the Bills and it could not even get the amendments ready, those amendments already announced by the much used press release method, for the Select Committee to discuss.

How will business in this country—which is under a big threat from the Labor Government not only at the moment but has been for the last eight or nine years—operate when the rules keep changing? Not only do the goal posts get moved, but also the playing fields get moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Different grounds.

—Yes, different grounds and maybe different towns. Superannuation levies were on and then off again, and now sales tax. As I said, business in Australia has been forgotten by this Government. As we have heard, this legislation impacts widely on many sections of the business community. As is the hallmark of this Labor Government, there has been an almost total lack of consultation by the Tax Office. I think that has to be rectified in the future.

PARA.TAB: There has been a lack of consultation with the businesses and organisations that are most affected. The Government talks about consultation, but it does not really know the meaning of the word. The Treasurer suggests that he has been consulting widely with the community. I already made the point a minute ago that in his press release he said that he consulted widely, but he did not. That is really the problem of the legislation.

In reality, lots of people wrote to him telling him what a crummy lot of Bills he had drafted. That is what this Government calls consultation. It is saying, `We will listen, but we are terribly sorry, we do not have our hearing aids on and we actually have not got our glasses either. So if you send in a written submission, we cannot even read it'.

If this Government's intention with these Bills was to simplify the process of sales tax, and the Treasurer tells us that was the case, then clearly he and his Government have failed. It is interesting, when we think of the sales tax system, that at the moment there are something like five rates of sales tax: zero, 10 per cent, 15 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. It is very difficult for people with any product to know what is happening with sales tax, because they do not know what will be rammed on in the form of sales tax. That is the subject of another Bill that will be debated in this chamber in a little while. That is something that we will fix up in government. We will have a flat 15 per cent goods and services tax which, as Senator Ferguson made very clear, is refunded as a business input for those who are operating with it.

All this legislation is doing is complicating the issue even further. I will quote what would have happened if we had not had the Select Committee. Of course, the Ernst and Young critique of the legislation highlighted the point of sales tax simplification—and this is in the Bill. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner may determine that particular things are to be treated as not having happened, that particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time, that particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened and, where appropriate, to have been done by a particular person or to have happened at a particular time.
If that is called simplification, God help us. That wording does not simplify the sales tax regime.

PARA.TAB: Of course, for a bankrupt government, the fact that this legislation in this so-called simplifying process will raise an additional $91m is a mere incidental part of it. Certainly it is designed to reduce the number of Bills, if not the confusion that these new substituted Bills will create. No matter how the Keating Government fiddles with the books, and no matter how many times it robs Peter to pay Paul, the fact remains that the economic incompetence of the Government lives on.

Australians seeking a better way and a more efficient and effective system will have to be patient—although the waiting time is getting shorter every day—for a proper, thorough and responsible overhaul of the economy through the coalition's Fightback package. The quicker we can have an election, the quicker we can allow people to get this type of legislation fixed up and have a decent fight back for all Australians, and the better it will be.

Clearly, this Government has introduced this legislation not to provide an easier or improved sales tax regime for business—because I truly believe that there are too many examples to demonstrate the total lack of concern the Labor Government has for anyone in business today—but as a revenue raiser. The capacity of the Labor Government to raise revenue from the public by stealth is something that every Australian voter ought to remember and be reminded of on a regular basis.

Every time those on the other side of this chamber mention the coalition's GST in a pathetic and desperate way that is designed to scare the electorate, one only has to ask—and I ask those on the other side of the chamber now—what about the Government's grab bag from hidden taxes? What about the $9.4 billion that it rips off the unsuspecting taxpayer every year in sales tax on everything from babies' nappies to funeral caskets? Why has that trebled in the last nine years? Why have those opposite, as members of the Labor Party under Mr Keating, first as the Treasurer and now as the Prime Minister, trebled the sales tax take? It is now $9.4 billion that the Government is ripping off everyone in all those different areas of sales tax.

What about the tax on fuel? It is some $7.2 billion this year. What about the slightly less hidden taxes such as Medicare, which is raising some $2.5 billion, and income tax generally? Income tax generally this financial year will give the Government $66 billion. That is $66 billion ripped off the Australian people in personal taxes; $2.5 billion into Medicare, ripped off the Australian people by the Keating Labor Government; $7.2 billion in fuel tax—which the coalition will abolish—ripped off the Australian people; and $9.4 billion that this Government is ripping off people now in sales taxes.

I believe that the Government rightly deserves the title of the highest taxing government in Australia's history. That is not fiction; that is fact. Here is a government that runs scared every time we say we want a new vision for Australia, we want a Fightback and we want a GST which will be fair for all Australians. Every time this Government, that is ripping all that money off the Australian population now, tries to start a scare campaign. I believe that this Government deserves the title it has earned of the highest taxing government in Australia's history.
