It has earned it at the expense of struggling families, for which it should stand condemned.

As Senator Ferguson mentioned earlier, desperate farmers are littered across this country in increasing numbers. Despite the already demonstrated capacity of the Australian Taxation Office to extract more money from the public, these Bills have increased the powers of the Tax Commissioner so that he can treat transactions in whichever way he chooses. If there is no other reason for fearing these Bills, I believe that this reason alone is sufficient to say that they should not pass through this place. Given Senator Bishop's recent questioning of the impartiality of the Tax Office and its Commissioner, anything which gives the Tax Office wider discretionary powers is dangerous in the extreme.

Having established that the benefits of these Bills accrue almost exclusively to the Government, one must start to ask just how they adversely affect business. I have to look no further than what this legislation would have originally done to the farm machinery dealers which has been well spoken about by speakers here this afternoon and tonight. The farm machinery industry is a classic example of a group that the Tax Office did not bother to even think about. It did not give them a chance to come and put their point of view. Farm machinery is an industry that the Government has not bothered to understand or keep in contact with. Comments by Democrat senators and by Senator Kernot in her letter to everyone in machinery dealerships is absolutely an indictment of her lack of knowledge of what the GST is all about.

The Opposition's position on these Bills has been very well put by Senator Short and Senator Vanstone in their minority report to the Senate Select Committee. The lack of consultation is demonstrated again and again—the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Australian Society of CPAS, the Retailers Council, the Farm Machinery Dealers Association, the Journalists Association, the Photo Marketing Association, ACROD and the list goes on.

Yet the Treasurer tells us that he has consulted widely. I wonder what telephone box he met in, because I do not think that he actually consulted with many people. The minority report expressed the following view:

SPEECH.PARA: The hearings revealed that the Government's new proposed Wholesale Sales Tax would include a tax on food, a tax on services, a tax on exports, a tax on tourism, a tax on farmers, a tax on many manufacturers, double taxation, a tax on infrastructure and a tax on plant and buildings. These taxes are all the result of the fundamentally flawed Wholesales Sales Tax system, that this Labor Government seeks to retain.

As I have said, the current sales tax system is just not working. It is actually driving people to the economic grave. The quote I have just read highlights a government that is trying to tell the electorate that a one-off, up-front visible GST is unfair and discriminatory. The Government's sales tax which is in place at the moment is the most unfair and most discriminatory of any taxes. It is a tax that does not give incentive in any way.

PARA.TAB: Sales tax is a tax on goods. It has a cascading effect which results in a tax on all sorts of goods and services. It is paid and borne by business and is highly uncompetitive. It means that many Australian producers are left at a substantial disadvantage compared with overseas competitors, both in export markets and domestically. On that basis, I have to ask why the Labor Government is continuing to hang on to such an iniquitous tax regime at the expense of Australians and Australian business. If this package of Bills is its best attempt to simplify our tax system and make it more equitable, it ought to give the game away. Clearly, the task of managing Australia and its economy for the benefit of all Australians is definitely beyond the Keating Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 7.30 p.m., under the sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally, I do not rise to speak on the adjournment, especially on a Wednesday night, but this week has been a very heavy week for the Australian wheat industry. It is still reverberating from the shock waves sent out by President Bush's announcement last week. I will start by quoting from President Bush's address to both Houses of Parliament earlier this year, on 2 January 1992. I quote from the Hansard of that day, when Mr Speaker said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, on behalf of the members and senators of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, I welcome you to this meeting of the House of Representatives and the Senate.
It therefore gives me great pleasure to invite you to address assembled members and senators.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Whereupon honourable senators and honourable members rose in their places and applauded.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think anyone would be applauding Mr Bush right now, having regard to the announcement that he has made. Certainly, he would not be applauded by Australian wheat farmers. I quote from his speech of that day:

PARA.TAB: This region is the fastest growing market in the world, and still there are voices on both sides of the Pacific calling for economic isolationism. While for some nations, including Australia and the United States, these are tough, hard economic times, we both know that protectionism is a fundamentally bankrupt notion. Make no mistake: America will continue to stand for open trade and open markets. And trade means jobs—it means good jobs—at home and abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: Later in his speech he stated:

PARA.TAB: We both know, all of us know, that the real answer is what our two governments are doing—working hard for an historic new GATT arrangement that cuts back subsidies, especially for exports. That is why the United States is committed to working with GATT Director Dunkel's new text.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what President Bush of the United States said on 2 January, a short seven months ago. Last week we had that shock announcement. When I first heard it in the morning, I thought the figure was $4.1 billion. Fortunately, later in the day it was cut back to $1.4 billion—the two figures were taken back to front. Of course, there was no applause for that announcement.

PARA.TAB: Following Bush's visit subsidised wheat sales continued throughout Europe, Asia and wherever the United States could get sales. At the time I gave notice of a motion. In fact, as Senator Evans had been quoted in one of the local newspapers as saying he was annoyed by what was going on, I gave notice of the following motion, which was declared formal and carried the next day:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) welcomes the decision by the European Community (EC) to reform its huge farm subsidy program;
(b) notes that the biggest breakthrough is in the area of grain production; and
(c) requests the Government of the United States of America to accept the EC's new position and cut back its own subsidies.

The reason I gave notice of that motion was because the EC had decided that enough was enough and it was starting to make inroads into what was being done. Rather than subsidise further, it cut back on the acreage.

PARA.TAB: The very next day or so I was visited in my office by two officers from the United States Embassy in Canberra. One was Donald R. Cleveland, First Secretary, Embassy of the United States of America, and the other was L. Stuart Allan, Counsellor for Economic Affairs, Embassy of the United States of America. They gave me a verbal going-over and wanted to know what I was up to. They believed that the United States was doing enough and that Europe should be following it. I told them that the United States was continually carrying out subsidisation, even though President Bush had given us hope that this would not be the case when he addressed both Houses of Parliament, and also when he met the delegation from the National Farmers Federation.

They told me that the EC was the villain and they had to get out and fight it. While they were there they told me that exactly the same motion was passed by the Belgian Parliament that day. There was shock and horror that I should have the audacity to put forward such a motion, yet the Belgian Parliament passed the same motion. They also told me that my Party had never heard of the motion, nor had the Labor Party or anyone else.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not need to explain to you what is done with regard to a formal notice of motion in this place. It is taken to the Whip's office and is okayed by the Government, the Democrats, Senator Harradine—and I presume he represents the others in that corner—and the National Party. So everyone knew about it, yet they tried to tell me that that was not so. I told them that I believed that the EC was to blame, but it had made a start and I expected the United States to follow. They went back to their office and I carried on with my own business that day.

On 22 June, just before the winter recess, the President of the Senate received a letter from Mel Sembler, the Ambassador for the United States. Unfortunately, it was missed because of the rush of business that day. A couple of us wanted to speak on the matter but we were not in the chamber at the time. It will take a few minutes, but I intend to read the letter. Mr Sembler said:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Sibraa:

PARA.TAB: Thank you for providing me with the text of the Senate Resolution of 3 June `welcoming the decision of the European Community (EC) to reform its huge farm subsidy program,' and requesting the U.S. Government `to accept the EC's new position and cut back its own subsidies.'

I was quite surprised with the Resolution since it suggests that the EC has done all it needs to do to reform its Common Agricultural Policy, and to imply that action to reduce European export subsidies and market access barriers is of no concern to the Australian Senate. I wonder if Australian farmers would agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian farmers have certainly agreed with everything I have had to say on that matter. The letter continues:

PARA.TAB: The U.S. began reducing its internal price support levels and mandating acreage set aside four years ago. These U.S. policy reforms are part of the reason that U.S. wheat output has been reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: He could have fooled me! The letter continues:

PARA.TAB: We are glad that the EC is beginning to catch up with our reforms. It should be emphasized that even with its announced reforms, the EC has yet to address the issues of increased market access and decreased export subsidies, which remain much greater than U.S. subsidies.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no argument about that. The letter continues:

PARA.TAB: The U.S. and Australia are on record as favouring the compromise proposals on agricultural trade offered by GATT Director General Arthur Dunkel. These proposals call for specific reductions in internal support, increased market access and decreased use of export subsidies. Until and unless the EC addresses these two latter points, the U.S. will be unable to begin to revise our programs.
I hope this helps to clarify this complex issue.
Sincerely yours,
Mel Sembler
Ambassador

SPEECH.PARA: That is the letter that the President received on 22 June. Having read that letter, I will accept that this was starting to happen, but then, all of a sudden, the other day, just when the wheat industry of Australia has some hope of recovery, that shock announcement was made.

PARA.TAB: Since the announcement there has been dismay from the farmers, of course. The shock waves are still reverberating. Harvesting machinery dealers are losing harvesting orders—whether they have been cancelled or delayed pending the market outcome. There has been a rush on fixed wheat contracts offered by the Australian Wheat Board. The prices are fixed and the hope is that a reasonably stable price will be received. The United States has sold 600,000 tonnes of wheat to the Egyptian market this week, at prices ranging between $US109 per tonne down to $US103, with the subsidy being $US25 a tonne or, in other words, $A35 per tonne.

I will quickly look at the history of the wheat market in Australia over the last three years. In 1989-90, the pool returned to Australian wheat farmers for ASW10 grade wheat was $185 a tonne. The year after, with that big push from American subsidised sales—or the export enhancement program, I should say—they received $125 a tonne, which is $60 a tonne less. It just fell away in the last month before harvesting. That was one of the biggest contributing factors to wheat farmers being in the position they are now compared with two years ago.Last year, there was an improvement in prices because the Americans had a tougher season, they did not have so much wheat to sell and subsidise, and the Australian wheat price went back to approximately $180 a tonne. This year, we were hoping to reach the same price, and the Wheat Board, where I spoke to somebody today, was expecting much the same figure.

Fortunately, it is not all doom and gloom just yet. The price has not slipped away yet, but in time it can happen. The subsidisation of the Egyptian sale at $A35 a tonne is only the starter. It will immediately take $A35 off the $A180 a tonne, and that is certainly something Australian wheat farmers cannot handle at present.Worse still, in the 1990-91 season, there was a lot more wheat in the world but the subsidy was paid in extra grain. This year, the Americans are not going to do that; they are going to pay it in cash. So the effect, when it comes, will be greater. Of course, the cash subsidy will be more apparent and at least it will be on the table.

The United States has said that it will target our good markets of India, South Africa, Pakistan and, I suppose, Indonesia. The other day, we heard Pakistan and South Africa say that they will stand by us because they are buyers of the premium wheat—of our good wheat. Fortunately, the Australian Wheat Board had made a lot of forward sales, but it will not tell me what the figure is because that information is commercially confidential. Those countries do not want the American wheat, but they do want the American prices. Although they will remain true to us, we will be receiving American prices. That will reverberate right through the wheat industry and cause more problems to farmers who, with that bad downturn in prices of two years ago, regained their position last year slightly. It was hoped that they were going to be in front this year, but now all we can do is look forward to much the same situation of two years ago.

Let us hope that the Australian Government can persuade the Government of the United States to back off from its ill-conceived plan. I know that it is an election year in the United States, but as far as I am concerned the sooner that election is over the better and we can get back to normal thinking. That does not mean that the Government should not be working to do all it can to reverse the decision and help the farmers out of the situation they are in. Australian farmers are not looking for guaranteed minimum prices; they are not looking for subsidy. They are just looking for the Government to do what it should be doing for them so that they will be in a much better position if this situation continues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to this place the story of Goonininup, possibly better known as the Old Swan Brewery project. This continues to be a running sore and source of contention in the West Australian community. For many and varied reasons, the majority of the community decries the intransigent attitude of the West Australian Government. A recent poll gave the figure of 78 per cent for those opposed to the Government-authorised Multiplex redevelopment of the site.

PARA.TAB: Public outcry ranges across a broad spectrum. There is fear of the undesirable consequences of a development involving liquor outlets and increased traffic on a notoriously hazardous stretch of road which has regularly claimed lives and caused injury. There is outrage at the high-rise, over-the-top development at a time of recession. Just as we have a recession we did not want, we are forced to have in that development seven restaurants, a museum, an art gallery, the crowning glory of Multiplex offices on the top storey and a three-storey car park across the road.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a disgrace.

—It is a disgrace. There is scandal at giving this kind of prime real estate for a dollar a year for eight years to Multiplex at a time of recession. There is suspicion regarding the WA Inc. overtones of a deal which saw an inadequate tendering process and obscure and deceptive discussion of plans in Parliament.There is concern for and among Aboriginal people who regard this place as sacred ground—the dreaming track and resting place of the Waugal, or rainbow serpent. This latter concern has led to many Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal protesters forming a community picket and, day after day, facing clashes with police, arrest and the kind of undermining that results from actions such as that of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie sponsoring a divisive rally.

PARA.TAB: The community has gradually been deserted and betrayed by one after another of Government members who could have intervened. The list of people who have changed their minds goes on and on. The about-face by Jim McGinty on the importance of Aboriginal spirituality and heritage is well known. I quote from his speech on his entering Parliament as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . rather than maintaining a preoccupation with the important and powerful people of our society. . . I will endeavour during my term in this Parliament to. . . enhance the welfare of the Aboriginal people of this country. In this context the Old Swan Brewery dispute needs to be reconsidered. In my view it is a social justice issue rather than a simple question of whether one ought to preserve the old building.

This is from the Heritage Minister who has put out a special edition of the Government Gazette which excises the Swan Brewery precinct from the operation of any law, town council, metropolitan regional planning scheme and the Aboriginal Heritage Act.

PARA.TAB: Likewise, Gerry Hand, when he was Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1989, was able to change his mind in the space of a month. On 22 June 1989, Mr Hand wrote to Robert Bropho saying that he had decided to make a permanent declaration over the site after considering the report of Dr Senior. That permanent declaration was revoked only a month later because the then Dowding Government in Western Australia had given an undertaking to abide by the Western Australian Aboriginal Heritage Act, an Act, by the way, that has just been superseded by a Heritage Act. Mr Hand, in a letter to Isobel Weir said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will be taking a careful interest in the manner in which the site is dealt with under the Aboriginal Heritage Act (WA). The Perth Aboriginal community, of course, may apply to me under the Act in the future, should they consider that the site is endangered.

In spite of Mr Hand's assurances, all approaches to Mr Robert Tickner, the current Minister, have failed. The Federal Government has refused to intervene to protect the site and is not prepared to put on the public record an explanation for its failure to act.

PARA.TAB: Does the Federal Government lack the political will to act in defiance of the Lawrence Government? Have Mr Hand's files from his time as Minister not been transferred to Mr Tickner's office, or has Mr Tickner's voice been stifled by his Cabinet? The list of people who have changed their minds or stopped speaking goes on. What happened to the spirited opposition to the redevelopment of the site from Rory O'Connor, who wrote to Robert Bropho in July 1989, saying that the site was regarded as sacred by Dr Egloff, Dr Vinnicombe and Dr Senior? The letter was written specifically to reject claims made to the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council by Premier Dowding, as he then was. And what of Ken Colbung, who went to the Supreme Court in November 1987 to have redevelopment of the site stopped? He walked in the march organised by Mr Campbell. His application then was based on the fact that the site is sacred by virtue of its association with the Waugal and therefore is a site to which the Western Australian Aboriginal Heritage Act applies.

While it may be uncomfortable for some that their previous positions on the site are exposed for all to see, the record stands clear in newspaper clippings, in Hansard and in letters and papers. This is Dr Carmen Lawrence's Noonkanbah. This is an opportunity for reconciliation which may never be repeated. Some voices have given up and been silenced but others remain strong. I would like to quote from Mr Steve Mickler, talking about the claims of the Nyungah people:

SPEECH.PARA: Theirs is also a powerful heritage claim in a city without a single publicly visible, legally denoted Aboriginal space, in a State without any genuine form of Aboriginal land rights and having arguably now the worst manifestations of indigenous impoverishment, incarceration and cultural marginality.

All the more powerful because opinion polls show an overwhelming majority of Western Australians agree with Aboriginal protest leader Robert Bropho's demand that the old brewery be demolished and the site turned into parkland, albeit most for varied and different reasons than his.

We must remember that the Aboriginal people whom we have decimated, who still survive in the metropolitan area, have a claim in their spirituality to that site. However, they are being subjected to the much more strict claims of Aboriginal people in heritage areas whose culture and social organisation have not been decimated. As I said, fortunately not all voices have been silenced. I am sure that many people took encouragement from the stand made by Galarrwuy Yunupingu, who was quoted in the West Australian paper this morning:
GALARRWUY YUNUPINGU says he looks to the future and sees a beautiful park on the old Swan Brewery to be enjoyed by all West Australians.

PARA.TAB: The Northern Land Council chairman is in town with Aboriginal band Yothu Yindi, of which his brother, Mandawuy, is lead singer.
He joined opponents of Multiplex's $40 million redevelopment at the site yesterday morning.
He said he had sent protesters letters of support and then called for sacred sites protection.
`It is something which all Aboriginal people in this country have always believed in, that if there is any development, a sacred site should not be tampered with. It's our law,' he said.

`We believe in the freedom of our law and culture and that sacred sites should remain intact. They are the full value of our life. That's what we've lost, the identity of who we are and where we belong.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to close with a quote from the People's Earth Declaration which was compiled by the Non-Government Organisations Forum at the Global Forum `92, which met in Rio de Janeiro. One of the consensus points made in the document is as follows:

Indigenous people also bring vital leadership to the task of conserving the earth and its creatures and in creating a new life-affirming global reality. Indigenous wisdom constitutes one of human society's important and irreplaceable resources. The rights and contributions of indigenous people must be recognised.
The opportunity is in Western Australia now. What becomes of the old Swan Brewery can be a tragedy or a magnificent act of reconciliation for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate the problems surrounding the development of open learning in Australia. Open learning is a rapidly developing area of our education sector that is exceptionally important to our future. It has many different applications and has the capacity to make education more accessible to many Australians who, at present, are deprived of educational opportunities.

PARA.TAB: The potential of open learning has been established. The problem that we all face now is to ensure that the direction of open learning is not corrupted by politics and that the standard of education is maintained. It is critical that the correct guidance is given for the development of this exciting and dynamic sector of the Australian education system. This is particularly the case when the enormous advances in technology in recent times are considered and their application to this area of open learning.

Education providers should have the freedom to develop open learning in this country so that it meets the needs of the Australian people. Unfortunately, the flexibility needed is not likely to happen under the current Labor Government with its national unified system. This highly bureaucratic and inflexible system has shown that it cannot cope with the huge demand for places. This year, 50,000 eligible students were unable to obtain a place in universities and 150,000 were turned away from TAFE colleges. It certainly will not be able to cope with the tidal wave of demand for higher education building up in the adult and community education sector.

We are all aware of the damage created by the attitude of Mr Dawkins to the higher education sector with his so-called national unified system. `Big is better' is his motto. This is simply not the case. That approach is anathema to the concept of open learning. The current attitude of the Government is to allow two major players to dominate the open learning game, with the Open Learning Technology Corporation initiative. This will allow only a few associated institutions into the game, hanging on vainly trying to achieve something in the face of government policy. It will leave the rest of the higher education institutions which have an interest in open learning out on a limb, with no association with this new learning model which will ultimately leave them all behind the times.

Announced in the 1992 Budget was an open learning initiative based on a small pilot project commenced this year. It will be established from 1993 and will operate at a cost of $53m over the next three years. University accredited units of study will be provided through distance learning courses and television open learning programs. Participants will pay charges which approximate HECS contributions paid by other students. No government financial support will be provided after 1995. Clearly, the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, must have been kidding himself if he believed the following statement that he made on Budget night:

SPEECH.PARA: In short, every Australian with access to a television and a letter box can now have access to a university education.

The Government's new plan has developed in the following way: in April 1991 the Australian Education Council working party set up a national education communications framework. In June 1992, the AEC, in conjunction with the Ministerial Council on Vocational Education, Employment and Training, or MOVEET, agreed to the recommendations of the working party establishing the new Open Learning Technology Corporation to provide brokerage and other functions related to open learning for education and training providers throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: The corporation is intended to play a significant role in fostering the collaborative development of open learning in this country. Fortunately, all this planning will come to fruition after the next election and the coalition will be taking a very different approach. It will ensure that open learning, while given guidance and support, will not be subjected to the heavy-handed bureaucracy that the Government is currently proposing.

Under the plan envisaged by the current Labor Government, we will see a system increasingly dominated by two higher education institutions—the University of Queensland and Monash University. This consortium, established to foster open learning, is already on the way to disintegration after only a few months in place and other questions must be raised about the current expressions of interest that have been called for in the open learning process. These were called for initially in July, with the closing date in September. This is an unusually short period for such a major area as the future of open learning.

What is the reason for the rush? It would seem that the Government has election jitters. It is worried about the unmet demand for 50,000 tertiary places in universities and 150,000 TAFE positions and it wants to be seen to be doing something before it gets to the next election. It sees open learning as a convenient way out, hence the ridiculous claim in the Budget that every Australian with access to a television or letter box will have access to a university education.

Another problem with what has been suggested by Mr Baldwin in the Budget is the very suspect figures that he uses. It would appear that the Minister has not really done his sums properly; $53m would not seem to be enough to achieve the result that the Government is talking about. Certainly, the HECS fee will not cover much of the cost of open learning per student if it is done properly. Open learning is not about throwing instructional materials at someone and saying, `Turn up for an exam'. Open learning must also involve backup assistance such as proper conferencing feedback, vacation schools and a lot of very time-consuming assessment, guidance and counselling.

In the end, open learning, when carried out properly, is no cheaper than providing normal tuition, and all the research here in Australia and overseas supports that. Mr Baldwin's Budget announcement is merely a cheap political gimmick a few months before an election—something that appears to solve the problem of unmet demand.The TV initiative that has been proposed has potential but it should be developed properly and carefully over time. The current plan will not help open learning in the long run and it still leaves tens of thousands of eligible students with no access to a tertiary education, plus the gathering demand of the adult and community education sector.

Until universities and colleges are given the freedom to offer additional places to undergraduates beyond those funded by the Government, the problems of unmet demand in this country for higher education will not be solved. It follows that the institutions providing the services should be given the right to set realistic fees. This is the only way we will get supply and demand to balance in this sector. When this happens, rigid controls on undergraduate fees currently imposed will have broken down.

The open learning initiative seems to be the beginning of the end of the Dawkins/Baldwin centrally regulated system. Once it is demonstrated that universities can be given financial freedom with regard to open learning, it should not be long before commonsense prevails and this freedom is extended to all aspects of higher education. That at least is the wish.A Federal election will be held before anyone can tell whether Mr Baldwin's brave new world is going to be a success or a failure. Open learning needs the coalition's approach of freedom and flexibility so that demands on the education sector can be met and the needs of the users of education can be fulfilled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my first opportunity to speak in honour of Sir Harold White, who died on the last day of August and whose funeral service was held at St John's Church here in Canberra two days ago. Sir Harold was the great force behind the establishment and development of our Parliamentary Library and the establishment of the National Library of Australia. I fondly remember the years when I was a member of the Library Committee of this Parliament. I now serve as one of the two parliamentarians representing the Parliament on the Council of the National Library.

PARA.TAB: Sir Harold White was a great man. His intelligence, and his determination to build great institutions of knowledge and learning in this city for all Australians, ought to be clearly and gratefully remembered at the time of his passing. He was born in Victoria in 1905. He joined the Commonwealth Library at the age of 18 and retired at the age of 65. He gave almost 50 years service to the central library institutions of this country at the point of their formation. He was the Parliamentary Librarian for 23 years—almost a quarter of a century—from 1947 until his retirement from that position in 1970. Because the National Library of Australia grew out of our Parliamentary Library and was intended to grow from it, at the same time as being Parliamentary Librarian he was the first National Librarian from 1960 until his retirement eventually in 1970.

The shape of the collections, and the services provided to parliamentarians in this building and to all Australian citizens in the National Library, owe a great debt to the carefulness of this most active man. When I think about the era in which he flourished, he stands alongside Sir Robert Menzies, the Prime Minister whom he knew so very well and whom he served, along with every member of parliament. It is in the Menzies generation that I salute Sir Harold White. I do not mean to imply that he had any particular sharing of the policy agenda of that great Prime Minister and founder of the Party that I belong to, but he is of that kind of stature, not only in terms of his contribution to the libraries of our country but also as a citizen of this country. I hold him in very high esteem.

When he stayed on as the Parliamentary Librarian in his last years, it was not least to establish the legislative research service which is available and currently used by the great majority of parliamentarians to very real effect. I speak of a body of scores of well-qualified graduates with specialised interests and responsibilities to develop a comprehensive knowledge as a base for giving advice to every member of Parliament. We have a service in the Parliamentary Library which is incomparable with any that is given in any educational or library institution in this country. I particularly recognise his contribution to the establishment of that service.

I met with Sir Harold White on a number of occasions. The time that I most remember was when the Queen was opening this new Parliament House in 1988. We happened to meet by the copy of the Magna Carta—one of the few original copies—which sets out one of the first great statements of the political rights and human rights of citizens. It is a foundational statement for parliaments anywhere at any time. Whilst I was in this new building seeing where this important document was being housed and exhibited, it happened that I met with Sir Harold again.

SPEECH.PARA: We talked in a very excited way about this great document. He related to me, as is well known to many, that he found this document himself and persuaded the government of the day to come up with $25,000—in 1952 it was #12,500—to make this purchase. Of course, it is worth millions of dollars now. It is very apt that we have such an original document of such foundation and importance in the history of all parliaments here in our building. I also note that he knew all the Prime Ministers of this country closely, from Scullin onwards. He had dealings on a personal basis and as an adviser to Prime Ministers of all political persuasions throughout his lifetime.

PARA.TAB: He is survived by his four children: David, who is a professor at the Melbourne University; John, who is the Chief Executive of the New South Wales Farmers Association; Judith, who is the director of research at a scientific institution in Paris; and Katherine, who is a research scholar at the University of Canberra. I pass on to them my own condolences at the passing of their father. I think I can speak in a representative capacity on behalf of all parliamentarians and, indeed, the public of Australia in recognising the contributions that their father, Sir Harold White, made to the benefit of us all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: National Food Authority Act—Direction and Statement of Reasons under section 11, 1 July 1992.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What cultural programs are offered by the Department for implementation in overseas countries.
(2) How are cultural programs promoted overseas.
(3) What is the total departmental expenditure on cultural programs overseas, both capital and recurrent costs.
(4) What methods of co-ordination are applied to maximise the availability of cultural programs on an equitable basis relevant to the size of each individual diplomatic post.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Delivery of cultural programs overseas is not a function carried out by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. The responsibility for such program delivery rests with the various Portfolio Statutory Authorities within broad policy parameters established in conjunction with the Australia Abroad Council of the Department of Foreign Affairs. Details of these programs are as follows:

(1) The Australia Council has an International Cultural Relations Policy, and the individual art form boards of the Council allocate resources to international activity (both export and import) on a project by project basis, as part of their market development, and promotional, advocacy and professional development activities. In addition, the Council administers a central International Advocacy program to facilitate international activities across art forms.

(2) The objective of the Council's International Cultural Relations Policy is to enhance knowledge and appreciation by persons in other countries of Australian arts and the ways in which they help foster expression of a national identity.
In order to achieve this objective the Australia Council has endorsed the following strategies:
(a) develop and promote international recognition and appreciation of Australian cultural identity through cooperation and exchange;
(b) assist the coordination of international activity by government and non-government cultural agencies;
(c) assist the coordination of exchanges of information relating to current or future opportunities for cultural relations;
(d) represent the cultural interest of Australia in foreign countries; and
(e) assist, directly or indirectly, Australian artists and cultural organisations in international cultural relations.
Each grant recipient is responsible for his/her own promotion at home and abroad. The scale and level of that promotion will vary from project to project.
(3) The total Australia Council expenditure on its international program in 1991-92 was approximately $4.43m.
This figure does not present the complete picture as the international activity of funded organisations in Australia, which is considerable, is not included.

(4) The Australia Council's funds are not allocated on the basis of the relative size of Australia's posts or missions abroad. The Council's International Advocacy Program ensures coordination across all Council programs.

Last year the Council developed its Asia Pacific Connections policy which aims to redistribute existing resources. In 1990-91 about 12.5% of the budget for international programs was allocated to Asian or Pacific oriented projects. In 1991-92 this figure rose to 20.5% and in 1992-93 the target is 50%.

(1) The Australian Film Commission engages in programs of activity designed to promote Australian film and television internationally. As film is both a cultural and commercial product the AFC undertakes activities designed to develop the commercial demand for Australian programs and projects designed to enhance the critical reputation of Australian film and television. Commercial market development activities are undertaken as special film events which nevertheless have a significant cultural importance. The cultural promotion of Australian film and television is undertaken via the established international film festival circuit for which the AFC recommends Australian titles and co-ordinates Australian entries.

In 1991-92 the AFC's major special event was the continuation of le Cinma Australien—a three month season presenting a critical overview of Australian cinema at the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris. Launched on 28 May 1991, the season ran through June and July with a summer recess in August and concluded on 14 October 1991. Over 100 Australian titles were screened covering the period 1896 to 1991. Total attendances numbered 24,804. In addition, the AFC assisted in the presentation of an Aboriginal film and video program in Dournanez (France), a presentation of a contemporary Australian cinema in Verona (Italy) and a program of Australian feature films at Cine-Expo in Seville.

An extensive program of Australian feature films, shorts and documentaries was broadcast on Channel Four in the United Kingdom in July and August 1991. This program was the result of several years of negotiation between the AFC and Channel Four.

In 1991-92, 163 Australian titles were selected for screening at 127 international film festivals. (These figures do not include Australian titles screening at special events such as Verona, Dournanez, film Society of the Lincoln Centre, Moscow International Film Festival or the Essen Children's Film Festival). Many titles received multiple festival entries, most notably Proof, Waiting, The Good Woman of Bangkok, A Woman's Tale and Black Robe.

(2) Promotion of the AFC's special events is undertaken via a variety of means depending on the specific nature of the project. These promotional strategies include the employment of specialist film publicists in the territory in which the program is being presented; through the normal promotional activities of the organisation hosting the event; through the production of publications or promotional materials designed for circulation in the host country; via international trade advertising and, where appropriate, via articles in the Australian trade and domestic press.
(3) In 1991-92 the AFC's total expenditure on cultural programs overseas including both capital and recurrent costs was $949,417.59.

(4) The AFC advises the Cultural Relations Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australia Abroad Council (of which the AFC is a member) and the diplomatic post in the territory for which a project is scheduled in order to enable the post to make suitable diplomatic use of the proposed activity or event. However, the size of the Australian diplomatic mission in any territory is not one of the criteria used by the AFC to determine which international territories to target for its annual international festival program or its special film and television events.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Film, Television and Radio School (AFTRS)

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Film, Television and Radio School conducts overseas training programs such as in-country courses, workshops, seminars, conferences and screenings of student productions in the Asia-Pacific region.
The AFTRS encourages student exchanges and staff exchange/secondment with Europe, America and the Asia-Pacific region.
The AFTRS also produces training videos and publications which are distributed through specialist distribution agencies in America and the Asia-Pacific region.

(2) These programs and products are promoted through direct contact with Australian and overseas government departments, the industry, educational institutions; the AFTRS' membership with CILECT (Centre International de Liaison des coles des Cinma et de Tlvision); word-of-mouth and information brochures.

(3) There are no capital costs. The programs are largely funded through overseas agencies and/or government sponsorship (ie AIDAB, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade) and to a lesser extent, scholarships.
The AFTRS expenditure for overseas training programs in the financial year 1991-92 was $12,876.
(4) The AFTRS responds to opportunities and needs of recipient countries as well as taking advice from individual diplomatic representatives.
(1) The Australian National Gallery from time to time develops or coordinates exhibitions for international display. Projects currently under consideration include:
an exhibition of Southeast Asian textiles to be displayed at The Asia Society from 8 September 1992 to 17 January 1993;
an exhibition of Aboriginal works of art to travel to France, Spain and possibly Japan; and
other exhibitions will of course arise or will be developed.

In addition in the 1992-93 year the Gallery will house an exhibition of Khmer sculpture from the National Museum of Cambodia. We are hopeful of also providing ongoing assistance to that institution during Cambodia's period of reconstruction.

(2) The Australian National Gallery's promotion of exhibitions is usually arranged in conjunction with those international institutions in which the exhibitions are displayed. At times the Gallery also provides particular exhibitions to assist specific cultural agendas. In the last year an exhibition of Max Dupain photographs was displayed in the Philippines to coincide with the opening of the new Australia Centre in Manila.

(3) The expenditure of cultural programs overseas by the Gallery varies according to the number of exhibitions and other activities in which the Gallery engages. In the 1992-93 year the Gallery would expect to incur approximately $100,000 on these international activities. Total expenditure will exceed this sum, with contributions coming from other sources, including overseas institutions, sponsorship etc.

(4) The coordination issue is not particularly relevant to the Gallery's international exhibition program. The program tends to be directed to specifically cater for previously identified needs or to respond to specific requests from overseas institutions.

(1) Film Australia's National Interest Program ($18 million 1992-94), a program of films intended primarily for Australian audiences, is actively promoted and sold in more than 55 countries. They achieve prominent exhibition on both public and commercial broadcast, satellite and cable systems and contribute significantly to the cultural profile of Australia

(2) To maximise the exhibition and exploitation of all Film Australia's programs and an increasing number of independent films, Film Australia runs a marketing and distribution operation which looks to overseas markets for more than 50% or its revenue ($5.4 million gross revenue 1991-92).
Film Australia

maintains an extensive network of overseas contacts and attends major international film and television marketplaces and trade fairs which are frequented by film and television users and buyers. It enters films into all major international festivals;
maintains regular contact with direct mailing and telephoning;
carries out publicity campaigns both nationally and internationally;
and publishes catalogues and brochures for wide distribution.
(3) Film Australia spends between $150,000 and $200,000 on its overseas commercial activities. Target revenue for all programs in 1992-93 from the international market is over $3 million.
(4) Film Australia supplies comprehensive information to diplomatic posts on National Interest Programs and is an active member of the working party of the Australia Abroad Council.

(1) to (4) The National Film and Sound Archive does not offer any programs for implementation in overseas countries. It does however provide assistance to programs of other government agencies, specifically the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Film Australia. Forms of assistance include the provision of technical and management advice to film and/or sound heritage organisations in developing countries (eg. Indonesia, Vietnam, Laos) and the provision of Australian Heritage film footage for exhibition and screening. On occasions the Archive also undertakes direct involvement in exhibition programs overseas. A forthcoming event of significance is the screening of a retrospective of Australian silent films at the Pordenone Silent film Festival, in Italy in September, 1992.

(1) The Library has a wide ranging international program. Under the Library's Regional Cooperation program the Library assists, both directly and in cooperation with other agencies, in the development of library services and infrastructure in the Asia-Pacific region. This assistance is mainly through the provision of training, both in-country and in Australia, including training in preservation and conservation of library materials. The Library presently provides assistance to 23 libraries in the region. The Library has relations at differing levels with all the major national libraries. A number of Australia's cultural agreements have formal provisions naming the Library in arrangements for the exchange of library materials.

In the case of China there is an ongoing formal arrangement for an exchange of official visits by delegations of library professionals, usually led by the Director-General. The most recent in the series was the visit of Australian librarians to China in May 1991 led by the Director-General. The Library's materials are sought (and generally provided) for major overseas exhibitions. Recently the Library's exhibition An Encounter with Eden, prepared as part of Australia's contribution to the Treaty of Waitangi commemoration, has been touring New Zealand.

(2) Information of the Library's activities is disseminated through direct correspondence, through briefings to staff or individual diplomatic posts, and through relevant local and international, general and professional, journals and newsletters. Representation at overseas conferences including those sponsored by UNESCO, (such as APINESS, Asia-Pacific Information Network in Social Sciences; and ASTINFO, Asian Scientific and Technologies Information Organisation), CONSAL, Congress of Southeast Asian Librarians, and IFLA also raise awareness of the Library's and Australia's contribution in the field of library development.

The Library's International Cooperation Program includes annual contributions to the core programs of the International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions (IFLA) and to the International Serials Data System (ISDS).
(3) The National Library of Australia's total identifiable expenditure on cultural programs overseas in 1991-92 was $99,550.

(4) None. The Library's assistance in the Asia-Pacific region is given in response to requests from the recipients on the basis of need in the country; this is not in any way related to the size of the diplomatic post.

(1) The Centre has no specific programs for implementation in overseas countries, however, it provides advice, technical assistance and generally co-operates when approached to support other country's initiatives to increase awareness of science and technology;
(2) The Centre does not actively promote its programs overseas;
(3) The cost to the Centre, outside providing advice, in the support of other country's initiatives is recovered from sponsors or the country involved;
(4) Because the Centre generally responds to requests from other countries, no co-ordination is required except that the Centre advises the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the approach.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Will the Minister explain why, in the 1992 National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) Guidelines, reference to both low and intermediate level nuclear waste have been dropped from both the titles and the text; (b) will the Minister explain why the specified permissible levels of radioactivity have been increased across the board in the 1992 Guidelines; and (c) will the Minister explain why the NH&MRC has decided to abandon defining radioactive wastes in its Code and Practice for Disposal of Radioactive Wastes.

(2) (a) Will the Minister explain why, when the 1990 guidelines made specific reference to Maralinga as a possible source of waste, the reference has been dropped from the 1992 draft Code and Guidelines; (b) will Maralinga be a source of waste for a national waste repository; (c) conversely, will the Minister comment on reports that Maralinga could be the site of a national waste repository; (d) will the Minister specify whether intermediate level waste will be disposed of at the chosen state/national disposal site; if so, will the Minister ensure that the title for the Code and Guidelines properly reflects the types of waste that are to be disposed of in accordance with internationally recognised categories.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Reference to low level and intermediate level radioactive waste has not been included in the 1992 draft Code of Practice for the Near Surface Disposal of Radioactive Waste in Australia and the associated Guidelines document because it was considered preferable to categorise the material for disposal in terms of quantitative criteria in the form of activity concentration limits for the radionuclides in question. As a result of public comment on the previous draft, it was apparent that the terms "low level" and "intermediate level" as applied to radioactive waste lack sufficient precision for use in the Code of Practice.

(1) (b) The radionuclide activity concentration limits given in the 1992 draft have been increased compared with those in the 1990 draft because the public dose limit used to derive them has been raised from the arbitrary value of 0.5 millisievert used in the 1990 draft to the 1.0 millisievert public dose limit currently recommended by the NH&MRC. However, the concept of a dose constraint has also been introduced in the 1992 draft meaning that other sources of exposure must be considered. In practice this could result in a reduction in the activity concentration limits for a specific facility. The choice of the value for this constraint is the responsibility of the appropriate authority as defined in the draft Code.

(1) (c) The term "radioactive waste" is defined on page 4 of the 1992 draft document which was made available for public comment and remains in the current version. I am advised that it is unlikely to be deleted by the NH&MRC.

(2) (a-b) I understand that reference to Maralinga as a possible source of waste was deleted following consideration of the final report of the Technical Assessment Group "Rehabilitation of Former Nuclear Test Sites in Australia" (1990) in which the rehabilitation options all involved disposal of radioactive materials at the test sites.
(2) (c) The Government has no intention of establishing a national radioactive waste repository at Maralinga.

(2) (d) The draft Code of Practice covers the disposal of radioactive wastes which could be characterised as short-lived intermediate wastes in a national shallow ground burial repository site. The Code precisely describes the nature of the radioactive wastes suitable for disposal at such a site. The NH&MRC, which has the responsibility for developing the Code of Practice, considers that the present title accurately reflects the contents of the Code and is consistent with international practice in naming such a document.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence upon notice, on 6 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) If, as stated in the Minister's reply to question on notice no.1869 (Senate Hansard 26 May 1992, p.2684), the Army does not maintain a list of personnel issued with the Vietnam Medal and of personnel yet to be issued with it, in what form does the Army keep its information of personnel to whom the Vietnam Medal has been issued and personnel entitled to the medal but not yet issued with it.
(2) Of the 41,910 Army personnel stated to have served in Vietnam, how many are entitled to the Vietnam Medal.
(3) What steps, if any, has the Army taken to facilitate the issuing of the Vietnam Medal to those entitled to it but not yet issued with it.
(4) What is the procedure to be followed by a person, entitled to the Vietnam Medal but not having received it, to apply for it.
(5) In Military Board Instruction 102-3 of 23 December 1968 concerning the Vietnam Medal, is there a typographical error in the reference to `condition 7a' in Note 2 to clause 7 on page 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Information concerning those personnel who have been issued the Vietnam Medal and those personnel who are entitled to the medal but not yet issued with it, is contained in each individual's personal dossier, which is held by the Soldier Career Management Agency.

(2) The Army is not able to state how many of the 41,910 Army personnel who served in Vietnam are entitled to the Vietnam Medal, as this information is contained on each individual's personal dossier and is not maintained on any list.

(3) From September 1988 to the end of February 1989 the Army undertook an extensive public relations advertising campaign, advising ex Vietnam service personnel to write to the Soldier Career Management Agency and request their individual Vietnam medal entitlements.

(4) The procedure to be followed by a person entitled to the Vietnam Medal but not having received it, is to write to the Soldier Career Management Agency and request the medal be issued. The person should include in the letter, regimental details, unit of service in Vietnam, current address, date and place of birth and any other information which will help to identify the member.

(5) Yes, there was a typographical error contained in the Military Board Instruction (MBI) 102-3 of 23 December 1968. The error was amended shortly after the MBI was issued. The reference to `condition 7a' in Note 2 to clause 7 on page 2 was amended to read `condition 7b'.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year for Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and co-ordinating activities for International Year for Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) My Portfolio is currently planning a number of activities to celebrate the Year. These activities include film festivals, research projects into Aboriginal cultural heritage, a round trip berth to Antarctica for an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander, joint displays within Portfolio heritage and collecting institutions, and a reciprocal international exchange program for an indigenous ranger/trainee to observe indigenous land management practices.

(3) Two Departmental officers are members of the 1993 International Year for the World's Indigenous People Interdepartmental Committee which is chaired by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year for Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and co-ordinating activities for International Year for Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2)In conjunction with ATSIC, my Department has an ongoing project to facilitate the phased introduction of appropriate award coverage for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples' organisations and their employees. To administer this project, the Department has established an Aboriginal Awards Project Unit in its Central Office and designated Aboriginal Liaison Officers in each of its State and Territory Offices.

To enhance activities during the International Year for the World's Indigenous People (IYWIP) the resources available for this project have been increased. These activities will include helping Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations to develop appropriate awards and conducting seminars, workshops and training courses to increase Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples' understanding of and effective participation in Australia's Industrial relations system.

The Department is also considering other activities that it may undertake in 1993 such as: promoting specific Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples' proposals under the Workplace Reform component of its Workplace Reform and Best Practice programs; and increasing the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff employed by the Department, particularly in State, Territory and District Offices.

(3)My Department is represented on the IYWIP Inter-Departmental Committee that is planning the calender of events for 1993. The Aboriginal Awards Project Unit of my Department will be working with ATSIC and will co-ordinate the Department's activities during the year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year for Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and coordinating activities for International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The Department of Tourism and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) are currently working together to develop a National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Tourism Strategy.

This strategy will be implemented during the International Year for the World's Indigenous People and will support and encourage tourism initiatives that have been identified as being of particular relevance and priority to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
The Strategy will involve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people in project initiation, design, planning, implementation and evaluation.
